subdebateinfo.title: Data Availability and Transparency (Consequential Amendments) Bill 2020

p.span: Data Availability and Transparency (Consequential Amendments) Bill 2020
Consideration of Senate Message
Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be considered immediately.
(1) Schedule 1, page 3 (line 3), omit the heading.
(2) Schedule 1, item 1, page 3 (lines 4 to 13), omit the item.
(3) Schedule 1, item 4, page 3 (lines 24 to 29), omit the item.
(4) Schedule 1, item 5, page 4 (lines 4 to 16), omit subsection 7(2F), substitute:

(2F) An agency that is a data scheme entity within the meaning of the Data Availability and Transparency Act 2022 is exempt from the operation of this Act in relation to a document that contains scheme data within the meaning of that Act, to the extent the document contains such data.
(5) Schedule 1, page 4 (before line 18), before item 6, insert:
Insert:

span.span: 36B Complaints relating to the data sharing scheme

p.span: (1) If a complaint relates to the data sharing scheme within the meaning of the Data Availability and Transparency Act 2022, the Commissioner may share information and documents about the complaint with the National Data Commissioner (the NDC), for the purposes of the NDC exercising powers, or performing functions or duties, under that Act.

(2) The Commissioner may share only information and documents under subsection (1) that were acquired by the Commissioner in the course of exercising powers, or performing functions or duties, under this Act.

(3) To avoid doubt, the Commissioner may share information or documents with the NDC under this section whether or not the Commissioner is transferring the complaint or part of the complaint to the NDC.
Note: The Commissioner may transfer the complaint to the NDC under section 50, if the Commissioner is of the opinion that the complaint could have been made to the NDC.
(6) Page 4 (after line 29), at the end of the bill, add:

(1) An entity may apply for accreditation as an accredited user or an ADSP under section 76 of the Data Availability and Transparency Act 2022 on or after the day after the end of the period of 4 months beginning on the day this Act receives the Royal Assent.

(2) However, an entity that is a Commonwealth body, a State body or a Territory body may apply for accreditation as an accredited user under section 76 of the Data Availability and Transparency Act 2022 on or after the day after the end of the period of 2 months beginning on the day this Act receives the Royal Assent.
(3) Applications for accreditation as an accredited user or an ADSP under section 76 of the Data Availability and Transparency Act 2022 may not be made except in accordance with subitems (1) and (2).
(1) In this Schedule:
DAT Act means the Data Availability and Transparency Act 2022.
rules means rules made by the Minister under item 4.
transitional entity means an Australian entity prescribed by the rules.
transition period, for a transitional entity, means the period prescribed for the entity by the rules.
(2) Other expressions used in this Schedule that are also used in the DAT Act have the same meaning in this Schedule as they have in the DAT Act.
(1) For the purposes of the data sharing scheme, a transitional entity is taken, during its transition period, to be accredited as an ADSP under the DAT Act.

(2) The rules may prescribe conditions of accreditation applicable to a transitional entity. For the purposes of the data sharing scheme as it applies because of subitem (1), any such condition is taken to have been imposed by the Commissioner under section 78 of the DAT Act.
Note: Under section 78 of the DAT Act as it applies because of subitem (1), the Commissioner may vary or remove a condition prescribed by the rules, or impose other conditions.
(3) The transition period for a transitional entity must end no later than the earlier of the following:
(a) if the Commissioner cancels the entity's accreditation as an ADSP under section 81 of the DAT Act—the day the cancellation takes effect;
(b) the end of the period of 40 months beginning on the day this Act receives the Royal Assent.

span.span: 3 This Schedule is part of the data sharing scheme

p.span: The data sharing scheme is taken to include this Schedule and the rules.
(1) The Minister may, by legislative instrument, make rules prescribing matters:
(a) required or permitted by this Schedule to be prescribed by the rules; or
(b) necessary or convenient to be prescribed for carrying out or giving effect to this Schedule.
(2) To avoid doubt, the rules may not do the following:
(a) create an offence or civil penalty;
(b) provide powers of:
(i) arrest or detention; or
(ii) entry, search or seizure;
(c) impose a tax;
(d) set an amount to be appropriated from the Consolidated Revenue Fund under an appropriation in this Act;
(e) directly amend the text of this Act.
Ms LEY (Farrer—Minister for the Environment) (10:51): I move:
That the amendments be agreed to.
Question agreed to.

subdebateinfo.title: Security Legislation Amendment (Critical Infrastructure Protection) Bill 2022

p.span: Security Legislation Amendment (Critical Infrastructure Protection) Bill 2022
Consideration of Senate Message
Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be considered immediately.
(1) Schedule 1, page 4 (after line 14), after item 7, insert:
Insert:
critical component of a critical infrastructure asset, means a part of the asset, where absence of, damage to, or compromise of, the part of the asset:
(a) would prevent the proper function of the asset; or
(b) could cause significant damage to the asset;
as assessed by the responsible entity for the asset.
(2) Schedule 1, page 5 (after line 21), after item 11, insert:
Insert:

critical worker
means an individual, where the following conditions are satisfied:
(a) the individual is an employee, intern, contractor or subcontractor of the responsible entity for a critical infrastructure asset to which Part 2A applies;
(b) the absence or compromise of the individual:
(i) would prevent the proper function of the asset; or
(ii) could cause significant damage to the asset;
as assessed by the responsible entity for the asset;
(c) the individual has access to, or control and management of, a critical component of the asset.
(3) Schedule 1, item 71, page 64 (after line 25), after paragraph 52B(3)(a), insert:
(aa) the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Intelligence and Security;
(4) Schedule 1, page 68 (after line 29), at the end of the Schedule, add:
Insert:
(1) The Secretary must give the Minister a report relating to the conduct, progress and outcomes of consultations undertaken by the Department in relation to:
(a) the amendments made by the Security Legislation Amendment (Critical Infrastructure Protection) Act 2022; and
(b) the amendments of this Act made by the Security Legislation Amendment (Critical Infrastructure) Act 2021;
during a designated reporting period (see subsection (4)).
(2) The Minister must give a copy of a report under subsection (1) to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Intelligence and Security.
(3) A report under subsection (1) must not include personal information (within the meaning of the Privacy Act 1988).
(4) For the purposes of this section, designated reporting period means:
(a) the period beginning at the commencement of this section and ending at the earlier of the following times:
(i) the end of the 6-month period that began at the commencement of this section;
(ii) the time when the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Intelligence and Security began to conduct a review under section 60B; or
(b) the period beginning immediately after the end of the immediately preceding designated reporting period and ending at the earlier of the following times:
(i) the end of the 6-month period that began immediately after the end of the immediately preceding designated reporting period;
(ii) the time when the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Intelligence and Security began to conduct a review under section 60B.
(5) Schedule 1, page 68, at the end of the Schedule (after proposed item 75), add:
Repeal the section, substitute:
(1) The Minister must cause an independent review to be conducted of the operation of this Act.
(2) The review must be conducted after the end of the 12-month period that began at the commencement of this section.
(3) The person or persons who conduct the review must:
(a) give the Minister a written report of the review; and
(b) do so within 12 months after the commencement of the review.
(4) The Minister must cause copies of the report to be tabled in each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the report is given to the Minister.
Ms LEY (Farrer—Minister for the Environment) (10:52): I move:
That the amendments be agreed to.
Question agreed to.

subdebateinfo.title: Road Vehicle Standards (Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Amendment Bill 2022

p.span: Road Vehicle Standards (Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Amendment Bill 2022
First Reading
Bill received from the Senate and read a first time.
Second Reading

Mr JOYCE (New England—Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development and Leader of the Nationals) (10:52): I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill and move:
That this bill be now read a second time.

The Road Vehicle Standards Act 2018 is about applying nationally consistent vehicle safety and environmental performance and security standards while also meeting consumer expectations that they may purchase a broad variety of road vehicles. The government set a 12-month transition period for adjustment to the new legislation, which commenced on 1 July 2021. But, over the past few years, almost all road vehicle manufacturers and importers have had to manage the severe impacts of the COVID pandemic on workplaces and the global supply chains. After listening to numerous industry participants, the Australian government has determined that a 12-month extension of the transitional period is necessary. A wide range of industry participants will benefit from the 12-month extension, and extending the transitional arrangements makes a level playing field for all participants.

The bill maintains the provisions of the new legislation. Road vehicle providers that have already transitioned to the new regulatory framework will be enabled to continue providing their vehicles, using approvals granted to them under the new legislation. I commend the bill to the House.
Leave granted for second reading debate to continue immediately.

Ms CATHERINE KING (Ballarat) (10:58): I rise to speak in the second reading debate on the Road Vehicle Standards (Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Amendment Bill. Frankly, this is where the government has come to us and asked for a further extension to the introduction of the Road Vehicle Standards Bill. That is a bill that the government introduced and that was passed in this House in 2018. It's a really significant measure around road safety in this country.

There are a couple of things I want to observe about this. This is a bit of an indictment on the government as to its incompetence. If you look at the history of this bill, back in 2018, Labor supported the Road Vehicle Standards Bill. So that was four years ago. That bill replaced the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989, which regulates the importation of road vehicles into Australia and the first provision of road vehicles into the market on Australian roads. That includes caravans and cranes. It includes importing a vehicle from America, a speciality vehicle, and changing it from left-hand to right-hand drive.

This has always been a really complex and controversial area—always. I thought it was pretty impressive that the then government decided that they were actually going to try and sort this issue out. There were always going to be groups within the road vehicle area that welcomed it and there were always going to be groups that did not want the reform. We supported the bill because its fundamental purpose back in 2018 was to create a much more modern regulatory framework to ensure that road vehicles and certain road vehicle components provided in Australia meet safety, antitheft and emissions standards—really important. So, good on the government, back in 2018, for actually doing that bill.

Because there were significant issues with industry that were recognised at the time, to deal with this the initial bill included a transition period which was almost a year. It was to go right through to 2019. The government, in July 2019, came to us again and said: 'We're not quite ready. We haven't got the datasets. We haven't got the computer systems. The industry's saying, "We're not quite ready."' So we supported an extension again. Being reasonable about it, we supported that extension of the transition period, and that was to conclude on 30 June this year.

Now, in March, this bill is asking us for a further extension. We're not going to stand in the way of the bill. We've indicated to the Deputy Prime Minister's office that we've supported the extension, and we did so in the Senate and supported the passage of the bill.

But I do want to say: look, this is an issue of competence. I understand that the pandemic has delayed a number of things. However, this bill was introduced four years ago. It's not a bill that was just introduced a year ago or two years ago; it was introduced four years ago. The government still haven't got the implementation right, they still haven't got the consultation right, and they've come begging for more time. Frankly, it's a bit of a wasted opportunity. Again, this is not a bill that Labor introduced in government and there have been some unintended consequences or whatever; this is a bill the government introduced. Last week the government approached us—only last week—to propose a further 12-month delay to allow time for industry to make further changes to implement this new system.

As I said, it's a bill that was initially passed some four years ago. It was meant to come into effect three years ago, and it's already been extended once. Our consultations with the industry over the past week have revealed that the truth of the delay is that a whole range of small and medium-sized enterprises are scathing of this government's handling of the transition period, including its communications with affected industry participants and the unwieldy nature of the IT solutions being used to implement the transition. It seems that the government hasn't used the extensions that were given, first in the initial bill transition period and then the second extension it asked for, to actually prepare for the new scheme and its full effect. Frankly, you have to question what they've been doing in this whole process to actually bring this forward.

To me, if this law is fundamentally about road safety, emission standards, ensuring antitheft devices and consistency, the government needs to really think about why it's being delayed. I know this is a really difficult area. It is an area where there will always be conflicting views about what to do. As I said, the government took the decision in 2018 to bite the bullet and try to fix this. They're now just pushing it off and pushing it off again when we're days away from the federal election being called. This mess is going to have to get fixed by whoever wins the next election. I'm saying very clearly that I think we will have to have a good look to see whether this law is actually contemporary and works in the way that it does. I want to make it very clear though that this is something for any incoming government. We should not be back here in this place in yet another year's time saying, 'It's all a bit too hard, the data systems aren't there, the IT systems aren't there and the communications haven't been done.' We can't keep doing this. If you want to enact this law and you think it's the right law to enact, and this is what the parliament agreed, then we actually need to get on with it, or you need to change the law or you need to do your job. As I said, this really does represent the government being pretty incompetent at doing its job.

As I said, Labor will support the bill. We've supported it in the Senate. But, again, this is going to be a problem for any incoming government, whether it's the existing government or an Albanese Labor government. If it's us, I'm pretty determined that we'll fix it.

Mr JOYCE (New England—Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development and Leader of the Nationals) (11:03): I'd like to thank honourable members for their consideration of the Road Vehicle Standards (Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2022. I concur with and I would like to thank the members of the opposition for expediting this process. There's a clear need to support businesses in the community to adjust to the severe impacts of the COVID pandemic, including workplace and supply chain challenges. This bill does this by providing a 12-month extension to the RVSA transition period.
I commend the bill to the House.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Third Reading

Mr JOYCE (New England—Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development and Leader of the Nationals) (11:04): I thank the shadow minister for her patience. We will make sure that we get the running sheet. Of course, we know how this place works: everybody will want to get home tonight if they can, so we'll expedite processes that we don't need to debate. I seek leave to move the third reading.
Leave granted.
Mr JOYCE: I move:
That this bill be now read a third time.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a third time.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report

Mr O'DOWD (Flynn—Deputy Nationals Whip) (11:05): I present the 36th report of the Petitions Committee for the 46th Parliament, together with 59 petitions and 95 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented.

As we approach the end of the 46th Parliament, I want to take the opportunity to draw attention to the work of the committee. As an extension of the House of Representatives, the Standing Committee on Petitions can only operate during the term of a parliament. Once a parliament dissolves, so too does the committee.

However, the Petitions Committee process does not completely stop between parliaments. For example, if a response to a petition referred to a minister has not been received before this parliament dissolves, that petition will still need a response in the 47th Parliament from the relevant minister. In practice, we encourage all ministers to respond to petitions within the expected 90 days and before the end of the parliament. This ensures petitioners receive timely information about the issues raised in their petition.

Petitioners can also request new e-petitions or paper petitions between the end of this parliament and the start of the new parliament. These requests are held by the secretariat for consideration by the new committee.

The Australian public clearly values the petitioning process. To date this parliament has received 1,664 e-petitions, and 76 paper petitions have been approved by the committee. There have been over 4.6 million signatures to e-petitions and 132,000 signatures made by hand on paper petitions.
We anticipate that the keen engagement with petitioning will resume in the new parliament, and the Standing Committee on Petitions will continue to update the House accordingly.
Chair Mr Ken O'Dowd MP
Deputy Chair Hon Justine Elliot MP
Mrs Bridget Archer MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Ms Gladys Liu MP
Mr Julian Simmonds MP
Mr James Stevens MP
Ms Susan Templeman MP

PETITIONS
Presentation

Mr O'DOWD
( Flynn — Deputy Nationals Whip ) ( 11:07 ):
I present the following petitions:
COVID-19: International Travel

The process of recent entry of non citizens to Australia who have not been fully vaccinated against COVID 19 is not acceptable to the majority of Australian Citizens due to the Health risk it poses to the nation.
We therefore ask the House to legislate to stop the entry of any noncitizen who has not been fully vaccinated and to not allow any exceptions.
from 19 citizens (Petition No. EN3822)
COVID-19: Migration

work,study,paying tax, supporting local business and Australia online retailers, etc. disruption by completing for migration program during pandemic couple limited unattainable pathways to permanent residency mean that the future for many temporary residents Australia in uncertain.
We therefore ask the House to permanent resident for temporary resident who live in Australia and supported it's economy during the covid 19 pandemic.

from two citizens (Petition No. EN3856)
COVID-19: Vaccination

Everyone should have their own freedom of choice regarding vaccines. Australia is being hit with covid as I write this. A booster is not recommended by the science for someone who has already had covid. Blanket mandating covid vaccinations for healthcare workers are not only a violation of our human rights to choice but contraindicated for someone who's already had covid, forcing a young healthy nurse who has already had covid to get the booster or they will lose their job is a disgrace to our rights and not even aligned with the science of immunology and the vaccines. Healthcare workers have enough knowledge of immunology to make a decision that's tailored to their healthcare needs, it is not the roll of the government to make that decision.
We therefore ask the House to stop all mandating of the vaccines. Allow freedom of choice. Without black mailing us that we will lose our jobs if we don't comply!
from 385 citizens (Petition No. EN3857)
Migration

Government have promised social security to attract immigrants to move to regional Australia and contribute the development when they first introduced 491 and 494 visa in 2019. As a result, many immigrants have moved to Regional Australia and actively contributing to the development of that area even though struggle with job finding, proper infrastructure for their kids etc.
We therefore ask the House to act on providing the social security to the visa holders of 491 and 494 on best possible way.
from 546 citizens (Petition No. EN3858)
COVID-19: International Travel

Novak Djokovic has shown total contempt for both the safety of those around him and of the Australian judicial system. He simply cannot be trusted to follow any guidance regarding the ongoing management of the global pandemic, by his own admission he exposed others to Covid 19 while he was infected.
We therefore ask the House to cancel Novak Djokovic visa and deport him immediately
from two citizens (Petition No. EN3861)
Invictus Games

To award all participants, carers, and support staff of the 2014, 2016, and 2017 Australian Invictus Games Teams the Australian Sports Medal. Recently the 2018 Australian Invictus Games team was formally awarded the Australian Sports Medal. The 2018 team all deserve this award; however, the question has been raised as to why this award was not also awarded to the previous three competing Australian Invictus teams and their support staff. The 2018 Invictus Games held in Sydney, would not have been as successful without the efforts of the previous Australian team's participation and outstanding representation of Australian sporting excellence exhibited whilst they competed in Invictus Games overseas. We believe that the success of the Invictus Games is due to each member of the 2018 team but also those individuals who represented Australia with pride and excellence in the Invictus Games held in 2014, 2016, and 2017. Shouldn't they all be recognised in the same way? This event has caused significant pain and division within the defence community. We wish for all Australian Invictus Teams to be treated with equality and respect. We believe that as a country we should always recognise our veterans, including the servicemen and servicewomen who participated in the Invictus Games and have done Australia proud.

We therefore ask the House to Representatives to acknowledge that the Australian Sports Medal should be awarded to eligible Australian team members and officials including from the 2014, 2016, and 2017 Invictus Games
from 108 citizens (Petition No. EN3865)
Migration

You probably knew the 143 is temporary onshore granting for 143 visa, however it has few conditions under it. Only applicants who were in Australia on 24 March 2021 and lodged their application prior to that date can be granted while on shore.

Lots of parents are requested to pay the 2nd VAC and leave Australia for the 143 visa to be granted. Because they were not in Australia on 24 March 2021 or they did parents 103 application and changed to 143 after the date. Parents have been added into direct family list for travel exemption to entry Australia in Nov 2021. Lots of parents came to Australia after the date, now the parents have to leave Australia again to get their Visa granted.

But due to global COVID-19 travel restrictions, there is very limited flight between Australia and China. Additionally, parents have to have lots of documents to entry other countries and one way flight can cost more than 4000 dollars.

Furthermore, they have to fly back to Australia to activate their visa which wastes the precious place in airline and hotel quarantine. Frankly, in the middle of a pandemic, the Government should not be forcing people to take risky and expensive trips overseas. It simply does not make any sense.
We therefore ask the House to remove the two conditions for onshore granting for Visa 143, as below:
Only applicants who were in Australia on 24 March 2021
and lodged their application prior to that date.
from one citizen (Petition No. EN3868)
COVID-19: International Travel

Family members of temporary visa holders are still barred from entering Australia due to the existing travel prohibition. Temporary residents are people, too. Their families have been split up, resulting in mental and emotional distress. There are many families who were separated under COVID who will never be reunited since they are not included in the exemption category.
Here are a few examples of the stories:
He hasn't met their newborn because she gave birth alone: Temporary visa holders who have been separated from their families face a harsh reality.
Mother and child are no longer together.
A pandemic separated a couple for two years.
During pregnancy, the future mother requires the assistance of her mother.

Temporary residents contributes to the economy by paying taxes, and they have the right to be with their families. Family reunification is vital and urgent for all Australian residents, whether TR, PR, or citizens.

We therefore ask the House to consider travel exemption on basis of humanitarian grounds. The members of the family should be sponsored and supported so that they do not become a burden on the government or the community. To preserve the health of the Australian community, a mandatory 14-day paid quarantine at specified institutions should be implemented.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN3869)
COVID-19: Vaccination

With big pharma and the FDA in the US suppressing safety data for 75 years, a lot of people are sceptical about the use of mRNA vaccines. However CORBEVAX initial development started 20 years ago and is a non mRNA vaccine. It was developed for the SARS 2003 outbreak, it involves using proteins from a virus or bacterium that can induce an immune response but not cause disease.
"It's the same technology as the hepatitis B vaccine that's been around for decades,"
Unlike the mRNA vaccines from Pfizer and Moderna, and the viral vector vaccine from Johnson & Johnson, protein subunit vaccines like CORBEVAX have a track record.
"And it's cheap, a dollar, dollar fifty a dose,".
Also unlike Pfizer and Moderna, CORBEVAX, the intellectual property of this vaccine will be available to everybody
We therefore ask the House to introduce this vaccine as another safe alternative to the mRNA shots.
If this is truly about people's health, then the options should not be limited to just the ones with stocks attached to them.
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN3871)
Migration
The on-hand cases for 491/190 visa applications are more than 30,000. Some of them are pending for more than 36 months, and new applications are being piled up.

Most of the visa applicants who were affected by s48 bar are offshore, and cannot come to Australia without an exemption. Travel exemption for bringing visa holders are mostly refused. Sadly, most of visa applicants' bridging visas have either expired already or is expiring soon. People's career, financial commitments and future plans have been significantly affected due to this status quo.
The Government can end this crisis by speeding up the decisions on the backlogs.
We therefore ask the House to
- Direct the government to decide all the on-hand cases for 491/190 visas to decide before new financial year begins or,
- Direct the government to extend the dates of expired bridging visa b holders who went offshore being affected by the section 48 or,
- Allow to apply bridging visa b to apply for another bridging visa b while being offshore and unable to travel to Australia due to current travel restrictions

I registered these application can still change my situation by apply for permanent residency in COVID pandemic their support of the economy has taken many reasonable :

Work, Study, Paying Taxes ,supporting local businesses and Australia online retailers, etc disruption by completing for Migration program during pandemic couple limited unattainable pathways to permanent residency mean that the future for many temporary residency in Australia is uncertain.

from six citizens (Petition No. EN3881)
COVID-19: Migration

887 applicants are skilled workers and have helped contributing to and supporting regional Australia's communities and economies for at least 2 years. We have close ties with the local communities and enjoy living in regional Australia. However, many of us can still hardly call Australia our home as temporary visa holders. Without a permanent residency, it can be difficult to settle permanently and progress with life, such as buying a home, securing a job, starting a family or enrolling children into universities. As shown on the Department of Home Affairs website, 887 visa processing has stopped at applications lodged before September 2020 without any progress for more than 12 months. Many onshore applicants have been waiting for more than 14 months without being contacted. This has caused a lot of mental distress and frustration to us, and is especially disheartening for onshore applicants who have waited for longer than 12 months, and have been staying in and supporting Australia since the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020.

We therefore ask the House to request the Department of Home Affairs to process 887 visa in chronological order, regardless of onshore or offshore applications, and to allocate more recourses to reduce the processing time from the current17-22 months to a more reasonable and humane range of 6-8 months. We appreciate the House's efforts and look forward for the Department to resolving the issue as soon as practicable.
from 251 citizens (Petition No. EN3882)
National Diabetes Services Scheme

In 2018 funding was allocated to expand free access to glucose-monitoring technology through the National Diabetes Support Scheme (NDSS) to help children, pregnant women, and adults with type 1 diabetes manage their condition. This funding brought about immediate changes to include children with cystic fibrosis (up to 21 years old) who require insulin to have access to this scheme.
Cystic fibrosis related diabetes (CFRD) is classified as "other" not type 1 or type 2 diabetes. Therefore, once a person with cystic fibrosis turns 21 they are no longer eligible for inclusion.

People living with CFRD are not cured upon turning 21 yet their access to live-saving NDSS support ends. CFRD affects 30% of adults with cystic fibrosis. Approximately 500 Australians with CFRD are not eligible for free glucose monitoring, making it difficult for them to effectively track and improve diabetic control and mitigate long term diabetic complications.

The Australian Cystic Fibrosis Data Registry reports that 85% of people with cystic fibrosis are pancreatic insufficient and almost half suffer from CFRD as a cystic fibrosis co-morbidity. Given that only 3500 Australians have cystic fibrosis and many of the modulator drugs your government has listed on the PBS on our behalf address many of the side-effects of CFRD, the financial implication of extending the NDSS to include people with CFRD would not be significant, yet the lives saved would be.
We therefore ask the House to expand free access to glucose-monitoring technology through the NDSS to include all adults living with CFRD.
from 1,492 citizens (Petition No. EN3885)
COVID-19: Vaccination

The recent US Supreme Court decision to block vaccine mandates noted that Biden's vaccine mandate was no 'everyday exercise of federal power' but rather 'a significant encroachment on the lives—and health—of a vast number of employees.'

Vaccine mandates in Australia have proven futile to stop the spread of coronavirus in this country as the vaccines themselves do not prevent an individual from catching COVID-19. Furthermore, the denial of work to unvaccinated Australians is contrary to the right to work as per the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights as well as the Human Rights Act 2004 (Cth).

We note as well that the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine safety data sheet notes no full list of ingredients, no Toxicity report, no effect on endocrine glands and is merely provided in good faith, not science, without warranty of any kind. We note the long-term effects of this product are unknown and sincerely believe that this product should be taken by an individual without threat, deception or coercion (i.e. the right to bodily autonomy).

We therefore ask the House to immediately cease all vaccine mandates in Australia as they are contrary to both Commonwealth legislation as well as international legislation; despite the Public Health Amendment Bill 2021 (ACT) (and other bills) to undermine these laws.

We request the immediate return of all unvaccinated Australians to work to allow them to support both themselves and their families as well as to support the restoration of the Australian economy post COVID-19 lockdown.
from 141,382 citizens (Petition No. EN3886)
Migration

Currently certain permanent residency visas are taking extremely long time to process, such as Skilled Regional 887 visa with the current processing time of 17-22 months. This has caused a lot of distress, uncertainties and difficulties in proceeding with life such as buying a home, starting a family or securing a career.

The Department of Home Affairs has a premium service, namely Priority Consideration, which offers priority processing with an additional fee of Australian dollar (AUD) 1000 for Business Visitor and Tourist streams visas. Under this service the Department will aim to finalise the application within 48 hours. It would be a win-win situation if the Department can offer similar service to permanent residency applicants, as it can lessen frustration faced by the applicants due to the long wait, as well as generating more revenue to the Department. The excess income can be used to allocate more resources for quicker visa processing and the excess being invested as the Department sees fit.

We therefore ask the House to suggest the Department of Home Affairs to offer Priority Consideration premium service to permanent residency visa applicants, such as 887 visa, to fast tract their visa processing for an additional fee.
from 104 citizens (Petition No. EN3890)
Gender and Sexual Orientation

Too many parents and children are misinformed about the LGBTQIA+ community leading to stereotypes, misinformation and general fear/disgust around the Community. Teaching kids and teens about gender and sexual orientation in sex ed at primary and high school levels will give kids the chance to express who they are and by the time they reach high school be prepared to take on school without the worry of gender identity. Children as young as 2 can start to question their gender identity this is a scientifically proven fact. Implementing education around the LGBTQIA+ community and gender identity will ultimately lead to a safer more inclusive primary and high school education experience and lead to less child/teen suicides and help mental health for teens from suppression of who they are.

We therefore ask the House to implement LGBTQIA+ education into the sex ed curriculum. Things such as sexual orientation, gender identity and expression. Which will ultimately lead to a healthier and more inclusive school environment.
from 44 citizens (Petition No. EN3892)
Commonwealth Integrity Commission

Transparency International publishes a Corruption Perceptions Index each year, measuring public trust in governments by their respective citizens. On this index, Australia has dropped from No.8 in 2010 down to No.11 in 2020. Compared to other nations, Australia has slipped backwards in the last decade. I am sorry to report New Zealand has been beating Australia for the last decade on this Corruption Perceptions Index. This must stop. We need a proven proof of concept governance-instrument to improve public perception of the Commonwealth Government of Australia. Australia needs an Independent Commission Against Corruption, similar to ICAC in NSW, if not better. The Hon Christian Porter MP has previously responded to similar Petitions EN1088, EN1303, EN1649 and EN2019, and the draft Commonwealth Integrity Commission Bill 2020 has unfortunately stalled, and it is now listed as "Not Proceeding". Please restart the foundations for a Federal ICAC as soon as practicable.
We therefore ask the House to set in motion the foundations for a Federal ICAC now, please.
from 50 citizens (Petition No. EN3893)
Japan
Since the end of WW2 Japan has been systematically abducting children from nations Worldwide and in the last decade there has been more than 70 cases of child abductions of Australian children.
Despite Japan being a member of the CRC and various other conventions, it has been breaking international law and violating the human rights of Australian children and their parents.
Japan actively protects the abductor and denies the children the right to meet their parents.
Recently Scott Morrison has entered Australia into an alliance with Japan.
To quote Scott "Japan is our closest partner in Asia with an equal partnership of shared trust between two great democracies committed to the rule of law and human rights."
It is outrageous that any country would enter into such an agreement when that country is committing human rights crimes against their own citizens.
Is this really the integrity of Australia?
There can be no alliance with a country that does not respect the rights of our citizens and uphold the principle of the promises it has made with the international community.

We therefore ask the House to terminate our alliance and suspend all defence agreements until Japan implements joint custody and honours its agreements to uphold the principle of the agreements it has agreed to uphold and these children can meet their Australian parents.
We also ask that Japan is taken to international court to seek compensation to all Australian children and parents that Japan has broken international law and committed human rights crimes against.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN3897)
COVID-19: Migration

Work, Study, Paying Taxes ,Supporting local businesses and Australia online retailers, etc disruption by completing for migration program during pandemic couple limited unattainable pathways to permanent Residency mean that the future for many temporary Residents in Australia is uncertain.
We therefore ask the House to establish a pathway to permanent Residency for Temporary Residency who live in Australia and supported it's economy during the covid 19 pandemic .
from 60 citizens (Petition No. EN3901)
Australia Day
The year is 2022. It's ridiculous that we still celebrate the founding of Australia on the day that marked the exposition of generations of suffering.
We therefore ask the House to change the date for Australia Day from 26th of Jan to an alternative, more suitable date
from 15 citizens (Petition No. EN3902)
Housing Affordability
Housing rental prices far out of reach for low to middle income Australian citizens causing significant increases of homelessness.

We therefore ask the House to place safeguard measures ensuring more affordable housing rental prices are available to those significantly impacted in conjunction of low income and unemployment benefits and those employed on minimum wage rates. More agencies need to be available to the public who are in the low income bracket to act as advocates for Australian citizens who are impacted by homelessness due to affordability issues due to low income.

I ask for a review of our national housing issues for low income Australian citizens and the significant rise in homelessness. Reducing the pressure of homelessness to ensure a more successful development of our economy via reducing homelessness and in turn increasing our chances of obtaining employment though stable and affordable accommodation to boost national gdp and strengthen our national financial security issues that are being impacted by homelessness rising and unaffordable housing prices causing unnecessary strain on the economy and Australian citizens over all.
from 30 citizens (Petition No. EN3904)
Private Health Insurance

The new emigrants are not educated about the cost and importance of having a private insurance policy which can be a hindrance in purchasing a better private health insurance cover. The come to know about Lifetime Health Cover (LHC) when they start comparing insurance covers to avoid medical surcharge levy. LHC's is a substantial cost and an hindrance to availing better private health insurance cover. The government should make the public's life easy with giving the emigrants one chance to correct their mistake.
We therefore ask the House to LHC should be waived and one chance should be given to emigrants to Australia who were not educated about LHC in the first year by Australian Government.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN3906)
Australia Day

To have a mutual date that we can all celebrate the amazing country we live in "AUSTRALIA" without offending anyone a day we can all feel happy about and may 8 is a pun on the Australian spirit and terminology "mate" mateship we can use a phrase we use "mate" and incorporate it in our new date set a new way forward for togetherness . #may8.
We therefore ask the House to change the official Australia Day date from January the 26th to May 8 .
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN3908)
Australia Day

I'm sure you're well aware of the discourse surrounding January 26th being celebrated as Australia Day, marking the landing of the First Fleet in Sydney cove and what proceeded to be the colonisation of Australia. Aboriginal Australians have marked it as Invasion Day, due to the following Frontier Wars that resulted in the death of at least 40,000 Indigenous Australians, and the displacement of countless others over the next nearly 150 years. Marking this date as a day of celebration shows egregious contempt for the Aboriginal people of Australia.

Additionally, for many Australians, even those with British ancestry, the mark of the celebration doesn't lend itself as a worthy 'Australian' day. The events of the date signify an expansion of the British Empire into another landmass—a landmass that would not come to be recognised as the Australia we know today for over 100 years. Another country's achievement, albeit one that we have a long history and influence with, should not be a date with which we celebrate our own identity.

We therefore ask the House to change the date of 'Australia Day' as a public holiday to the 19th of January (19/01) to pay homage to the Federation of Australia, which commenced in the beginning of the year 1901. Furthermore, we ask the House to recognise the 26th of January as 'Survival Day', and for it to be treated as a day of recognition and respect for the Aboriginal Australians.

from 301 citizens (Petition No. EN3946)
Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme

Cystic Fibrosis (CF), the most common life limiting genetic disability, is caused by mutations of the CFTR gene. Some 2500 known mutations are known to this large gene, 90% having one called F508del. Mutations cause defects in a protein that controls the anions Chloride (and less so Bicarbonate) being pumped out of cells. In the lungs, gut and other mucous secreting cells this leads to thick mucus and the symptoms of CF.

Recent developments and research has developed a group of drugs known as modulators that improve the excretion of chloride leading to more normal mucous and improved lung function, greatly improving the well-being and lives of the pwCF.

Unfortunately these modulators of which Trikafta, the most recent, has just been recommended by the PBAC, have only been registered for use in only persons with one or just a very few mutations. Trikafta only for persons with the F508del mutation. This is because large double blinded trials only included that mutation. Vertex's own laboratory research has shown there are 120 mutations that should respond and the US Prescribing Information includes these in their list of mutations for which the drugs can be used. With these rare mutations, such as the one person with the mutations R75Q and G542X, large double blinded trials are impossible.
We therefore ask the House to make these modulators available for all persons with CF whom reasonable evidence, as judged by expert CF Physicians, exists that they should respond.

from 3,272 citizens (Petition No. EN3949)
PETITIONS
Responses

Mr O'DOWD
( Flynn — Deputy Nationals Whip ) ( 11:07 ):
I present the following ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Herpes Simplex Virus
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence concerning Petition number EN2216 to include herpes simplex virus (HSV) in all standard sexually transmissible infections (STI) tests, regardless of symptom presentation. I regret the delay in responding.

The response from Australian governments (Commonwealth and state and territory governments) to blood borne viruses (BBV) and STI is guided by five National Strategies, including the Fourth National Sexually Transmissible Infections Strategy 2018-2022 (Strategy). The Strategy recognises that young people continue to be significantly impacted by STI, and effectively engaging them in prevention, testing and treatment is essential to preventing the spread of STI in Australia.

Currently, both the Australian STI Management Guidelines (developed by the Australasian Society for HIV, Viral Hepatitis and Sexual Health Medicine) and the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners Guidelines for preventive activities in general practice, recommend that testing for HSV should only be conducted if it is clinically indicated. These expert guidelines recommend that testing should be limited to specific situations where results will provide meaningful clinical information that inform better patient outcomes.

The Australian Government, through the National Health and Medical Research Council, has provided $6.3 million for research into the causes and potential treatments for HSV. There are a small number of clinical trials being undertaken for HSV treatments in Australia and information is available at: www.australiailclinicaltrials.gov.au by searching for herpes simplex. A larger number of clinical trials are occurring or have been completed internationally for a HSV vaccine and other potential treatments. Information on a vaccine and treatments can be found at: www.clinicaltrials.gov by searching for herpes simplex.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Crohn's Disease
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence concerning EN2238—changes to the approval process for authority required applications to prescribe medicines for treatment of Crohn's disease. I regret the delay in responding.

There are a number of medicines available on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) that may be used to treat Crohn's disease (to initially control and then maintain the disease). These include corticosteroids, immunosuppressants and biological medicines (adalimumab, infliximab, ustekinumab and vedolizumab).

The PBS listings for these medicines reflect the evidence that has been considered by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) to date. The PBAC is an independent expert body which advises the Australian Government about the listing of medicines on the PBS. The Government cannot list a medicine or change the circumstances of a listing on the PBS unless the PBAC makes a positive recommendation to do so.

At the time of making a recommendation for PBS listing, the PBAC also advises the authority level that should apply for PBS subsidised access. The level of authority recommended by the PBAC depends largely on the potential risk of the medicine being prescribed outside of the PBS restrictions (i.e. outside of the legal arrangements) and provide a mechanism through which the prescriber must demonstrate that their patient meets the eligibility criteria. This can vary depending on the condition or indication and also the complexity of the PBS restriction. These arrangements are important to ensure the ongoing sustainability of the PBS.

Authority Required PBS listings require the prescriber to seek prior approval from Services Australia, before prescribing a medicine. The application may need to be in writing or via telephone (or online), depending on the requirements of the listing. Services Australia is the agency that is responsible for the day-to-day administration of the PBS, on behalf of my Department.
The PBS listings for immunosuppressant medicines and corticosteroids, which may be used to treat Crohn's disease, do not require prescribers to seek prior approval from Services Australia.

However, the PBS listings for the above biological medicines require the treating doctor to apply in writing to Services Australia for both initial treatment and continuing supply (except for biosimilar brands) of these medicines. A written authority is generally applied where it is considered necessary for the doctor to provide information, often including medical test results, to confirm a patient's eligibility to receive PBS subsidised access to a medicine.

The PBS listings for these medicines outline the minimum duration of therapy that is required before assessing the patients' response to treatment and recommend that a patient be reviewed in the four weeks prior to completing their current course of treatment to ensure uninterrupted supply of treatment.

Authority Required (written) applications may currently be submitted to Services Australia via Australia Post or by the existing upload functionality in the Health Professional Online Services system (HPOS). Prescribers may wish to consider using the HPOS upload functionality as this reduces the time between the submission of an application to Services Australia and the receipt of the assessment decision.

Biosimilar products are available for Adalimumab and infliximab (intravenous). Subsequent continuing listings for the biosimilar brands are Authority Required (Streamlined). In line with the Government's policy to promote prescribing of biosimilar medicines in treatment naive patients, the treating doctor is not required to seek prior approval from Services Australia to prescribe a biosimilar brand, for patients who continue to meet the PBS eligibility requirements.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Welfare
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 24 May 2021 to the Minister for Government Services and Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme, Senator the Hon Linda Reynolds CSC, concerning PETITION (EN2548)—Cashless Debit Card (CDC). As the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibility, your letter has been forwarded to me for reply.

The CDC is a useful tool that operates alongside other reforms to address the devastating impacts of drug and alcohol misuse and problem gambling. It has been designed to be as non-interventionist as possible to allow participants to have flexibility and control over their lives and finances while still achieving its core objectives of reducing social problems.

The Government commissioned the University of Adelaide to undertake a second independent impact evaluation of the CDC in the first three sites of Ceduna, East Kimberley, and the Goldfields. Both stakeholders and participants reported the CDC was prioritising, and therefore encouraging, greater spending on essential items such as food, bills, clothes, household goods and fuel. These findings are consistent with findings from the first independent impact evaluation, which also found reductions in alcohol consumption and gambling.
If participating in the program would seriously risk their mental, physical or emotional wellbeing, CDC participants are able to apply for a wellbeing exemption.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston
Regional Skilled Worker Visas
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN2708, originally directed to the Minister for Immigration, Citzenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, on regional visa holders acquiring residential property in regional areas. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response. I apologise for the delay in responding to you.

Foreign investment provides significant benefits to Australia. It contributes to the prosperity of businesses, communities and the overall economy. At the same time, the Australian Government recognises that foreign investments must be in the national interest. Australia's foreign investment framework strikes a balance between ensuring we remain an attractive investment destination and upholding the national interest. If it is determined that a proposed investment is contrary to the national interest, it will not be approved or conditions will be applied to safeguard the national interest.

Under Australia's foreign investment review framework, foreign persons generally need to apply for foreign investment approval before acquiring any residential real estate in Australia. The Government's policy is to channel foreign investment into new dwellings, as opposed to established dwellings, as this creates additional jobs in the construction industry, bolsters Australian housing stock, and supports economic growth. Foreign investment applications are therefore generally considered in light of the overarching principle that proposed investment should increase Australia's housing stock.

For this reason, non-resident foreign persons are generally prohibited from purchasing established dwellings in Australia. This policy applies nationally. However, reflecting the fact that foreign persons who are temporary residents need a place to live during their time in Australia, temporary residents can apply to purchase one established dwelling to use as a residence while they live in Australia. Temporary residents cannot acquire established dwellings to rent out or for use as a holiday home.

Approval for an acquisition of a new (or near-new) dwelling is not usually subject to any conditions concerning its usage, and approval for an acquisition of vacant land for residential development will generally be conditional on the construction being completed within four years (to prevent land banking).

Stamp duties and land taxes, including any additional surcharges that may be levied on foreign owners, are the responsibility of state governments. You may wish to raise your concern regarding stamp duties and land taxes with the relevant state or territory Treasurer.
Further information on the foreign investment review framework can be found on the Foreign Investment Review Board website at: www.firb.gov.au
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Feral Animals
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 23 August 2021 in relation to a petition calling for an end to the use of sodium fluoroacetate (commonly known as 1080) in Australia. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA) is the independent statutory regulator of agricultural and veterinary (agvet) chemicals in Australia. The APVMA makes science-based regulatory decisions within a framework of accepted international risk assessment and management practices, in accordance with the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Code Act 1994.

The APVMA must be satisfied that a chemical product meets the statutory criteria for safety, efficacy and trade before the product can be registered. These criteria ensure that agvet chemicals do not pose undue risk to the health and safety of humans, animals, the environment and trade. ·

APVMA-registered products, including 1080, are safe to use when used in accordance with APVMA approved label directions or permit conditions. Vertebrate poisons such as 1080 are an essential tool for land managers to effectively control invasive feral pests and often form a strategic part of habitat maintenance for the reintroduction of vulnerable Australian species, as well as protection of livestock production from predator attacks.

As a Restricted Chemical Product (RCP) under the Agricultural and Veterinary Code Regulations 1995, 1080 is strictly controlled and can only be supplied to persons authorised under the laws of the relevant state or territory. Supply is limited to authorised persons who have specific training or qualifications, which ensure the safe handling and use of RCPs such as 1080.

The APVMA completed a review of 1080 in 2008. This review considered the potential environmental contamination, poisoning of non-target animals and optimising efficacy. Outcomes of the review included amendments to product labels to enhance protection of the environment and non-target animals. The final review report can be found on the APVMA website at apvma.gov.au/node/15061.

The Australian regulatory system recognises that credible new scientific information may be generated that suggests the existence of previously unknown risks to human health, animal or crop safety, the environment or trade, or that suggests product ineffectiveness. Anyone can nominate a registered product, approved active constituent or label for reconsideration. A nomination must provide reasons to support the proposal for reconsideration, including reference to new information and/or evidence of risk when a product is used in accordance with the label instructions.
Further information regarding the APVMA's Chemical Review program, including information on nominating a chemical for reconsideration, can be found on the APVMA website at apvma.gov.au/node/10966.
Thank you again for bringing these concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Agriculture and Northern Australia, Mr Littleproud (Petition No. EN2801)
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 23 August 2021 concerning petition number EN2883 requesting the opening of international borders. This matter has been referred to me as the Minister for Health and Aged Care. I regret the delay in replying.

Australia has reopened its border to vaccinated travellers as part of the Australian Government's step by step and safe reopening to the world, in line with the National Plan to Transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response (National Transition Plan). This is a result of the success Australia has achieved through the vaccine rollout.

As of 4 January 2022, more than 91 per cent of people in Australia aged 16 and over are fully vaccinated with a COVID-19 vaccine. All Australian jurisdictions now have 84 per cent (or more) double dose vaccination rate for those aged 16 and over.

As we continue to implement the National Transition Plan, and subject to the latest medical advice, there will be a gradual reopening of outward international travel. To support the next steps of reopening, proportionate testing, tracing, quarantine, and isolation measures will be implemented within the Australian jurisdictions.

Fully vaccinated Australian citizens and permanent residents can leave Australia without needing to apply for a travel exemption. Children under 12 and those who cannot be vaccinated for medical reasons will also be able to travel overseas without an exemption.

Unvaccinated Australian citizens and permanent residents (apart from children under 12 and those who cannot be vaccinated for medical reasons) wishing to travel overseas are required to apply for an exemption to leave Australia.

Australia continues to monitor the latest international and domestic evidence and developments regarding the Omicron COVID-19 variant. Additional border measures that are in place or have been in place to protect Australians from Omicron are necessary, appropriate, and proportionate to the risk presented by Omicron, and are considered consistent with actions being considered by other countries.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
South Africa
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence regarding petition EN2935 on the unrest in South Africa.

The Australian Government shares concerns expressed by the petitioners about the civil unrest which occurred in South Africa, centred on the Gauteng and KwaZulu-Natal provinces, in mid-July 2021. We offer our condolences for the lives lost, and our regret for the injuries to people and the impact on livelihoods.
I have spoken with South African Minister for International Relations and Cooperation, Dr Naledi Pander, to convey these concerns and our hope for stability to be restored.

The Australian Government welcomes the South African Government's commitment to resolving the situation peacefully, ensuring justice by holding perpetrators to account, and providing support to those who have been affected.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Telecommunications
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 18 October 2021 to the Hon Paul Fletcher MP, Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, regarding Petition EN2998 requesting the provision of fair and reliable mobile coverage, by any mobile service provider, to the Moore Creek, Upper Moore Creek, Daruka and Moonbi Gap Road areas of New South Wales. Your email was referred to me, as this matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

Following receipt of your email, I sought an update from the mobile network operators (MNOs)—Optus, Telstra and TPG Telecom (formerly Vodafone Hutchinson Australia) on their mobile networks at the locations referred to in the petition, and any plans they had for future network investment in these areas.

Telstra acknowledge that the difficult terrain of Moore Creek and surrounds, as well as distance from the closest mobile base stations, would affect the mobile coverage experienced by Moore Creek residents. Telstra advised that it has no immediate commercial plans for new infrastructure in the Moore Creek area, however, the location will be reviewed and considered as a possible candidate under future rounds of the Australian Government's Mobile Black Spot Program (MBSP).

TPG advised that all of its mobile base stations in the Moore Creek area are operational. However, due to the challenges presented by the mountains and hills surrounding Moore Creek and the large geographic area, the towers are providing Outdoor only coverage. At this stage, TPG have no current commercial plans to upgrade mobile coverage in the Moore Creek area, but stated they will take into consideration the issues raised by the petition for future network planning in the region.

Optus advised that its mobile base stations in the Moore Creek area are also functioning as expected with no recent faults affecting services, and that they have no current commercial plans for mobile coverage upgrades in the area at this point in time.

There are a number of factors, such as buildings (including their internal structure) or other physical obstacles such as local terrain and trees that can interfere with mobile reception and therefore impact a user's ability to obtain or maintain a mobile signal at any given time or place. Products are available to improve mobile reception including the use of an external antenna or authorised repeater.

Wi-Fi calling is also available on the mobile carriers' networks for use with a compatible device allowing some customers to call and text over a Wi-Fi connection. This can be particularly helpful for those experiencing poor or no mobile coverage inside their home by providing an alternative form of connectivity. Residents are encouraged to talk to their mobile service provider to make their coverage issues known and to identify ways to maximise their reception.

span.span: Mobile Black Spot and Regional Connectivity Programs

p.span: The Liberal and Nationals Government is committed to improving communications services, including mobile coverage, in regional and remote Australia. This is why the Government has committed $380 million to the MBSP to invest in telecommunications infrastructure projects which address mobile black spots across Australia. More than 1,270 mobile base stations have been funded under the MBSP to date, including four new base stations adjacent to the Moore Creek area at Hallsville, Oxley Vale, Attunga and Moonbi which are now on air and providing improved mobile coverage to these communities.

The Government is also improving digital connectivity in regional Australia through the Regional Connectivity Program (RCP), which will complement the National Broadband Network (NBN) and the MBSP by providing regional communities with significant upgrades to voice and data services.

Applications are now being accepted for the second round of the RCP. Interested parties have until 5pm AEDT, 10 February 2022 to submit applications to the competitive grant process. More information is available on the Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Communication's website at
www.infrastructure.qov.au/media-technology-communications/internet/regional-connectivity-program.

Community members are also encouraged to contact their local council, as well as the MNOs, to make their coverage issues known. Past experience has shown that when local communities and councils engage with the MNOs it increases the likelihood that an application will be put forward under these programs. The MNOs' contact details are enclosed for reference.

Ultimately, any investment in new mobile network infrastructure remains a commercial decision for the MNOs. However, the Government is ready to help subsidise investment in areas where the commercial incentives are insufficient to drive the carriers to deliver new and improved services.

The Department maintains a central register of locations which have been the subject of a complaint concerning poor or non-existent mobile coverage. Following receipt of this petition, Moore Creek, Upper Moore Creek, Daruka and Moonbi Gap Road have been added to the register. This register is used by the Government to inform future policy decisions and is also made available to all bidders for their consideration when applying for funding under the MBSP.

I understand that you have referred a separate Petition EN2989 to Minister Fletcher, regarding ADSL and NBN services available to these communities and requesting the provision of reliable and consistent internet service, and that Minister Fletcher has separately responded on those matters.
Thank you for bringing the petitioner's concerns to my attention and I trust this is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Regionalisation, Regional Communications and Regional Education, Senator McKenzie
