p.span: COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning petition number EN3112 against allowing anyone other than medical professionals to ask for private medical information. I regret the delay in responding.

The Australian Government is providing access to COVID-19 vaccines for everyone living in Australia aged five and over. The COVID-19 vaccines used in Australia have been shown to have a 71 per cent effectiveness against transmission according to a Eurosurveillance study which can be viewed at: www.eurosurveillance.org using the search term 'Vaccine effectiveness against SARS-CoV-2 transmission and infections'.

Business and other organisations need to make sure their clients and staff are safe. Among other safeguards, this can include ensuring people are vaccinated against COVID-19. The requirement to prove vaccination is set by state and territory jurisdictions through their public health orders.

The digital certificate, integrated with state and territory applications, shows the minimal information required by venues and employers that someone is fully vaccinated, and can therefore participate in society according to public health orders. Guidance is published by the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner to encourage good privacy practice by business when dealing with personal information relating to COVID-19 vaccination.
The guidance can be viewed at: www.oaic.gov.au using the search term 'Privacy guidance for businesses collecting COVID-19 vaccination information'.

As Australia continues to open up to the rest of the world, it is essential that we restrict the movement of COVID-19 and new emerging strains entering our community. A requirement to prove vaccination status for those entering the nation, ensures we can minimise the impact of COVID-19 whilst enabling families to be reunited and tourists to return stimulating the economy. Recognition of other nations' vaccination status enables this.
The Government will continue to ensure personal privacy of health data is respected, whilst enabling public health measures keep our community safe.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence to Senator the Hon Marise Payne, concerning petition number EN3266 requesting changes to the public health measures used to minimise the effects of COVID 19. This matter has been referred to me as the Minister for Health and Aged Care. I regret the delay in responding.

The National Plan to Transition Australia's National COVID-19 Response aims to balance the need to minimise the risk of disease transmission, with the need to get back to normal, living with the pandemic.

Australia is reopening its borders to vaccinated travellers as part of its step-by-step, and safe, reopening to the world. Reopening the borders in this graduated way recognises the benefits of resuming international travel and is designed to test Australia's border systems and processes before a broader reopening to international travellers.

There is substantial global evidence based on thorough research that demonstrates the effectiveness of face masks in reducing the risk of transmission. This includes evidence that high community use of face masks reduces cases, hospitalisations and deaths associated with COVID-19. In Australia, face masks have played an important role in our outbreak responses. Many countries recommend the use of face masks within the community to help suppress COVID-19. Masks are not a panacea and they are just one layer of control alongside other public health measures.

The polymerase chain reaction and laboratory-based serological tests used in Australia are specific to SARS-CoV-2, and are of high quality. To ensure this, the Australian Government supports the Royal College of Pathologists of Australasia (RCPA) Quality Assurance Programs to deliver a dedicated program to assess and confirm that the COVID-19 tests provide high-quality results. Pathology testing in Australia is subject to quality and competency standards and requirements set by the National Pathology Accreditation Advisory Council. Practices in pathology laboratories are guided by the National Association of Testing Authorities Australia, and the RCPA.

Vaccination continues to be the best method of prevention against COVID-19. Decisions on COVID-19 vaccines have been guided by the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI). The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) formally assesses the safety, quality, and efficacy of medicines, including vaccines for children, prior to their approval for use in Australia.

On 19 November 2021, ATAGI recommended COVID-19 vaccination for all Australians from 12 years of age. On 5 December 2021, the TGA provisionally approved the Pfizer vaccine for children aged five to 11 in Australia. The Government plans to commence the roll out of vaccinations for five to 11 years from 10 January 2022.

Further, state and territory governments have operational responsibility for emergency management and public health in their respective jurisdictions, as described in the National Health Security Agreement. State and territory governments' actions are based on the medical advice from their respective Chief Health Officers.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Biosecurity
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning petition EN3277 to terminate the COVID-19 human biosecurity emergency period under the Biosecurity Act 2015 (Act).

SARS-CoV-2, the virus which causes COVID-19, is real. Multiple scientific studies across the world demonstrate that highly reputable laboratory medicine experts have isolated and sequenced the virus that causes COVID-19, demonstrating that the virus exists, that it exists in variant forms, that it is different from the influenza virus, and that it causes a disease that has resulted in more than 5.2 million deaths worldwide in just over 23 months. While my Department is not the custodian of the scientific studies establishing the existence of SARS-CoV-2, this research has informed the Australian Government's response to the pandemic.

Human coronavirus with pandemic potential (including COVID-19) was declared a listed human disease under the Biosecurity (Listed Human Diseases) Determination 2016 on 21 January 2020. In order for a disease to become a listed human disease, the Director of Human Biosecurity must be satisfied that the disease may be communicable and cause significant harm to human health.

On 30 January 2020, the World Health Organization (WHO) determined the COVID-19 outbreak to be a Public Health Emergency of International Concern, reflecting the international spread of the disease to several regions of the world and limited evidence of human to human transmission outside of mainland China. Additionally, in recognition of the significant further international spread including increasing case numbers and deaths as a result of COVID-19, the WHO declared a pandemic on 11 March 2020.

On 18 March 2020, the Governor-General declared a human biosecurity emergency on advice from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, pursuant to section 475 of the Act. The declaration enlivens the powers for the Minister for Health and Aged Care to determine requirements and give directions to prevent the spread of COVID-19 as a result of the emergency being declared. The current human biosecurity emergency period under the Act is scheduled to lapse on 17 December 2021, unless extended by the Governor-General.

Under section 476 of the Act, the Governor-General may vary a human biosecurity emergency declaration to extend the human biosecurity emergency period for a period of up to three months on the condition that the Minister is satisfied that:
the listed human disease (COVID-19) is continuing to pose a severe and immediate threat or is continuing to cause harm to human health on a nationally significant scale
the extension is necessary to prevent or control the entry into, or the emergence, establishment or spread of COVID-19 in Australian territory or a part of Australian territory.

The human biosecurity emergency period and the requirements made under the emergency period will cease when the public health and legal threshold for a further extension of the emergency period cannot be met.

Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) using polymerase chain reaction (PCR) on a respiratory sample collected by a throat and bilateral deep nasal (or nasopharyngeal) swab is the gold standard test for confirming an acute diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2 infection. This test method is very sensitive and detects nucleic acid sequences specific to the virus. PCR testing has been comprehensively validated and continues to be monitored by pathology laboratories both locally and internationally to ensure a high testing and performance standard is met.

It is important to note that no test has 100 per cent sensitivity or specificity in all clinical circumstances. PCR testing may not always detect the virus when it is present in low levels. For example, after initial infection with SARS-CoV-2, it takes a number of days for viral replication to produce enough genetic material to be detected by PCR. Testing during the incubation period (approximately 2-3 days) may return a negative result, even when an individual is infected with SARS-CoV-2. There is currently no test that will reliably detect the virus during the incubation period when a person is asymptomatic. There is also no test that can reliably detect whether and individual is infectious. Therefore, it is important that all testing for SARS-CoV-2 is conducted in line with the Communicable Disease Network Australia (CDNA) COVID-19 Series of National Guidelines for Public Health Units. The CDNA Guidance can be found at:
www1 .health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/cdna-song-novel-coronavirus.htm.

Further information on interpreting SARS-CoV-2 NAAT results, including PCR, can be found in the Public Health Laboratory Network guidance on nucleic acid test result interpretation for SARS-CoV-2 on my Department's website.
Resources on COVID-19 can also be found at:
www.health.gov.au/news/health-alerts/novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov-health-alert.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence concerning Petition EN3364 asking the House to ensure the immediate repeal of the statement on ivermectin made by the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) within my Department. I regret the delay in responding.

Ivermectin is an anti-parasite medication that is used to treat human and animal diseases. Oral ivermectin (Stromectol) is approved by the TGA for the treatment of river blindness (onchocerciasis), threadworm of the intestines (intestinal strongyloidiasis), and scabies.

On 10 September 2021, the TGA decision maker (delegate), acting on the advice of the Advisory Committee for Medicines Scheduling (Advisory Committee), placed restrictions on the prescribing of oral ivermectin through a change to its scheduling entry in the Poisons Standard. The Advisory Committee, which included senior medical officers and pharmacists as well as representatives from each state and territory, unanimously supported the change. The change is also supported by the two peak bodies representing general practitioners—The Royal Australian College of General Practitioners and Australian Medical Association.

The TGA decision is independent from Commonwealth parliamentary processes and is given effect through state and territory law and regulation. It should be noted that there are a significant number of other medicines that either cannot be prescribed by GPs, or alternatively require individual special authorisation (e.g. by the Chief Executive Officer of their state health department) to do so.

GPs can now only prescribe ivermectin for TGA-approved conditions (indications) such as scabies and certain parasitic infections. Certain specialists including infectious disease physicians, dermatologists, gastroenterologists, and hepatologists can prescribe ivermectin for other unapproved indications if they believe it is appropriate for a particular patient. Ivermectin is one of 30 substances for which only certain medical practitioners can prescribe. For these 30 substances, prescribers have either to be certain types of specialists, or have a specific prescribing approval from the Secretary of my Department or the head of a state or territory health department.

The TGA introduced these changes because of concerns with the prescribing of oral ivermectin for the claimed prevention or treatment of COVID-19. These concerns include the significant public health risks to an individual, and those around them, associated with taking ivermectin in an attempt to prevent COVID-19 infection rather than being vaccinated, the unsafe dosages being promoted, and to ensure continued access for those who need the medicine for the treatment of scabies and parasitic infections.

Ivermectin is not approved for the treatment of COVID-19 in Australia, or in any other comparable Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development country. Its use by the general public for COVID-19 is strongly discouraged by the National COVID Clinical Evidence Taskforce, the World Health Organization, the United States of America's Food and Drug Administration, and the European Medicines Agency.

Merck, one of the major companies manufacturing ivermectin, publicly confirmed on 4 February 2021 that, to date, there is no scientific basis for a potential therapeutic effect against COVID-19 from pre-clinical studies, no meaningful evidence for clinical activity or clinical efficacy in patients with COVID-19 disease, and a concerning lack of safety data in the majority of studies.

In addition, a recent analysis of published ivermectin trials by the Cochrane Collaboration (Collaboration) concluded that ivermectin could not be recommended for COVID-19 treatment or prevention. The Collaboration is one of the key independent international bodies responsible for assessing clinical evidence for medical treatments and therapies. The Collaboration also found that the available evidence for ivermectin is of low to very low quality, and insufficient to come to any clinically meaningful conclusions.

If a sponsor holds the appropriate evidence, such as data demonstrating the safe and efficacious use of ivermectin for the treatment of COVID-19, they can make an application at any time to the TGA to register their medicine on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods. Any application must include a comprehensive data package to support the medicine's safety, quality, and efficacy for the intended end use.

My Department has published information on how evidence is used in the approach to COVID-19 treatments to keep Australians safe. I can assure the House that the TGA is regularly meeting with researchers, developers and manufacturers about a wide range of medicines for the prevention and treatment of COVID-1-9 in a variety of clinical settings.

The TGA ensures that effective treatments are made available to Australians in a manner that broadly protects public health. To date, the TGA has provisionally approved seven COVID-19 treatments: Remdesivir (VEKLURY), Sotrovimab (XEVUDY), casirivimab/imdevimab (RONAPREVE), tocilizumab (ACTEMRA); regdanvimab (REGKIRONA), nirmatrelvir + ritonavir (PAXLOVID) and molnupiravir (LAGEVRIO), and has provisionally designated one other COVID-19 medicine for evaluation through the provisional pathway. Up-to-date information about COVID-19 treatments available in Australia is on the TGA's website.

I note the petition seeks a firm assurance to the Australian people that 'overreach of this kind by a Federal Government agency will never again limit access to safe treatments in a non-consultative and unilateral manner'. I can assure the House that there has been no overreach as I have outlined. The TGA followed relevant policies and processes in the course of its consideration concerning this change.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Biosecurity Act
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 November 2021 to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Greg Hunt MP, concerning petition EN3405, which raises certain concerns about the Biosecurity Amendment (Enhanced Risk Management) Bill 2021, specifically in relation to 'biosecurity enforcement orders'. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for Agriculture and Northern Australia as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government takes the management of biosecurity and human biosecurity risks seriously. The government is taking appropriate steps to strengthen the Biosecurity Act 2015 (the Act) to protect Australians, our agricultural industries and our environment from exotic pests and diseases. The Bill includes a range of proposed improvements to support the borders reopening safely while managing the risk of listed human diseases.

The Bill provides for the use of human biosecurity group directions in limited circumstances in order to manage risks of the entry, emergence, establishment or spread of a listed human disease in Australia.

International vessels at Australia's borders are a key risk pathway for the entry of infectious diseases into Australian territory. The Inspector-General of Biosecurity has recommended that the Act be amended to provide broader mechanisms for managing large numbers of passengers and crew with potential listed human diseases on board vessels.

Infectious diseases do not discriminate based on religion, ethnicity or political-social groupings. Consistent with this, the Bill ensures that all decisions about human biosecurity group directions, from determining the class of individuals to be specified in a direction, to the biosecurity measures individuals are required to comply with, are appropriately focussed on the management of biosecurity risks.

The Bill contains important and appropriate safeguards. First, only a chief human biosecurity officer or a human biosecurity officer may make a human biosecurity group direction. This is because clinical expertise or qualifications are needed to make informed public health and medical decisions about the assessment and management of a class of individuals in relation to risks posed by a listed human disease.
Second, the class of individuals specified in a human biosecurity group direction must be some or all of the individuals who:
are on board an aircraft or a vessel that is in Australian territory

are either at a landing place or port in Australian territory, or at a place that is in close proximity to it. This may include people who may be at a heightened risk of contagion because of their exposure to an unwell passenger who has disembarked.

Only individuals who fall within this definition can be subject to a human biosecurity group direction, and the Bill does not allow such group directions to specify other classes of individuals residing in Australia.

Third, a chief human biosecurity officer or a human biosecurity officer must be satisfied that one or more people on the aircraft or vessel show signs or symptoms of a listed human disease or have been exposed to such a disease. A listed human disease is one that has been identified by the Director of Human Biosecurity (who is the Commonwealth Chief Medical Officer) under the Act as warranting Commonwealth intervention because the disease may be communicable and cause significant harm to human health. Current examples include smallpox and human coronavirus with pandemic potential, such as COVID-19.

Fourth, to ensure the making of a human biosecurity group direction is reasonable and proportionate to achieve a legitimate objective, the general protections set out in section 34 of the Act will apply. This means that before making a decision in relation to a biosecurity measure included in a human biosecurity group direction, a chief human biosecurity officer or human biosecurity officer must be satisfied of a range of important considerations, including that the manner in which the measure is to be imposed is no more intrusive or restrictive than required to manage the risk posed by the listed human disease. Force must not be used to require compliance with these biosecurity measures and the group direction must not interfere with any urgent or life-threatening medical needs of an individual.

Lastly, a human biosecurity group direction may be in force for no longer than is reasonably necessary to address the risk, up to a maximum of eight hours with a single extension available for up to four hours. While a new direction can be made if the class of individuals still require assessment or management after the initial direction expires, a direction is only intended to be a preliminary measure to assess and manage the immediate risk of contagion of a listed human disease.

The combination of these provisions ensures that the Bill does offer adequate protections and limitations against possible overreach, while achieving the legitimate objective of protecting public health. Moreover, the Bill contains detailed and appropriate limitations on the use of the directions against classes of people, and it does not limit the application of any other Australian law, such as anti-discrimination legislation.

The Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee considered whether the Bill has an appropriate regulatory balance for managing human health risks and reporting requirements for aircraft and maritime vessels to enable Australia's borders to reopen safely. The committee recommended that the Senate pass the Bill.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Agriculture and Northern Australia, Mr Littleproud
cc: The Hon Greg Hunt MP, Minister for Health and Aged Care
COVID-19
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 22 November 2021 concerning petition number EN3416 requesting the standard cycle threshold (Ct) for the COVID-19 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test be lowered to 28 Ct.

The Australian Government is continuing to take a strong and decisive approach to responding to COVID-19, based on the latest medical advice from the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee, and its expert standing committees, including the Public Health Laboratory Network, and remains vigilant about the evolution of the pandemic.

Australia is also fortunate to be supported by an expert and extensive network of public and private laboratories with the capability, capacity, and appropriate accreditation to detect SARS-CoV-2 (the virus that causes COVID-19). The ability of this sector to scale-up testing capacity has been essential to Australia's success in flattening the curve and avoiding the devastating infection rates seen in other countries.

In Australia, nucleic acid amplification testing using PCR on a respiratory sample collected by a throat and bilateral deep nasal (or nasopharyngeal) swab is the gold standard test for the acute diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2 infection. This test method is very sensitive and detects nucleic acid sequences specific to the virus. PCR testing has been comprehensively validated and continues to be monitored by pathology laboratories both locally and internationally to ensure a high testing and performance standard is met.

During the testing process, the PCR amplifies (i.e., makes many copies of) a highly specific target region of the SARS-CoV-2 genome so that it can be detected. Each amplification reaction is known as a cycle. The Ct value of a reaction is the cycle number when the fluorescence of a PCR product can be detected above the background signal. Each PCR assay may have a different Ct value that is used for detecting SARS-CoV-2. Ct values for one in vitro diagnostic (IVD) device should not be compared with Ct values from other platforms. Ct values are IVD dependant. This means there is no 'set' Ct value to aim for across all platforms. There are also nucleic acid amplification devices used for the diagnosis of SARS-COV-2 infection which do not record a Ct value. This emphasises the need for interpretation of results by a suitably qualified pathologist or laboratory medicine scientist.

Furthermore, commercial IVD Devices are subject to TGA regulations and require that pathologists and medical laboratory scientists to follow the manufacturer's instructions for use. For in-house assays, the parameters for determining a result have been determined by the laboratory through the assay development and evaluation process.

In Australia, all properly accredited pathology providers offering testing to detect SARS-CoV-2 operate in accordance with the requirements established by the National Pathology Accreditation Advisory Council (NPAAC) and undergo accreditation by assessment by the National Association of Testing Authorities, Australia in conjunction with the Royal College of Pathologists of Australasia which assess to the NPAAC requirements and use the international standard ISO 1589 as an assessment guide.

The combined SARS-CoV-2 PCR testing experience in Australia is that the false positive rate is extremely low. However, it is important to note that no test has 100 per cent sensitivity or specificity in all clinical circumstances. PCR testing may not always detect the virus when it is present in low levels. For example, after initial infection with SARS-CoV-2, it takes a number of days for viral replication to produce enough genetic material to be detected by PCR. This occurs roughly two to three days before symptoms become apparent. Testing during the incubation period may return a negative result, even when an individual is infected with SARS-CoV-2.

Therefore, it is important that all testing for SARS-CoV-2 is conducted in line with the Communicable Diseases Network Australia (CDNA) COVID-19 Series of National Guidelines for Public Health Units. The CDNA Guidance can be found at:
www1.health.gov.au/intemet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/cdna-song-novel-coronavirus.htm.
For further information, the Public Health Laboratory Network has published technical guidance on nucleic acid test result interpretation for SARS-CoV-2 on my Department's website at:
www.health.gov.au/resources/publications/phln-guidance-on-nucleic-acid-test-result-interpretation-for-sars-cov-2.

As the pandemic situation continues to evolve and new evidence emerges, the Government will continue to review its response strategies and provide Australians with the most up-to-date information and advice on my Department's website at:
www.health.gov.au.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Health Care
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 15 January 2022 to the Minister for Government Services, the Hon Stuart Robert MP, concerning petition PN0491, relating to the process for payment of Medicare benefits. This matter has been referred to me as the Minister for Health and Aged Care.

The 2021-22 Budget announced a measure to cease Pay Doctor via Claimant cheques from 1 July 2023 for unpaid and partially paid claims submitted to Services Australia. Services Australia will no longer post a cheque for the Medicare benefit amount to the claimant, made out in the name of the health practitioner. Instead, Services Australia will send an automatic electronic funds transfer (EFT) for the Medicare benefit amount to the health practitioner after 90 days.

The EFT scheme supports patients who cannot afford to pay the full fee at the time of the medical service, while retaining bulk-billing as the mechanism for health practitioners to receive the Medicare benefit within days of submitting a claim to Medicare. Bulk billing is an important component of the Medicare system.

EFT payments will be made via existing bank account details that health practitioners and claimants have provided to Services Australia for the payment of other Medicare claims. No further action is required from health practitioners or claimants if correct banking details are registered with Services Australia.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination

I refer to your correspondence to the Minister for Education and Youth, the Hon Alan Tudge MP concerning petition EN3425—recognition of Sinopharm and Sinovac vaccines for international students returning to Australia. This matter has been referred to me as the Minister for Health and Aged Care. I regret the delay in responding.

On 15 December 2021, Australia reopened to fully vaccinated international students, skilled migrants, working holiday makers and refugee, humanitarian, temporary and provisional family visa holders as part of our step by step and safe reopening to the world. Individuals are considered fully vaccinated seven days after they have completed a full course of a Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) approved or recognised vaccine, including a mixed dose. More information is available via the TGA website at:
www.health.gov.au/health-alerts/covid-19/international-travel#approved-and-recognised-vaccines·

Current accepted vaccines and dosages for the purposes of travel are two doses at least 14 days apart of AstraZeneca Vaxzevria, AstraZeneca Covishield, Pfizer/Biontech Comirnaty, Moderna Spikevax, Moderna Takeda, Sinovac Coronavac, Sinopharm BBIBP-CorV (for people under 60 years of age on arrival in Australia), Bharat Biotech Covaxin and Gamaleya Research Institute Sputnik V or one dose of Johnson & Johnson/Janssen-Cilag COVID Vaccine.

Seven days must have passed since the final dose of vaccine in a course of immunisation for individuals to be considered fully vaccinated. Mixed doses count towards being fully vaccinated as long as all vaccines are approved or recognised by the TGA. Travellers who have received a vaccine other than a TGA recognised or approved vaccine, or have not been vaccinated, may still be able to travel, but only under the rules of unvaccinated travel.

The TGA will continue to work on vaccine recognition in the coming weeks and months and expects to receive more data on a wide range of other vaccines already in use or in late-stage clinical trials in other countries. The most up-to-date information on approved and recognised vaccines is available on the TGA website at: www.tga.gov.au/intemational-covid-19-vaccines-recognised-australia#_blank.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Pensions and Benefits
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email dated 23 November 2021 concerning a petition (EN3471) presented to the House of Representatives on social security pension payments.

Australia's social security system is a non-contributory system designed to support the basic living standards of all Australians and increase their social and economic participation. Pensions are funded by taxpayers and targeted through the means test to those who need them most. They are designed to provide income support to people who, for reasons such as age, unemployment or ill health, are unable to support themselves.
Income support payments fall into 2 groups: pensions and allowances. The type of payment a person receives depends on their circumstances.

Working age allowance payments such as JobSeeker Payment are designed to provide a safety net for people who require financial assistance, while maintaining incentives for people to join or return to the workforce. Recipients are required to undertake a range of activities while receiving their allowance. JobSeeker Payment rates are indexed to the Consumer Price Index (CPI) twice a year on 20 March and 20 September.

On 1 April 2021, the Australian Government permanently increased the rate of working age allowance payments by $50 a fortnight. This is more than a $9 billion spend across the forward estimates, which equates to about a 10 per cent increase on the Government's typical annual spend on JobSeeker Payment. People receive additional support above and beyond the base rate of JobSeeker Payment—including supplementary payments, assistance through the jobactive network, concessions on healthcare and childcare.

Pensions are designed to acknowledge that some people face additional barriers such as age, disability or caring responsibilities that make it difficult for them to support themselves or supplement their income through paid employment.
Pensions are paid at the highest legislated rate of income support in the social security system because recipients are not expected to work to support themselves.

Under social security law, base pension rates are indexed twice a year to ensure they keep up with increases in the cost of living, as measured by the CPI and the Pensioner and Beneficiary Living Cost Index. These rates are calculated according to provisions in legislation and are not a decision of government. Base pension rates are also benchmarked to Male Total Average Weekly Earnings (MTAWE) to align them with community living standards. Base pension rates are currently above the MTAWE benchmark.

On 20 September 2021, the maximum total pension rate for single pensioners increased by $14.80 to $967.50 a fortnight or $25,155 a year. The maximum rate for pensioner couples combined increased by $22.40 to $1,458.60 a fortnight or $37,923.60 a year. Pension rates will continue to be reviewed twice a year, as set out in legislation.

In addition to their main payment, pensioners can receive a range of benefits and concessions that increase their economic security, including Commonwealth Rent Assistance, subsidised prescription medicines under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, subsidised health care and related products, and subsidised aged care.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston
Transport Industry
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence, originally directed to the Treasurer, concerning Petition EN3483 and the luxury car tax (LCT). Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The LCT has existed in one form or another for many years. Since its introduction, the LCT was sometimes seen as a protectionist measure as most cars priced over the LCT threshold tended to be imported. However, this was not the intention of the LCT. Prior to its introduction in 2000 as part of the goods and services tax (GST) changes, luxury cars were taxed at the standard rate of wholesale sales tax plus a higher rate above the luxury threshold. The current LCT was introduced to ensure that after the introduction of the GST, the value of luxury cars did not drop dramatically relative to non-luxury cars but only in a manner consistent with the removal of the standard rate of wholesale sales tax.

The Australian Government has no plans to change the LCT in its current form. The Government uses the revenue collected by the LCT to fund essential services that all Australians benefit from such as health, education, defence and security.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
1 refer to your correspondence concerning petition EN3496—vaccinations for children aged five to 11 years old. I regret the delay in responding.

The safety of the Australian population has always been the Australian Government's highest priority. For this reason, decisions concerning COVID-19 vaccines have been, and continue to be, based on the expert medical advice of the Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation (ATAGI).

As the Government continues to expand and accelerate the vaccine rollout, it is taking the issue of vaccinating younger Australians against COVID-19 very seriously. As of 10 January 2022, roll out of the Comirnaty Paediatric (Pfizer) COVID-19 vaccine to individuals aged five to 11 years of age commenced.

The paediatric version of the Pfizer vaccine uses a smaller dosage (one-third) of the same vaccine used for youth and adults. This version has been demonstrated to be safe and effective in millions of children worldwide. ATAGI has approved a two-dose vaccination program for five to 11 year olds soon with an eight-week interval.

The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) rigorously assesses all vaccines for safety, quality, and effectiveness. The approvals are subject to certain strict conditions, such as the requirement for sponsors to continue providing information to the TGA on longer term efficacy and safety from ongoing clinical trials and post-market assessment. Emerging clinical trial evidence, as well as real world data then continues to be monitored by technical experts. More information on the TGA evaluation process for COVID-19 vaccines can be found at: www.tga.gov.au/covid-19-vaccines.

Children can be affected by COVID-19, especially by the dominant delta variant strain. Although the severity of illness from COVID-19 is lower, adolescents appear to have similar infection rates to adults. Approximately four to seven per cent experience a severe outcome, and more may experience complications from COVID-19. Complications may include prolonged symptoms ('long COVID') or Paediatric Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome Temporally associated with SARS-CoV-2 (PIMS-TS).

The Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective public health measure to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death. At the same time, the Government's position on COVID-19 vaccination is that it is voluntary, as are all vaccinations in Australia.

The five to 11 year olds Pfizer vaccine is now available through a variety of available channels including through state and territory clinics, Commonwealth Vaccine Clinics, general practices, Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Services, Vaccine Administration Panel Providers, and pharmacies.

We have sufficient doses for every child aged five to 11 years to be fully vaccinated with first and second doses in the first quarter of 2022. Our advanced purchase agreement for 60 million doses of Pfizer for 2022 and 25 million doses for 2023 includes paediatric doses children aged five to 11 years.

The ATAGI recommendation on the Pfizer Paediatric vaccine is available on my Department's website at: www.health.gov.au using the search term 'ATAGI recommendations on Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine use in children aged five to 11 years'.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning petition EN3497 on the production of the AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria) COVID-19 vaccine in Australia. I regret the delay in responding.

The AstraZeneca vaccine continues to be manufactured in Australia and will be made into 2022. AstraZeneca remains committed to fulfilling its contractual agreements to supply 53.8 million doses. My Department is working closely with AstraZeneca to ensure that domestic production is being met.

The Australian Government has invested in a diverse portfolio of COVID-19 vaccines, based on advice from the expert Science and Industry Technical Advisory Group. Australia currently is entered into five separate agreements for the supply of COVID-19 vaccines, if they are proved to be safe and effective. My portfolio has allowed for ample supply for all Australians and is now offering a choice of vaccine.

Australia is stepping up its support to bring the COVID-19 pandemic to an end in our region and globally. Australia's health security is tied to that of our neighbours and access to vaccines and support for the national vaccine rollout is fundamental to the Indo-Pacific region's response to COVID-19.
On 22 September 2021, at the Global Summit on COVID-19, the Prime Minister committed to supplying up to 60 million vaccine doses to our region by the end of 2022, including:
20 million vaccine doses from Australia's own supply already committed to share with the Pacific and Southeast Asia by mid-2022
an additional 20 million doses from Australia's own supply to be shared by the end of 2022

up to a further 20 million doses to be procured through a partnership with United Nations Children Fund, also to be shared by the end of 2022 and managed by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT).

Australia's $130 million contribution to the COVAX Advance Market Commitment (AMC) is supporting equitable global access to effective COVID-19 vaccines, with more than 344 million doses delivered to developing countries around the world to date. Through the COVAX AMC, more than 89 million doses have been distributed to Southeast Asia and the Pacific since the start of 2021.

Further enhancing Australia's support for the Pacific and South East Asia, on 31 October 2020 DFAT announced the creation of the Regional Vaccine Access and Health Security Initiative that consists of a range of support mechanisms, including supplying effective vaccine doses and delivering technical support to our regional partners. The Government has allocated $623 million to this initiative.

As at 4 January 2022, Australia has shared more than 17 million doses with the Pacific and Southeast Asian region, as per the Government's Health Security Initiative, which can be found online at: www.indopacifichealthsecurity.dfat.gov.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
First Nations People
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 29 November 2021 to the Minister for Indigenous Australians, the Hon Ken Wyatt AM MP, regarding a petition relating to the High Court decision in Love v Commonwealth; Thoms v Commonwealth (2020) 270 CLR 152 ('Love'). As the issues raised fall within my portfolio responsibilities, your correspondence was referred to me for reply.

The Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs and the Minister for Home Affairs appealed to the Full Federal Court from the decision of Justice Derrington of the Federal Court in Montgomery v Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs ('Montgomery'). One of the grounds of appeal is that the High Court's decision in Love should be overruled.

On 29 November 2021, on my application, the appeal was removed into the High Court of Australia. I have intervened in the matter in support of the Ministers under section 78A of the Judiciary Act 1903 (Cth).

The Government respects the High Court's decision in Love and is acting in accordance with that decision. It raises important legal questions about the scope of the Commonwealth Parliament's power to make laws under section 51(xix) of the Constitution in relation to 'aliens'.

The Government's reasons for seeking to overturn Love are set out in its submissions to the High Court in Montgomery, which are available on the High Court's website. It would not be appropriate to comment further on a matter that is before the High Court.
The Government is committed to working closely with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people on policy to improve their socio-economic outcomes.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash (Petition No. EN3510)
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 29 November 2021 concerning Petition Number EN3532 the introduction of a no fault national vaccine injury compensation scheme covering historical and future severe adverse reactions to all Therapeutic Goods Association (TGA) approved vaccines.

A no fault vaccine injury compensation scheme is not considered necessary. Australia has universal access to health care through the public health system, as well as a comprehensive social support system in place; including access to the Disability Support Pension and the National Disability Insurance Scheme.

With respect to the COVID-19 Vaccine Claims Scheme, it has been established as a fit-for-purpose, time-limited claims scheme to respond to the unprecedented circumstances of the COVID-19 pandemic. It is designed to ensure that people who have suffered a recognised adverse effect as a direct result of a COVID-19 vaccine have faster access to compensation than a costly and complex court process. As widespread vaccination is an essential response to overcome the COVID-19 pandemic, the Government, following consultation with medical, consumer and insurance sectors, agreed to develop a no fault compensation scheme. Vaccinations and claims for compensation will be accepted up to two years after the end of the Human Biosecurity Emergency period under the Biosecurity Act 2015.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Australian Broadcasting Corporation
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter of 29 November 2021 concerning petition number EN3534, about the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's (ABC) coverage of certain matters.

The ABC has editorial and operational independence, though it is accountable to Parliament through its annual reports, corporate plans, financial and performance audits, and in appearances before parliamentary committees. The ABC Board is required also to develop a code of practice on its programming matters and lodge this code with the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA).
I maintain regular contact with the ABC Board to encourage its adherence to its Charter to inform, entertain and reflect the cultural diversity of Australia.

Concerned members of the public may engage with the ABC by contacting the broadcaster directly. This is the best way to guarantee that the ABC is made aware of any concerns and is given the opportunity to respond.

If audience members are not satisfied with the response they receive from the ABC or have not received a response within 60 days, they may refer the matter to ACMA for investigation. Information about making a complaint to ACMA about content broadcast on ABC TV or radio is on ACMA's website at www.acma.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Kashmir

Thank you for your email of 29 November 2021 regarding petititon PN0524, concerning the rights of the people of Kashmir.

The Australian Government recognises the importance of open political systems and internationally accepted rules, norms and due processes. The promotion and protection of human rights globally is a foreign policy priority for Australia. We continue to raise human rights concerns through bilateral, regional and multilateral processes.

China: Human Rights
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 15 February 2021 regarding Petition EN2206, which requested that Parliament cancel the China-Australia Free Trade Agreement (FTA) in response to the human rights situation in Xinjiang.

The Australian Government is deeply concerned about credible reports of severe human rights abuses against Uyghurs and other Muslim ethnic minorities in Xinjiang. These include restrictions on freedom of religion, mass surveillance, large-scale extra-judicial detentions, forced labour and forced birth control, including sterilisation.

Australia does not shy away from speaking out about these matters. Most recently, Prime Minister Morrison expressed the Government's serious concerns about the situation in Xinjiang in a joint statement with the Prime Minister of Japan, HE Mr Fumio Kishida, on 6 January 2022. Australia's Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator the Hon Marise Payne, and Minister for Defence, the Hon Peter Dutton MP, also did so, in a joint statement with their UK counterparts, on 21 January 2022. And at the UN General Assembly in October 2021, Australia was one of 43 countries to issue a joint statement expressing concern about human rights abuses in Xinjiang, and calling on China to allow access for independent observers, including the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Michelle Bachelet.
The Government will continue to raise concerns at the United Nations, in our national and joint statements with the international community, and directly with China.

The Government is not considering cancelling the China-Australia FTA. Australia's openness to trade is a key driver of our national prosperity, supporting jobs and higher wages, and our FTA with China remains in Australia's national interests.

However, the Government is aware of credible reports of forced labour in Xinjiang, and is taking concrete action to combat any risk of forced labour in Australian supply chains. The Australian Government has introduced robust legislation to combat all forms of modern slavery, including forced labour (the Modern Slavery Act 2018). The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Australian Border Force also engage proactively with the business community to raise awareness of the risks of doing business in Xinjiang. We urge any Australian company with links to the region to undertake due diligence into its supply chains and suppliers, and to ensure its operations are consistent with Australian law and international standards.
I have copied this letter to the Minister for Foreign Affairs.
Thank you for bringing this matter to the attention of the Government. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Trade, Tourism and Investment, Mr Tehan
International Development Assistance
Dear Chair

Thank you for the referral of petition EN2299 concerning Australia's development program contributions to the Asian Development Fund and the Pacific Private Sector Development Initiative, which are funds managed by the Asian Development Bank.

The Australian Government has transformed our development program to stand with our neighbours in the wake of COVID-19. Until our region is safe, prosperous, and healthy, neither are we. Our development program makes investments through a range of delivery partners, including the Asian Development Bank, with the aim of supporting an open, inclusive and resilient Indo-Pacific region. We work in lockstep with our diplomatic, defence and economic engagement to support our region to address the devastating impacts of COVID-19.

How our region responds to and recovers from the pandemic directly affects Australia's national interests. If transmission rates are not controlled, our own health security will be compromised. If cohesion within countries falters, this will impact our own security. If the region does not recover rapidly, our own economy will be affected, including the one in five Australian jobs that depend on international trade.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Child Support Scheme
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for referring Petition EN2489 to me on 13 January 2022. As the matters raised fall within my portfolio responsibility, your letter has been forwarded to me for reply.
I note the petitioner has raised similar concerns in Petition EN3349. The petitioner may be interested in the following information.

Australia's child support scheme is designed to ensure parents take responsibility for the ongoing financial care of their children in line with their financial capacities. Child support is in place to ensure that as far as possible children affected by a family breakdown remain financially secure no matter the custody arrangements. Child Support exists to assess and collect child support payments for the benefit of children of separated parents, and does not make any distinction based on the gender or background of either the paying or receiving parent.

The child support formula was introduced in 2008, using extensive research undertaken by the Ministerial Taskforce on Child Support on the costs of caring for children in Australia. The child support formula incorporates each parent's 'cost percentage' for a child based on the amount of care they provide for that child. Child support assessments are also generally based on parents' adjusted taxable income for the last relevant financial year as this is generally the most up-to-date and accurate income information available.

Child support assessments are generally calculated on the actual care of the children, as this helps to ensure they have access to an adequate amount of ongoing financial support, regardless of whom they reside with. Services Australia may take into account the amount of time during both day and night that each parent cares for the child, as well as who is responsible for making arrangements for, and decisions about, the child's welfare.

Adjusted taxable income, rather than net or gross income, to calculate both parents' incomes, as it better reflects parents' true capacity to support their children. Adjusted taxable income is also used in the Costs of the Children Table which means the effect of taxation is taken into account under the child support formula as the same approach is used for both income and expenditure.

If either parent believes their child support assessment is unfair because of the special circumstances of their case, they can seek a review under the change of assessment process. The change of assessment process allows Services Australia to examine the broader financial circumstances of both parents to determine an appropriate amount of child support payable.
Services Australia encourages parents who are behind in their child support payments to enter into an arrangement to address their debt in the shortest possible time.

Services Australia can use any combination of the available collection methods including garnishee arrangements to ensure children of separated parents are financially supported. The effective enforcement of child support obligations is central to the integrity of the child support scheme.

Family breakdown are difficult, and the Government funds a range of support services such as Lifeline and MensLine Australia to support people reaching out for assistance in a time of need. MensLine is a 24-hour counselling, information and referral service for men. MensLine Australia can be contacted on 1300 789 978, or through their website at www.mensline.org.au.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston
Pensions and Benefits
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for referring EN2602—Pensions and Benefits (including childcare subsidies) to me on 13 January 2022. As the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities, your letter was referred to me for reply.

The Government provides support to a range of individuals and families through the family assistance, income support and tax systems. While the support of children is primarily the responsibility of parents who, within the limits of their capacities, are expected to provide for their children, family assistance programs assist most families with some of the costs of raising children in recognition of this socially valuable role. The wellbeing of children is important to all Australians and essential for the future of the nation. Therefore, the Government supports families to raise their children regardless of family size.

The Australian welfare system is needs-based and is targeted through income testing to individuals and families that most require support and assistance. The system is intended to respond to the circumstances of families and is not designed to promote any particular family structures.
Thank you again for writing.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston
Youth Allowance
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for referring Petition (EN2680)—Youth Allowance age of independence to me on 13 January 2022. As the matters raised fall within my portfolio responsibility, your letter has been forwarded to me for reply.

The Australian Government provides a wide range of financial supports for young people to assist them to live, study and meet study costs, including assistance relocating to or from a regional area to study or undertake a practical placement in a regional area. Supports include Youth Allowance, Austudy and ABSTUDY payments, further supplemented by Relocation Scholarships, Student Start-up Loans, Assistance for Isolated Children and Fares Allowance. Provisions are also made to support students to earn their own income through use of an income free threshold and ability to use Income Bank credits.

Youth Allowance policy is based on the principle that financial support for students is a shared responsibility between parents, the Government and the young person themselves. The Government believes that parents should support their children, where they are able, until they achieve financial independence. This will often include support with tertiary studies which may take 3 to 4 years to complete. Applying the parental and partner income test ensures Government support is targeted to those families least able to support their child/children with living and study-related costs.

There are a range of reasons that young people can qualify as independent for Youth Allowance, one of which one is turning 22 years of age. Other criteria include where the person's parents cannot exercise their responsibilities for certain reasons, where it is unreasonable to live at home (such as conflict, lack of physical facilities, or chronic illness in the family), where the young person themselves is a parent, or where they have demonstrated their ability to support themselves through paid work.
Thank you again for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 9 August 2021, to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Greg Hunt MP, enclosing Petition EN2702 with 241 signatures, which seeks lifting travel restrictions for unmarried and same sex couples. Your correspondence was referred to me as 13 January 2022, as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

Australia's travel restriction policy has played a key foundational role underpinning management of COVID-19's impact on public health in Australia and was implemented on the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

As of 21 February 2022, all fully vaccinated visa holders, including those with a visitor visa, will be able to enter Australia without a travel exemption. This further re-opening of our international border will ensure we protect the health of Australians, while we continue to secure our economic recovery.

The Australian Border Force Commissioner's travel exemption system will remain in place for unvaccinated travellers. Visa holders who are not fully vaccinated will still require a valid travel exemption to enter Australia, and will be subject to state and territory quarantine requirements.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN2702 to the Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
COVID-19: International Travel

Thank you for your correspondence of 9 August 2021, to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Greg Hunt MP, enclosing Petition EN2712 with 4090 signatures, which seeks automatic travel exemptions for Prospective Marriage (subclass 300) visa holders. Your correspondence has been referred to me on 13 January 2022, as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

Australia's current travel restriction policy has played a key foundational role underpinning management of COVID-19's impact on public health in Australia and was implemented on the advice of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee.

As of 21 February 2022, all fully vaccinated visa holders, including those with a visitor visa, will be able to enter Australia without a travel exemption. This further re-opening of our international border will ensure we protect the health of Australians, while we continue to secure our economic recovery.

The Australian Border Force Commissioner's travel exemption system will remain in place for unvaccinated travellers. Visa holders who are not fully vaccinated will still require a valid travel exemption to enter Australia, and will be subject to state and territory quarantine requirements.

Youth Allowance
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for referring Petition (EN2743)—Youth Allowance independence criteria and income free threshold to me on 13 January 2022. As the matters raised fall within my portfolio responsibility, your letter has been forwarded to me for reply.
Youth Allowance policy is based on the principle that financial support for students is a shared responsibility between parents, the Government and the young person themselves.

Generally, students aged under 22 years are considered financially dependent on their parents and are subject to both parental and personal means testing. Parental means testing arrangements take into account a family's situation and targets support to those most in need. While young people over the age of 18 may be considered, by the community to be independent and able to undertake various activities associated with adulthood they may still be dependent on their parents for financial assistance.

It is recognised that some young people will establish financial independence from their parents before they turn 22 years—for example, because they have been supporting themselves through paid work. Additional criteria also apply, where the person's parents cannot exercise their responsibilities for certain reasons, where it is unreasonable to live at home (including due to conflict, lack of physical facilities, or chronic illness in the family), where the person is a member of a couple or has a child.

Incentives are in place that allow students on payment to earn more income without losing access to payments and benefits. Currently a student can earn up to $452 a fortnight before their student payment begins to reduce. A student aged 18-24 years, living away from home may be able to earn as much as $1,362.67 in a fortnight before their payment is reduced to nil. The student Income Bank also allows students to accumulate credits (capped at 11,300) against any unused portion of their fortnightly income free area which can be later used to offset any income above the threshold. The student income bank provides additional flexibility for students to take advantage of seasonal employment during semester breaks when their study load is reduced.
Thank you again for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston
Myanmar
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email, referred to Foreign Affairs on 16 December, regarding the petition EN2788 which calls for the channelling of humanitarian assistance to Myanmar through independent third parties. I apologise for the delay in responding.

As a longstanding supporter of Myanmar's democratic transition, the Australian Government is gravely concerned about the situation in Myanmar and we condemn the violence being perpetrated against its people. We have consistently called on the military regime to exercise restraint, refrain from violence, release all those arbitrarily detained and engage in dialogue. We remain seriously concerned about the ongoing human rights abuses being perpetrated by the military regime across Myanmar, including against the Rohingya, minorities and displaced persons.

Australia supports ASEAN's efforts to de-escalate the crisis in Myanmar as one element of our multi-faceted approach. Our contributions through the ASEAN Coordinating Centre for Humanitarian Assistance on disaster management (the AHA Centre) are in addition to our significant existing development and humanitarian assistance to Myanmar, which continues to be delivered outside regime systems. Australia is providing an estimated $95.5 million this year to support the people of Myanmar through our multilateral and NGO partners. Our partners have rigorous processes in place to ensure that funding is delivered appropriately and to intended beneficiaries. This is a fundamental condition of our engagement.

Australia's support to the AHA Centre includes the $5 million contribution announced on 25 April 2021, and the deployment of technical experts and PPE announced on 7 August 2021. These are tangible ways to support ASEAN efforts, while also ensuring that relief gets to where it is most needed. The AHA Centre is aware of Australia's policy position of not legitimising or providing direct benefit to the military regime, and the implementation arrangements for Australia's support to the AHA Centre will be consistent with this policy position. We are working closely with the AHA Centre to identify how Australia's assistance can best be utilised in partnership with NGOs and CSOs. We will continue to emphasise the importance of coordinating with other humanitarian actors to ensure effective delivery of humanitarian assistance.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne

Thank you for your letter of 23 August 2021 regarding a petition presented in the House of Representatives on 23 August 2021 EN2822. I apologise for the delay in responding to your letter.
The Australian Government has no intention to change the name of the Commonwealth of Australia.
