COVID-19: Income Support Payments
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN2837 on reinstating COVID-19 payments. Please accept my sincere apologies for the delay in responding to you. I have received a large number of emails and requests for information and have not been able to respond as quickly as I would like.

The Australian Government is committed to temporary, targeted and scalable support during the COVID-19 pandemic. The Coronavirus Supplement was introduced from 27 April 2020 to provide additional financial support to recipients of eligible income support payments, such as JobSeeker Payment, during the initial phase of COVID-19. The amount of the Supplement was adjusted to reflect gradually improving economic conditions before ceasing on 31 March 2021.

From 1 April 2021, the Government permanently increased the base rate of working age income support payments by $50 per fortnight, and permanently increased the income free area for JobSeeker Payment, Youth Allowance (other), and Parenting Payment Partnered to $150 per fortnight, allowing recipients to earn more each fortnight before their payment reduces. These changes aimed to get the balance right between providing support for people and incentives to work, as the nation moves away from relying on the emergency supports in place during 2020.

The Government introduced the COVID-19 Disaster Payment in June 2020 in response to the Delta lockdowns across the country. This payment provided up to $750 per week for individuals who lost hours of work and income due to a state or territory public health order that imposed restrictions on movement, such as a lockdown.

The COVID-19 Disaster Payment has ceased in all jurisdictions as each state and territory reached 80 per cent full vaccination of its population aged 16 years and older and lockdowns have ended. People who have not already returned to work following the end of the COVID-19 Disaster Payment may be eligible for support through the social security system until they to return to work.

The Pandemic Leave Disaster Payment remains in place to support people who are required to isolate or quarantine because they have COVID-19, are a close contact, or are caring for someone who has COVID-19 or is a close contact. The Pandemic Leave Disaster Payment provides up to $750 per seven-day isolation period and will remain available until 30 June 2022. This payment encourages workers to self-isolate and helps prevent the spread of COVID-19 by mitigating the financial hardship associated with being unable to attend work while isolating.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Australian Constitution
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter of 18 October 2021 regarding petition EN3040 seeking the removal of the terms 'his' and 'he' from the Constitution.
The Commonwealth Government is not currently proposing any changes to the Constitution in relation to the use of gendered language.

There is a longstanding rule of interpretation that, unless the contrary intention appears, words importing the masculine gender include females. That rule was expressly set out in British law as far back as 1850 by the Interpretation Act (Imp), and reflected in Commonwealth law by the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 until 1984, when it was updated to adopt gender-neutral language.
As the petition notes, a number of provisions in the Constitution use gendered language, including:
sections 3-5, 58, 62, 70, 126 (relating to the Governor-General)
sections 13, 15, 17-20, 33-38, 40, 42, 45, 46, 48 (relating to parliamentarians)
section 64 (relating to ministers)
section 72 (relating to judges)
section 84 (relating to public servants), and
section 117 (relating to residents of states).

The gendered language in section 72 was introduced by the Constitution Alteration (Retirement of Judges) 1977, after the appointment of the first woman to an Australian federal court, and did not restrict the appointment of High Court Justices to any one gender. Section 7 of the High Court of Australia Act 1979, which sets out the qualifications to be a Justice of the High Court, uses language that is consistent with that position.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Senator Cash
Cystic Fibrosis
Dear Chair,

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN3224 that was presented in the House by the Deputy Chair of the Standing Committee on Health, Aged Care and Sport, the Dr Mike Freelander MP. I note that the petition has 35,815 signatures and relates to the listing of Trikafta® (elexacaftor/tezacaftor/ivacaftor and ivacaftor) on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) for cystic fibrosis (CF).
I am aware of the distress and difficulties faced by people living with this debilitating condition and the ongoing concern felt by their families and friends.

The Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC)—an independent expert advisory body comprising doctors, other health professionals and consumer representatives—makes recommendations to the Australian Government about PBS listings. Under legislation, the Government cannot list a new medicine on the PBS unless the PBAC makes a recommendation in favour of its listing.

I have previously been delighted to announce a number of PBS listings that bring improved outcomes to many people with cystic fibrosis. Since 2014, the Government has invested over $1 billion in PBS subsidies to secure access to three modulator medicines listed on the PBS for the treatment of CF, namely: Kalydeco® (ivacaftor), Orkambi® (lumacaftor/ivacaftor) and Symdeko® (tezacaftor/ivacaftor).

At its July 2021 meeting, the PBAC recommended Trikafta® for the treatment of patients with CF aged 12 years and older who have one F508del mutation and one minimal function mutation in the CFTR gene (F/MF population), a patient population that does not current have access to PBS-subsidised treatment. However, the sponsor chose not to progress listing based on this recommendation, unfortunately delaying access to this treatment through the PBS.

The PBAC has recommended the PBS listing of Trikafta®, for the treatment of all patients with CF who are 12 years and older who have at least one F508del mutation on the CF transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene, at its December 2021 meeting.
If the company accepts the required terms, then the Government will be delighted to list this medicine as we have done with over 2,800 new and amended medicines to date.

I can confirm my Department is in advanced discussions with the company and subject to their final agreement I look forward to further announcements shortly. As has been the case with regards to Symdeko and Orkambi, this is a matter of deep personal passion.

The Medicine Status website enables you to search and monitor the status of medicines as they progress through the PBS listing process. The website is updated monthly and can be found at: www.pbs.gov.au/medicinestatus/home.html.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN3230 on support for workers and small business owners during lockdowns. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

Since the start of the pandemic, the Commonwealth Government has delivered more than $215 billion in direct economic and health support to Australian citizens including jointly funding around $14.6 billion in business support to more than 440,000 small- and medium-sized businesses between July and December 2021. The design and administration of the support payments, including the treatment of separate business locations, was the responsibility of each of the state and territory governments.

Recognising the ongoing challenges presented by Omicron, the Commonwealth continues to provide support for individuals who cannot earn an income while self-isolating, in quarantine, or caring for someone with COVID-19, through the $750 Pandemic Leave Disaster Payment. As of 9 February 2022, more than $698 million has been distributed to more than 790,000 people around Australia to support those that require time off work.

The SME Recovery Loan Scheme also continues to provide access to loans of up to $5 million for small- and medium-sized businesses who are dealing with the economic impacts of COVID-19 and economic support is still flowing through business tax incentives, such as through the Government's temporary full expensing policy, and infrastructure investments.

In accordance with the agreed National Plan to Reopening, the Commonwealth has ceased co-funding business support programs for each state as vaccination targets have been reached and as the economy recovers.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Housing Affordability
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN3249 on the home ownership impacts of foreign ownership of residential land; negative gearing; the supply of land; and regulation of the real estate industry. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The foreign investment review framework allows the Australian Government to consider Australia's national interest while ensuring Australia remains an attractive place to invest. If it is determined that a proposed investment is contrary to the national interest, it will not be approved or conditions will be applied to safeguard the national interest.

Since taking office, the Government has strengthened the rules around foreign investors owning Australian housing, including by introducing an annual charge on foreign owners who buy residential property and leave it vacant; placing a cap on foreign ownership in new developments; and tightening the foreign investor tax integrity rules to reduce avoidance of capital gains tax.

The Government has also enacted comprehensive reforms to the foreign investment review framework which came into effect from 1 January 2021. These reforms update the framework in three broad ways: address national security risks; strengthen the compliance regime foreign investors are subject to and the enforcement powers available to the Treasurer; and streamline investment in non-sensitive businesses.
Further information on the foreign investment review framework can be found on the Foreign Investment Review Board website at: www.firb.gov.au.

Under Australia's foreign investment review framework, foreign persons generally need to apply for foreign investment approval before acquiring any residential real estate in Australia. The Government's policy is to channel foreign investment into new dwellings, as opposed to established dwellings, as this creates additional jobs in the construction industry, bolsters Australia's housing stock, and supports economic growth. Foreign investment applications are therefore generally considered in light of the overarching principle that the proposed investment should increase Australia's housing stock.

Negative gearing is a long-standing feature of the tax system and is used by around 1.3 million Australians. Investors can deduct the costs of maintaining an investment property from their assessable income because it is a general principle of Australia's tax law that expenses incurred in the process of generating assessable income are deductable. This principle extends broadly throughout the tax system and isn't limited to investment properties. The latest available data indicates that, in 2018-19, around 63 per cent of individuals who negatively geared their investment properties had a taxable income less than or equal to $90,000. The Government has made several changes to improve the integrity of tax arrangements for residential investment properties and limit excesses. This includes disallowing deductions for travel expenses, limiting plant and equipment depreciation deductions to assets not previously used, and denying deductions for expenses related to holding vacant land.

span.span: Commonwealth action to support housing affordability and supply

p.span: The Government understands the importance of access to secure and affordable housing. While state, territory and local governments are primarily responsible for housing policy (including regulation of both the supply of land and the real estate industry), a number of Commonwealth measures support housing supply.

The Government's National Housing Finance and Investment Corporation (NHFIC) is designed to improve housing outcomes and support new housing supply in Australia. Through the Affordable Housing Bond Aggregator (AHBA), NHFIC provides cheaper, long-term finance for community housing providers (CHPs). Through the National Housing Infrastructure Facility (NHIF), NHFIC provides finance for critical infrastructure underpinning housing supply, particularly affordable housing. As at 20 October 2021, the NHFIC Board has approved over $2.7 billion of loans to CHPs under the AHBA, supporting over 14,000 new and existing homes; and over $320 million in NHIF transactions supporting the delivery of more than 6,700 new social, affordable and market dwellings.

In addition, the New Home Guarantee, which was temporarily expanded for a second year in 2021-22, provided an additional 10,000 guarantees in 2021-22 for first home buyers seeking to build a new home or purchase a newly built dwelling with a deposit of 5 per cent. The $2.7 billion HomeBuilder grant program was designed to support confidence and drive economic activity in the residential construction sector in response to the economic downturn caused by the COVID-19 pandemic.

These programs complement other measures the Government has taken to increase housing supply, including commitments as part of the City Deals program with state, territory and local governments. For example, both the Western Sydney City Deal and Hobart City Deal, include initiatives to support increasing the supply of social and affordable housing, including local government planning and zoning reforms. Further, the Australian Government Property Register enables all Australians to propose alternative uses for Commonwealth land. The Government has continued to progress announced divestments of a number of properties, some of which are likely to result in increased housing stock.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Electoral Communications
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your emails of 22 November 2021 concerning petitions about unsolicited political communications (EN3264—Minimum Conditions for Unsolicited Digital Messages, EN3288—Political Party Exemption from Spam Act 2003, EN3296—Make it an Offence for a Political Party or Politician "Using a Carriage Service to Menace, Harass or Cause Offence", EN3328—Stop the Exemption on Political Mobile Phone Messaging to Callers on the Do Not Call List and EN3329—Make Amendments to Spam Act to Include Political Parties).

Freedom of expression and freedom of political communication are vital concepts. They are only subject to limitations that are reasonable and necessary for our democratic society to achieve an appropriate balance between freedom of expression, and the protection of groups and individuals from offensive or harmful behaviour.
Any amendment to the legislative framework for unsolicited communications requires careful consideration and appropriate consultation to reduce the prospect of unintended consequences.
In particular, I note there are a number of Acts that are relevant to this matter.
The Spam Act 2003 regulates the sending of unsolicited commercial electronic messages that seek to offer, advertise, supply or promote goods, services, land or business or investment opportunities.

The Do Not Call Register Act 2006 prevents organisations calling a number for telemarketing if the number is on the Register. Telemarketing is any call where the caller is aiming to sell, advertise or promote goods and services.
Both of these Acts preserve freedom of political expression and do not prohibit political messages.

The Privacy Act 1988 contains an exemption for members of an Australian Parliament, local government councillors and registered political parties, and their volunteers and contractors, in relation to specified kinds of political acts and practices. This exemption is designed to encourage freedom of political communication and support the operation of the electoral and political process.

The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 (the Electoral Act) also does not constrain the manner in which electoral matter is communicated. Under that Act, 'electoral matter' is a matter communicated for the dominant purpose of influencing the way electors vote in a federal election. A communication that expressly promotes or opposes a candidate, political party, member or Senator is presumed to be for the dominant purpose of influencing the way electors vote.

The Electoral Act also includes provisions designed to ensure that voters who receive political text messages know who is communicating with them. The Electoral Act requires electoral communications to be authorised by the person responsible for the communication. Finally, the Australian Electoral Commission does not disclose the telephone numbers of electors.
Thank you for bringing the petitioners' concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Taiwan
Dear Chair
I refer to recent correspondence on Petition Number EN3283, regarding Taiwan.

Australia remains committed to our one-China policy. Further, the Australian Government does not take a position on Taiwan's future status or its diplomatic relationships—those are matters for the parties involved.

Australia supports a peaceful resolution of differences over Taiwan through dialogue and without the threat or use of force or coercion. Our national interests, including our economic recovery from COVID-19, are tied to the stability and prosperity of the Indo-Pacific. Stable and constructive cross-Strait relations remain key to this and serve the interests of all parties.

Australia affirms Taiwan's important role in the Indo-Pacific and is strengthening our unofficial ties with Taiwan, a leading democracy and critical partner. We continue to engage with Taiwan unofficially in practical ways that advance our interests and bolster Taiwan's resilience. This longstanding unofficial relationship is underpinned by robust economic and cultural links. Through the Australian Office in Taipei, we will continue to work with Taiwan to advance our trade and investment cooperation, education, science and research links, as well as our people-to-people links, which are strong and growing. We have also strongly supported Taiwan's practical participation in international organisations, including the World Health Organization.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Gambling
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 22 November 2021 regarding Petition EN3287, which relates to gambling promotions.

I note the petition requests the House of Representatives " ... to further restrict the capabilities for gambling companies to advertise their services online, on national television, billboards and radio etc."

The Morrison Government recognises the importance of gambling promotions being presented in a responsible manner. Advertising regulation in Australia is intended to strike a balance between legitimate commercial interests and appropriate community safeguards.

Most content broadcast in Australia is regulated by co-regulatory codes of practice developed by broadcasting industry sectors in accordance with the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. This co-regulatory system recognises the importance of ensuring that television and radio content reflects community standards. Codes of practice are available on the Australian Communications and Media Authority's (ACMA) website at acma.gov.au/industry-codes-practice.

span.span: ldren's viewing hours on broadcast platforms

p.span: The Commercial Television Industry Code of Practice prohibits gambling advertisements:
during General (G), Preschool (P) or Children's (C) rated programs broadcast between:
6.00 am and 8.30 am; and
4.00 pm and 7.00 pm; and
during any program that is broadcast between 5.00 am and 8.30 pm and that is principally directed at children.

These prohibitions do not apply to advertisements broadcast in news, current affairs or sports programs during those periods. These prohibitions also do not apply to advertisements relating to such things as government sanctioned lotteries, keno or competitions, or, generally, to advertisements for entertainment or dining facilities where gambling may take place.

The Subscription Broadcast Television Code of Practice requires broadcasters to take into account the intellectual and emotional maturity of the intended audience of the relevant channel when scheduling advertising relating to betting or gambling.

In 2018, further restrictions were applied to the showing of gambling promotions during live sporting events broadcast on commercial television, commercial radio, subscription television and the Special Broadcasting Service.

New rules also came into effect to restrict the showing of gambling promotions during online streams of live sporting events. The Broadcasting Services (Online Content Service Provider Rules) 2018 contain gambling promotions restrictions that are, to the extent possible, similar to those which broadcasting industry codes impose on the broadcast of live sporting events.
More information about these restrictions is available on ACMA's website.
TV and radio—acma.gov.au/gambling-ads-during-live-sports-broadcasts
Online platforms—acma.gov.au/gambling-ads-during-sport-streamed-over- internet.

Broadcasting industry codes of practice are periodically reviewed. Members of the public may contact the relevant peak industry body to raise their concerns, and to enquire about how they can contribute to future review processes. The relevant contact details are:
Free TV Australia
First Floor
44 Avenue Road
MOSMAN NSW 2088
freetv.com.au
Australian Subscription
Television and Radio
Association
admin@astra.org.au
astra.org.au
Commercial Radio Australia
Level 5, 88 Foveaux Street
Surry Hills NSW 2010
commercialradio.com.au

td.style: margin:0;padding:0;border:none;width:157.3pt ;
margin:0;padding:0;border:none;width:156.5pt ;
margin:0;padding:0;border:none;width:168.1pt ;

p.span: The content of advertisements, and placement of out-of-home (OOH) advertising such as billboards, are subject to predominantly self-regulatory arrangements. These self-regulatory arrangements reflect that it is ultimately advertisers who have primary responsibility for their advertisements and that content needs to reflect community standards and expectations.

Regulation for the content of advertisements is underpinned by codes of practice developed by the advertising industry peak body, the Australian Association of National Advertisers (AANA), and includes the AANA Code of Ethics and the AANA Wagering Advertising and Marketing Communication Code (AANA Wagering Code). Ad Standards administers the complaint resolution process and provides support for the independent Ad Standards Community Panel (the Panel).

The AANA Code of Ethics applies to most advertising published in Australia, and contains a range of provisions relating to taste and decency. This includes that advertising or marketing communication shall not depict material contrary to prevailing community standards on health and safety. The AANA Wagering Code includes a range of provisions related to the content of wagering advertising and marketing communications. The object of this code is to ensure that advertisers and marketers develop and maintain a high sense of social responsibility in advertising and marketing wagering products in Australia.
More information and copies of the codes can be found on the Ad Standards website at:
adstandards.com.au/issues/gambling-advertising.

The Outdoor Media Association (OMA) is the peak national industry body that represents operators who advertise across all OOH formats, including roadside, transport and retail. OMA has developed and administers the OMA Code of Ethics, a set of voluntary principles defining the OOH industry's community and environmental responsibilities, and the industry's standards for working with advertisers and regulators. For instance, the OMA Code of Ethics states that OMA members are committed to the responsible advertising of products and services aimed at audiences, and therefore will not display advertisements for wagering products within a 150 metre line of sight of a primary or secondary school.

Under the OMA Code of Ethics, OMA members support all decisions made by the Panel in relation to complaints about outdoor advertising and remove any content found in breach of the AANA codes of practice. In addition, OMA provides the Concept Advisory Service that assists advertisers to gauge their compliance with the codes of practice developed by the AANA.
Thank you for bringing the petitioners' concerns to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
HomeBuilder Grant
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN3293 and HomeBuilder.

HomeBuilder is a time-limited program designed to assist the residential construction sector by encouraging the commencement of new home builds and substantial renovations. On 29 November 2020, the Government announced that the HomeBuilder program was extended for all new build contracts signed between 1 January 2021 to 31 March 2021. Applications for HomeBuilder closed at midnight, Wednesday 14 April 2021, and this deadline will not be further extended. Unfortunately, applications cannot be submitted after this date.

The National Partnership Agreement (NPA) on HomeBuilder outlines the application eligibility criteria for the HomeBuilder program. In administering HomeBuilder on behalf of the Commonwealth, states and territories determine the evidentiary requirements to satisfy themselves that an applicant has met the criteria. The definition and assessment of an eligible contract is in the remit of each jurisdiction.

The states and territories have sole discretion to determine whether an application has been validly submitted by the deadline. Any questions about HomeBuilder applications should be referred to the relevant State Revenue Office.

In addition, the Commonwealth Government announced on 17 April 2021 that for all eligible contracts signed between 4 June 2020 and 31 March 2021 (inclusive), the construction commencement requirement would be extended from six months to 18 months.

The Government's decision to provide existing applicants with an additional 12 months to commence construction was taken in response to unanticipated delays in the construction industry caused by supply and labour constraints including delays in global supply chains, the impact of COVID-19 lockdowns and natural disasters.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar

Eating Disorders
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning petition EN3380—federal funding for the establishment of more eating disorder services in South Australia. I regret the delay in responding.

I am sorry to learn of the difficulties people with eating disorders are facing gaining access to appropriate specialised treatment services in South Australia. I recognise the enormous mental and emotional toll an eating disorder has on individuals and their family and carers.

Assisting people with an eating disorder and their families to access appropriate supports and services is an issue of national importance for the Australian Government. This ongoing commitment is demonstrated by the substantial investment we have made in eating disorder treatment services over recent years. These investments include:

Increasing the accessibility and affordability of eating disorder treatments in the community setting by introducing specific Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) items for eating disorders, enabling up to 40 psychology and 20 dietetic treatment sessions per year for those eligible for an Eating Disorder Treatment and Management Plan ($110.7 million).

Establishing new community-based residential eating disorder treatment centres across Australia, filling a critical gap in eating disorder treatments, sitting between hospital and community programs ($63 million). This included $5 million to the South Australian Government to establish a residential eating disorder treatment centre at the Repat Hospital Precinct.
Operation of Butterfly Foundation's National Helpline, ED Hope ($9.5 million). The helpline provides supports for those concerned about eating disorders or body image issues and their loved ones.

Developing brief intervention training for staff at Head to Health and headspace Centres ($1.9 million), to enhance the capacity of community-based mental health services to identify and treat eating disorders. The InsideOut Institute has commenced delivering eating disorder interventions through headspace centres.

Establishing a National Eating Disorder Research Centre ($13.0 million), to progress key eating disorder research priorities relating to prevention, and early identification and intervention. This will be operated by the InsideOut Institute from 2022.
Supporting Eating Disorders Families Australia's 'strive' program ($0.4 million), providing education, learning and peer support to parents, carers and families of people with eating disorders.

These significant investments represent the Government's commitment to providing more accessible, timely and affordable services for those struggling with eating disorders, while also investing in ongoing policy and research to allow earlier and more effective intervention and treatment.

Specialised eating disorder services are a shared responsibility with state and territory governments. While the Australian Government has invested significantly in boosting the availability of community-based care, state and territory governments are responsible for public hospital systems including planning and delivering clinically necessary inpatient and outpatient services. Decisions concerning the provision of treatment for eating disorders delivered through public hospitals, including those provided by the Statewide Eating Disorder Service, rests with the South Australian Government. If it has not been done so already, you may wish to contact the South Australian Minister for Health and Wellbeing, the Hon Stephen Wade MLC, about the issues raised.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Australian Defence Force
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 22 November 2021 concerning Petition EN3407 which requests 2 Squadron, Special Air Service Regiment (SASR) be restored to the Australian Army's Order of Battle.
I would like to acknowledge the individuals who have signed this petition and their support of the Australian Defence Force and SASR.

The Inspector-General of the Australian Defence Force Afghanistan Inquiry report, released November 2020, made 191 findings and 143 recommendations. Defence accepted the Inspector-General's findings and is addressing the recommendations.

In November 2020, the Chief of Army directed that 2 Squadron SASR was to be removed from the Army Order of Battle. In September 2021, it was announced the command and control arrangements for the SASR were being strengthened. The command of SASR has been elevated to a Colonel (06) position from a Lieutenant Colonel (05) position to ensure sufficient capacity and appropriate oversight for the complex missions SASR is expected to perform in the future.

Members of SASR continue to work incredibly hard to prepare for the demanding, sensitive and important role they are employed to undertake, and they have my full support as Minister. The focus now is on the strategic challenges facing our country into the future.
I trust this information is of assistance to the petitioners of EN3407.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Dutton
Teachers
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 November 2021 to the Minister for Education and Youth, regarding Petition number EN3408. As the acting Minister for Education and Youth, your correspondence has been provided to me for reply. In response to the issues raised in the petition, I can provide the following advice.

Quality teaching is key to improving school education in Australia. One of the Australian Government's top priorities for the Education and Youth portfolio is to ensure that every student who trains to become a teacher is equipped with the toolkit they need to be highly impactful in the classroom.

The Government knows that teachers are the single largest in-school driver of student achievement, and that enhancing the capability of teachers is vital to raising the overall quality of Australia's school system and lifting student outcomes. Improving quality teaching in Australian schools must begin when teachers are first prepared for the profession. The test is just one aspect of the system aimed at ensuring the quality of initial teacher education (ITE).

For all teachers, no matter the year level or subjects they teach, strong personal literacy and numeracy skills form an essential part of the attributes and skills needed to be effective in the classroom. While personal literacy and numeracy skills are only one element of what makes a good teacher, they are critical to fostering the development of strong personal literacy and numeracy in students.

The requirement that all ITE students possess personal literacy and numeracy skills broadly equivalent to the top 30 per cent of the Australian adult population has been in place since 2011, when all Education Ministers agreed to introduce the Accreditation of Initial Teacher Education Programs in Australia: Standards and Procedures (Standards and Procedures). Education Ministers subsequently agreed that, from 1 July 2016, the test would be used as the nationally consistent means for future teachers to demonstrate they have achieved this existing standard for their profession.

Under the Standards and Procedures, higher education providers have a key role in supporting their students with the test. To meet standard 3.5 under the Standards and Procedures, as implemented by State and Territory teacher regulatory authorities, higher education providers must ensure entrants to ITE possess levels of personal literacy and numeracy broadly equivalent to the top 30 per cent of the Australian adult population. Providers that select students who do not meet this requirement upon entry into the program must establish satisfactory arrangements to ensure that these students are supported to achieve the required standard before graduation.

In response to the petitioners' requests, there can be no exemptions to the requirement that future teachers pass the test in order to graduate and begin teaching. This has been agreed by all Education Ministers and is in line with community expectations for our teaching workforce.

It is regrettable that students who have invested their time and effort in attempting the test are unable to pass. To this end, in December 2020, all Education Ministers agreed that, from 2023, students who are planning to enrol in an ITE course will have the option to sit the test before they commence their studies. This decision is intended to offer more certainty and fairness to students before they decide to invest time and resources in pursuing a teaching career. This will also give higher education providers the opportunity to provide targeted assistance to students who need additional support to meet the required standard.
Yours sincerely
from the Acting Minister for Education and Youth, Mr Robert
Australia Post
Dear Chair

Thank you for your letter dated 22 November 2021 concerning Petition EN3424 (the Petition) requesting an investigation into the services provided by Australia Post on the basis of concerns raised regarding delays experienced in parcel delivery, unsatisfactory customer service, and alleged breaches of the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989 (Cth) (the Act) and Australian Consumer Law.

Australia Post is an independent Government Business Enterprise, both legally and financially separate from the Australian Government. Therefore, I have sought advice from Australia Post on this matter.

Australia Post's advice indicates that lockdowns, limited air freight capacity and COVID-19 related impacts on the workforce all impacted operations in late 2021. Record parcel volumes, up 27.1 per cent from last year, were also experienced. During the extended lockdowns in Australia's most populous states, Australia Post was also impacted by temporary facility closures and having more than 1,500 members of its workforce in necessary self-isolation on any given day in accordance with state regulations.

Australia Post has advised that they sought to recruit up to 5,000 additional staff ahead of Christmas 2021, introduced new and pop-up processing facilities, continued the suspension of their express post service guarantee, and twice temporarily suspended collections from ecommerce providers to minimise backlogs. Tracking on all parcels was also provided to customers and Australia Post regularly provided public advice about delays on their website and in the media.

On the question of Australia Post's legislative obligations, Australia Post is required to meet the standards set out in the Australian Postal Corporation (Performance Standards) Regulations 2019 (the Regulations), including for letter delivery speed and frequency. Performance against the prescribed performance standards is subject to independent audit by the Australian National Audit Office. As summarised in the 2020-21 Annual Report (available at www.auspost.com.au), Australia Post met or exceeded all of the Prescribed Performance Standards in 2020-21, taking account of the temporary regulatory relief in place throughout financial year 2020-21.

The provision of parcel services in Australia is not subject to Australian Consumer Law and is open to consumer choice and competition. Consumers are free to choose a provider of these services that best meet their needs. Notwithstanding this, Australia Post has advised that they are continuing to improve their operations to ensure they continue to meet customer expectations, including a $1 billion investment in new facilities over the next three years.

The Australian Government has also established the Postal Industry Ombudsman (PIO) as a free, independent and impartial body to help resolve concerns about the performance of postal services in Australia. In 2020-21, the PIO received 3,656 complaints from over two billion items delivered by Australia Post. Further information about the PIO can be found on their website:
https://www.ombudsman.gov.au/How-we-can-help/postal-industry-ombudsman.
Thank you for bringing these concerns to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Gambling
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 22 November 2021 regarding Petition EN3434, which relates to gambling promotions.
I note the petition requests the House of Representatives " ... to take steps to restrict the number and viewing time of television advertisements promoting gambling."

The Morrison Government recognises the importance of gambling promotions being presented in a responsible manner. Advertising regulation in Australia is intended to strike a balance between legitimate commercial interests and appropriate community safeguards.

Most content broadcast in Australia is regulated by co-regulatory codes of practice developed by broadcasting industry sectors in accordance with the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. This co-regulatory system recognises the importance of ensuring that television and radio content reflects community standards. Codes of practice are available on the Australian Communications and Media Authority's (ACMA) website at acma.gov.au/industry-codes-practice.

Broadcast television requirements in relation to gambling promotions generally relate to the content or scheduling of advertisements, rather than volume. However, there are hourly limits for advertising in general, which apply to commercial free-to-air and subscription television and are set out in the relevant codes of practice.

span.span: Gambling advertising restrictions during children's viewing hours on broadcast platf

p.span: The Commercial Television Industry Code of Practice prohibits gambling advertisements:
during General (G), Preschool (P) or Children's (C) rated programs broadcast between:
6.00 am and 8.30 am; and
4.00 pm and 7.00 pm; and
during any program that is broadcast between 5.00 am and 8.30 pm and that is principally directed at children.

These prohibitions do not apply to advertisements broadcast in news, current affairs or sports programs during those periods. These prohibitions also do not apply to advertisements relating to such things as government sanctioned lotteries, keno or competitions, or, generally, to advertisements for entertainment or dining facilities where gambling may take place.

The Subscription Broadcast Television Code of Practice requires relevant licensees to take into account the intellectual and emotional maturity of the intended audience of the relevant channel when scheduling advertising relating to betting or gambling.

In 2018, further restrictions were applied to the showing of gambling promotions during live sporting events broadcast on commercial television, commercial radio, subscription television and the Special Broadcasting Service.

New rules also came into effect to restrict the showing of gambling promotions during online streams of live sporting events. The Broadcasting Services (Online Content Service Provider Rules) 2018 contain gambling promotions restrictions that are, to the extent possible, similar to those which broadcasting industry codes impose on the broadcast of live sporting events.
More information about these restrictions is available on ACMA's website.
TV and radio—acma.gov.au/gambling-ads-during-live-sports-broadcasts
Online platforms—acma.gov.au/gambling-ads-during-sport-streamed-over- internet

Broadcasting industry codes of practice are periodically reviewed. Members of the public may contact the relevant peak industry body to raise their concerns, and to enquire about how they can contribute to future review processes. The relevant contact details are:
Free TV Australia First Floor
44 Avenue Road
MOSMAN NSW 2088
freetv.com.au
Australian Subscription Television and Radio Association
admin@astra.org.au astra.org.au

margin:0;padding:0;border:none;width:177.15pt ;

p.span: Thank you for bringing the petitioners' concerns to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
HomeBuilder Grant
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN3435 and HomeBuilder.

HomeBuilder is a time-limited program designed to assist the residential construction sector by encouraging the commencement of new home builds and substantial renovations. On 29 November 2020, the Government announced that the HomeBuilder program was extended for all new build contracts signed between 1 January 2021 to 31 March 2021. Applications for HomeBuilder closed at midnight, Wednesday 14 April 2021, and this deadline will not be further extended. Unfortunately, applications cannot be submitted after this date.

The National Partnership Agreement (NPA) on HomeBuilder outlines the application eligibility criteria for the HomeBuilder program. In administering HomeBuilder on behalf of the Commonwealth, states and territories determine the evidentiary requirements to satisfy themselves that an applicant has met the criteria. The definition and assessment of an eligible contract is in the remit of each jurisdiction.

The states and territories have sole discretion to determine whether an application has been validly submitted by the deadline. Any questions about HomeBuilder applications should be referred to the relevant State Revenue Office.

In addition, the Commonwealth Government announced on 17 April 2021 that for all eligible contracts signed between 4 June 2020 and 31 March 2021 (inclusive), the construction commencement requirement would be extended from six months to 18 months.

The Government's decision to provide existing applicants with an additional 12 months to commence construction was taken in response to unanticipated delays in the construction industry caused by supply and labour constraints including delays in global supply chains, the impact of COVID-19 lockdowns and natural disasters.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Media
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email dated 22 November 2021 regarding petition EN3438, which relates to media content.
I note the petition requests the House of Representatives to " ... please consider putting a ban on all accident pictures for 48 hours by all media."

Where media services are regulated in Australia, the regulatory framework they are subject to depends on the platform on which they are provided. Under these frameworks, industry plays a leading role in the development and administration of content regulation.
Print and online news publications in Australia, such as newspapers, predominantly operate under self-regulatory arrangements whereby media standards reflect community expectations.

The Australian Press Council (APC) is the self-regulatory body with responsibility for promoting high standards of media practice and administering the complaints process for most major Australian newspapers, magazines and associated digital outlets, as well as some independent online-only news services. The Independent Media Council (IMC) is the self-regulation body and complaints administrator for most other major print and online news publishers in Australia.

Both the APC and IMC set content standards for their respective publications. The APC's Standards of Practice, including the Statement of General Principles requires relevant publications to, among other things, avoid causing or contributing materially to substantial offence, distress or prejudice, or a substantial risk to health or safety, unless doing so is sufficiently in the public interest. The Statement of General Principles is available at presscouncil.org.au/standards/statement-of-principles.
The IMC Code of Conduct, which incorporates the Seven West Media Print and Online Publications Privacy Policy, provides, among other things, that:

images of dead or seriously wounded people which may seriously distress or seriously offend a substantial number of readers should be displayed only when there is an identifiable public interest reason for doing so; and
reasonable steps must be taken to ensure that murder or accident victims are not identified directly or, where practicable, indirectly before their immediate families are notified by the authorities.
The Code of Conduct is available at www.independentmediacouncil.com.au.

Both the APC and IMC have complaints processes for their respective associated publications, with information on the process available at their respective websites, presscouncil.org.au/complaints and independentmediacouncil.com.au. If a member of the public's concerns relate to material published by news publications that are not subject to either the APC or the IMC's regulatory arrangements, they should raise their concerns directly with the publication.

Most media content broadcast on commercial and subscription television and radio in Australia is regulated by co-regulatory codes of practice developed by broadcasting industry sectors in accordance with the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. These co-regulatory arrangements recognise the importance of broadcast content being in line with community expectations. Codes of practice are available on the Australian Communication and Media Authority's (ACMA's) website at: acma.gov.au/industry-codes-practice.

The Commercial Television Industry Code of Practice (the Commercial TV Code) contains provisions relating to news and current affairs, and material that may cause distress to viewers. It includes the requirement to provide warnings before distressing material is broadcast and to not show certain content unless it is in the public interest. Specifically in relation to images, broadcasters are required to:
exercise sensitivity in broadcasting images of, or interviews with, bereaved relatives or people who have witnessed or survived a traumatic incident; and
have regard to the feelings of relatives and viewers when including images of dead bodies or people who are seriously wounded, taking into account the relevant public interest.

The Subscription Broadcast Television Codes of Practice contains similar provisions relating to the broadcasting of distressing material during news and current affairs programs. In relation to images, subscription broadcasters must exercise sensitivity in broadcasting images of or interviews with bereaved relatives and survivors or witnesses of traumatic incidents.

Broadcasting co-regulatory codes of practice are periodically reviewed. Members of the public may contact the relevant peak industry body to raise their concerns and to enquire about how they can contribute to future review processes.
For commercial television broadcasters, Free TV Australia can be contacted at freetv.com.au/contact-us.
For subscription television broadcasters, the Australian Subscription Television and Radio Association can be contacted via admin@astra.org.au.

The ABC Code of Practice provides that the reporting of or depiction of violence, tragedy or trauma must be handled with extreme sensitivity and to avoid causing undue distress to victims, witnesses or bereaved relatives. Editorial decisions are guided by the ABC's editorial policy on Harm and Offence.

The SES Code of Practice provides that material that is likely to cause harm and offence must be justified by context, and that adequate protective measures be provided. In the case of news and current affairs, publishing of this content is based on the editorial relevance of the material, including public interest and regard for the likely audience.
Information about how to complain about the content viewed on television, including news programs, is available on ACMA's website at acma.gov.au/complain-about-program-tv-or-radio.
Thank you for bringing the petitioners' concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Myanmar
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email regarding the petition EN3443 calling on the Australian Government to impose targeted economic sanctions on Myanmar and military leaders.

As a longstanding supporter of Myanmar's democratic transition, the Australian Government shares the concerns of the signatories of the petition and we condemn the violence being perpetrated by the military regime against the people of Myanmar. We have consistently called on the military regime to exercise restraint, refrain from violence, release all those arbitrarily detained and engage in dialogue. We remain seriously concerned about the ongoing human rights abuses being perpetrated by the military regime across Myanmar, including against the Rohingya, minorities and displaced persons.

Australia has made clear our concerns directly to the regime, in ministerial and embassy statements, and in multilateral fora such as the Human Rights Council and the UN General Assembly. Since the coup, I have discussed with a wide range of counterparts how best the international community can support a de-escalation of the situation in Myanmar and constructively work towards a resolution.

Australia provides extensive humanitarian and development assistance to support the basic needs of crisis-affected people in Myanmar, including food, water, healthcare, shelter, livelihoods, education and gender-based violence services. On 27 October I announced $4.5 million for the Access to Health Fund delivered through the UN Office for Project Services, which will be used to procure emergency supplies, provide medical treatment and support COVID-19 prevention and control measures. The Australian Government has redirected development assistance away from regime-controlled entities and is focused on supporting the people of Myanmar. We do not provide any funding directly to the Myanmar regime.

Australia's autonomous sanctions regime already includes a longstanding arms embargo against Myanmar, as well as targeted sanctions against five individuals responsible for atrocities committed in Rakhine State. Australia's framework for targeted sanctions does not currently allow for the listing of Myanmar entities. I continue to keep our sanctions regime under active consideration, and further sanctions have not been ruled out.

Australia continues to support calls for a global arms embargo. We are working bilaterally, multilaterally in the UN General Assembly and Human Rights Council, and with likeminded partners to encourage those countries that persist in providing arms and enabling materiel to Myanmar to cease doing so. On 26 November, Australia issued a joint statement with the governments of Canada, New Zealand, Norway, the Republic of Korea, the United Kingdom and the United States that called on the international community to suspend all operational support to the Myanmar military and cease the transfer of arms, material, dual-use equipment, and technical assistance to the military and its representatives.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Child Obesity
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email dated 22 November 2021 regarding Petition EN3449, which relates to the representation of children in advertising content.

The content of advertisements in Australia is subject to predominantly self-regulatory arrangements, underpinned by codes of practice developed by the advertising industry peak body, the Australian Association of National Advertisers (AANA), including the AANA Code of Ethics (the Code).

Ad Standards administers the complaint resolution process for the advertising self-regulatory framework. Relevant codes of practice are available on the Ad Standards website at adstandards.com.au/codes-and-cases/Codes.

The Code requires, among other things, that advertising shall not depict material contrary to prevailing community standards on health and safety. The practice notes accompanying the Code include guidance on body image and that advertising should not portray an ideal or unrealistic body image. The practice notes also advise that the Code does not require the use of 'healthy weight' models, as this could unnecessarily limit the portrayal of diversity in society.

Further information about the advertising content self-regulatory arrangements is available at adstandards.com.au/about/self-regulation and information about specific advertising issues, including health and safety, is available at
adstandards.com.au/issues.
Ad Standards can also be contacted at:
PO Box 5110
Braddon ACT 2612
Thank you for bringing the petitioners' concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
National Disability Insurance Scheme
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 November 2021 regarding House of Representatives Petition EN3450, requesting improved National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) accessibility for people with complex psychosocial disabilities with particular reference to Forgotten Australians. The delay in response is regretted.

The Australian Government delivered a National Apology to the Forgotten Australians and Former Child Migrants at a special remembrance event in Canberra on 16 November 2009. The Apology recognised that many Forgotten Australians and Former Child Migrants continue to face a range of complex issues, including mental and physical illness, homelessness, substance abuse, educational and family relationship difficulties, as a result of their experiences in out-of-home care.

Following the Apology, the Australian Government announced initial funding of $26.5 million over 4 years for Find and Connect services. Funding for the Find and Connect Support Services was renewed to extend services for 5 years to from I July 2021 to 30 June 2026.

The Find and Connect Support Services provide specialist trauma informed counselling, referral services, peer support, education and social support programs. Services also provide assistance to locate and access records and reconnect with family members (where possible) for Forgotten Australians and Former Child Migrants.

The Australian Government worked collaboratively with Find and Connect Support Services and organisations representing Forgotten Australians, Former Child Migrants and Care Leavers, state and territory governments, records specialists and non-government records holders to provide the service delivery model for Find and Connect.

The NDIS is an insurance-based scheme that provides eligible Australians under the age of 65, who have a permanent and significant disability, with reasonable and necessary supports to pursue their goals. These goals may include greater independence, community involvement, employment and improved wellbeing.

As an insurance scheme, the NDIS takes a lifetime approach, investing in people with disability early to improve their outcomes later in life. The NDIS also provides people with disability, their family and carers with information and referrals to existing support services in the community.

Improving the responsiveness of the NDIS for people with psychosocial disability is a key focus of the Australian Government. The NDIA wants all people with psychosocial disability in the NDIS to be supported in their personal recovery and to live a life that has meaning for them.

The NDIA and the Department of Social Services are working in conjunction with state and territory governments, Mental Health Australia and other stakeholder groups to improve the delivery of the NDIS for people with psychosocial disability, and improve their long term outcomes.

Improvements to the Scheme include the introduction of psychosocial recovery coaches, plan flexibility to respond to the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic and a stronger focus on psychosocial recovery. In addition, the Agency is working to improve linkages and referrals to mainstream supports with clinical mental health services. This will provide an improved service systems response for people with severe and enduring psychosocial disability.
The Government is committed to providing services for Forgotten Australians such as Find and Connect and the NDIS and thanks you for your referral of this petition.
I trust this information is of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme, Senator Reynolds
Denmark
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 November 2021 to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator the Hon Marise Payne, concerning Petition EN3477 on the hunt of whales and dolphins in the Faroe Islands. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for the Environment, as the matters raised fall within my portfolio responsibilities. I apologise for the delay in responding.

I am very disappointed that the September 2021 traditional hunt of Atlantic white-sided dolphins in the Faroe Islands resulted in an unexpectedly large catch. The Australian Government is committed to the protection of cetaceans and I welcome the announcement by the Faroese Government of a public review of the regulations surrounding the dolphin hunt. I am hopeful this leads to greater protection for these wonderful animals.

Denmark (the Faroe Islands) is one of several countries that undertakes aboriginal subsistence whaling with the oversight of international agreements including the International Whaling Commission (IWC) and the North Atlantic Marine Mammal Commission. Aboriginal whaling allows First Nations communities to meet their traditional, cultural and dietary needs. The government recognises this practise as distinct from commercial whaling which the government strongly opposes.
Australia welcomes Denmark's cooperation with the IWC and has no plans to suspend trade.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to the government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment, Ms Ley
Eating Disorders
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence concerning petition EN3482—increased federal funding for specialised eating disorder programs and treatments. I regret the delay in responding.

I recognise the enormous mental and emotional toll an eating disorder has on sufferers, and their families and carers. I am also very conscious of the increasing number of eating disorder presentations observed throughout the COVID-19 pandemic. Whilst assisting people with an eating disorder and their families to access appropriate supports and services is an issue of national importance for the Australian Government, specialised eating disorder services are a shared responsibility with state and territory governments.

The Government has significantly increased funding for specialised eating disorder services. Since 2018-19, the Government has committed an additional $225 million to provide support for people with eating disorders and their families, building on existing investments to continue to improve eating disorder treatment and services nationally. These significant reforms include:

Increasing the accessibility and affordability of eating disorder treatments in the community setting by introducing specific Medicare Benefits Schedule items for eating disorders, enabling up to 40 psychology and 20 dietetic treatment sessions per year for those eligible for an Eating Disorder Treatment and Management Plan ($110.7 million).

Establishing new community-based residential eating disorder treatment centres across Australia, filling a critical gap in eating disorder treatments, sitting between hospital and community programs ($63 million). The first of these centres, Wandi Nerida, opened on the Sunshine Coast in June 2021. States and territories are responsible for the construction and operation of the Centres.

National coordination roles for the Butterfly Foundation and the National Eating Disorder Collaboration to build an effective, equitable and accessible system of care for all Australians ($8.1 million).
Operation of Butterfly Foundation's National Helpline, ED Hope ($9.5 million). The helpline provides supports for those concerned about eating disorders or body image issues and their loved ones.

Developing an eating disorders workforce clinical credential ($2.8 million), which aims to increase the eating disorder workforce by 600 health professionals. Applications from health professionals to be credentialled have commenced. Consumers will be able to identify these appropriately trained and experienced clinicians from May 2022.

Developing brief intervention training for staff at Head to Health and headspace Centres ($1.9 million), to enhance the capacity of community-based mental health services to identify and treat eating disorders. The InsideOut Institute has commenced delivering eating disorder interventions through headspace centres.

Translation of eating disorder evidence into clinical practice by the InsideOut Institute ($4.0 million). 7,500 places have been funded in the InsideOut Institute's Essentials training and the Australian Eating Disorder Research and Translation Strategy 2021-31 has been launched, providing a roadmap to establishing eating disorders as a national research priority.

Establishing a National Eating Disorder Research Centre ($13.0 million), to progress key eating disorder research priorities relating to prevention, and early identification and intervention. This will be operated by the InsideOut Institute from 2022.
Supporting Eating Disorders Families Australia's 'strive' program ($0.4 million), providing education, learning and peer support to parents, carers and families of people with eating disorders.

These significant investments represent the Government's commitment to providing more accessible, timely and affordable services for those struggling with eating disorders, while also investing in ongoing policy and research to allow earlier and more effective intervention and treatment.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Australian Defence Force
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 29 November 2021, regarding Petition Number EN3509 concerning the medical and fitness standards for entry into the Australian Defence Force (ADF). I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

Defence's mission is to defend Australia and its national interests in order to advance Australia's security and prosperity. This requires Defence to maintain an operationally capable military force with high levels of fitness, commitment and discipline.

The prescribed level of health and physical fitness is a fundamental requirement for entry and retention in the ADF. The nature of military service can require all members to be called upon to perform operational service, often at short notice. All serving ADF members are required to carry out both the duties of their primary occupation and also the duties of general service. This is the case in times of both peace and war, under austere field conditions, in a range of challenging climates, and often with medical and dental support that may be rudimentary and cannot be specially tailored to an individual's needs.

To be able to fulfil their duties, ADF members are required to undertake, to varying degrees, arduous training during initial entry courses and throughout their career. Those who cannot meet the required health and physical fitness standards may not be able to perform their duties safely in a deployed or operational setting, placing themselves and others at risk, to the extent that an operation or mission may be compromised.

Defence has an integrated workforce of ADF members, Australian Public Service employees and contracted personnel all supporting the Defence mission. While I appreciate the intent of Petition EN3509, I am cautious of potential impacts that may compromise the operational capability of our ADF. I admire and respect anyone who wishes to serve our county, and I encourage them to do so in any capacity that they can.
Thank you for bringing the petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Dutton
Assange, Mr Julian
Dear Chair
Thank you for your letter regarding petition EN3512 on Mr Julian Assange.

Australia will continue to respect the UK legal process, including any further appeals under UK law. It is for Mr Assange to decide how to respond to the recent High Court decision. Australia is not a party to the case.

We are monitoring Mr Assange's case closely, as we do for other Australians detained and subject to court proceedings overseas. We continue to offer Mr Assange consular assistance, and to seek his consent to discuss his health situation with prison officials. Mr Assange has not responded to our offers.

I have raised the situation of Mr Assange with US and UK counterparts, including to state the Australian Government's expectations that Mr Assange will be afforded due process, humane and fair treatment, access to proper medical and other care, and access to his legal team.
The Australian Government will continue to convery these expectations.
I trust this informations is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
HomeBuilder Grant
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN3643 and HomeBuilder. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

HomeBuilder is a time-limited program designed to assist the residential construction sector by encouraging the commencement of new home builds and substantial renovations. On 29 November 2020, the Australian Government announced that the HomeBuilder program was extended for all new build contracts signed between 1 January 2021 to 31 March 2021. Applications for HomeBuilder closed at midnight, Wednesday 14 April 2021, and this deadline will not be further extended. Unfortunately, applications cannot be submitted after this date.

The National Partnership Agreement (NPA) on HomeBuilder outlines the application eligibility criteria for the HomeBuilder program. In administering HomeBuilder on behalf of the Commonwealth, states and territories determine the evidentiary requirements to satisfy themselves that an applicant has met the criteria. The definition and assessment of an eligible contract is in the remit of each jurisdiction.

The states and territories have sole discretion to determine whether an application has been validly submitted by the deadline. Any questions about HomeBuilder applications should be referred to the relevant State Revenue Office.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Housing Affordability
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN3772.

The Australian Government understands the importance of access to secure and affordable housing. While state and territory governments are primarily responsible for housing and homelessness policy, the Commonwealth Government expects to provide $9 billion in 2021-22 to assist with improving housing outcomes for all Australians. The Government's National Housing Finance and Investment Corporation is designed to improve housing outcomes in Australia through several of its programs. The Government's Home Guarantee Scheme—comprising the First Home Loan Deposit Scheme, New Home Guarantee and Family Home Guarantee—has already supported more than 50,000 Australians to enter the housing market sooner.

Australia's foreign investment framework is open and welcoming, as it needs to be to support Australia's economic development. At the same time, the Government recognises that foreign investment must be in our national interest. Since taking office, the Government has strengthened the rules around foreign investors owning Australian housing, including by introducing an annual charge on foreign owners who buy residential property and leave it vacant; placing a cap on foreign ownership in new developments; and tightening the foreign investor tax integrity rules to reduce avoidance of capital gains tax.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
HomeBuilder Grant
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN3810 and HomeBuilder. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

HomeBuilder is a time-limited program designed to assist the residential construction sector by encouraging the commencement of new home builds and substantial renovations. On 29 November 2020, the Australian Government announced that the HomeBuilder program was extended for all new build contracts signed between 1 January 2021 to 31 March 2021. Applications for HomeBuilder closed at midnight, Wednesday 14 April 2021, and this deadline will not be further extended. Unfortunately, applications cannot be submitted after this date.

The National Partnership Agreement (NPA) on HomeBuilder outlines the application eligibility criteria for the HomeBuilder program. In administering HomeBuilder on behalf of the Commonwealth, states and territories determine the evidentiary requirements to satisfy themselves that an applicant has met the criteria. The definition and assessment of an eligible contract is in the remit of each jurisdiction.

The states and territories have sole discretion to determine whether an application has been validly submitted by the deadline. Any questions about HomeBuilder applications should be referred to the relevant State Revenue Office.

In addition, the Commonwealth Government announced on 17 April 2021 that for all eligible contracts signed between 4 June 2020 and 31 March 2021 (inclusive), the construction commencement requirement would be extended from six months to 18 months.

The Government's decision to provide existing applicants with an additional 12 months to commence construction was taken in response to unanticipated delays in the construction industry caused by supply and labour constraints including delays in global supply chains, the impact of COVID-19 lockdowns and natural disasters.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Mental Health
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence enclosing Petition PN0426 concerning mental health care and services in rural and remote Australia. I regret the delay in responding.

I appreciate you presenting a petition on this important issue. Mental health and suicide prevention continues to be one of the Australian Government's highest priorities and a central feature of its long-term National Health Plan. In line with its vision for stronger rural health outcome, the Government is committed to closing mental health care gaps in rural and remote Australia.

I note the petition calls for the development of a National Rural and Remote Mental Health Strategy (Strategy). I am pleased to confirm that the Government is committed to delivering a Strategy, as recommended by the Senate Standing Committee inquiry into the accessibility and quality of mental health services in rural and remote Australia.
The Strategy will provide a framework that informs and underpins ongoing reform and investment towards improving the mental health outcomes of Australians living across rural and remote Australia.

The Strategy will build on significant reform and investment recently announced under the Government's $2.3 billion National Mental Health and Suicide Prevention Plan. This new investment is on top of the Australian Government's estimated $5.8 billion investment in mental health and suicide prevention in 2020-21, including significant investment in response to the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic and the 2019-20 summer bushfires.

The National Mental Health and Suicide Prevention Plan includes funding to improve access to mental health and suicide prevention services for people in rural and remote areas. The Government recognises communities themselves are best placed to determine local needs including through regional services commissioned by Primary Health Network, increased access to telehealth psychology and a range of digital mental health services.

The Government is also addressing workforce shortages in rural and remote areas through the $550 million Stronger Rural Health Strategy, providing doctors more opportunities to train and practice in rural and remote Australia, and nurses and allied health professionals, a greater role in primary health care.
In addition, the Government is progressing a National Mental Health Workforce Strategy that will consider the quality, supply, distribution, and structure of the mental health workforce.
This work will identify practical approaches governments could implement to attract, train and retain the workforce required to meet consumer demand, across all parts of Australia.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Tibet
Dear Chair

Thank you for your letter of 17 January 2022, regarding petition EN1855, presented to the House of Representatives on 9 November 2020, calling for Australian Government recognition of the Central Tibetan Administration as the Government of Tibet.

The Australian Government remains deeply concerned about the human rights situation in Tibet. In particular, we are concerned about the detention of Tibetans for the peaceful expression of political views, restrictions on travel and China's policies on Tibetan cultural rights and heritage.

In September 2021, I joined the Minister for Defence Peter Dutton and our United States' counterparts, Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Secretary of Defence Lloyd Austin, in expressing our deep concern about the human rights situation in Tibet, in a Joint Statement following Australia-US Ministerial Consultations (AUSMIN).

In June 2021, Australia was one of 45 countries to join a statement on human rights in China at the UN Human Rights Council, which raised concerns about human rights in Tibet. DFAT officials also regularly raise the Government's concerns about the treatment of Tibetans with Chinese officials in Canberra and Beijing.

Australia recognises that Tibet is a part of China. This was implicit when Australia recognised the People's Republic of China in 1972 and this position conforms to that of the wider international community. For this reason, Australia does not recognise the Central Tibetan Administration, but Australians, including individual members of the Australia Parliament, State and Territory governments and parliamentarians are free to meet with the Central Tibetan Administration representatives in a private and unofficial capacity.

Australia supports direct talks between the Chinese Government, the Central Tibetan Administration and the Dalai Lama. We urge China to engage in constructive dialogue, with the aim of addressing the causes of frustration in Tibetan communities. Australia continues to call for official visits by foreign governments and parliaments to Tibet.
Australia will continue to raise our concerns, both publicly and directly with China, on this important issue.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Dear Chair
Thank you for your letters of 17 January 2022, regarding petitions EN1900 and EN1898, on the tragic sinking of Gulf Livestock 1 on 2 September 2020.

Tragically, the two Australians on board the vessel, Lukas Orda and William Mainprize, remain missing. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) continues to provide consular assistance to their families.

Under international agreements, Japan is responsible for leading and coordinating searches in its search and rescue region. We trust the professionalism of Japan's efforts since 2 September 2020 to locate any further trace of Gulf Livestock 1.

The Prime Minister and I have discussed these efforts personally with our Japanese counterparts, and our Embassy remains in touch with Japan's Coast Guard for any further news. On 11 September 2020, Australia provided a standing offer to assist the search effort.
