Australia has also registered its interest in the formal investigation of the incident, led by Panama, the vessel's flag state.

I recognise that this has been a harrowing time for the family and friends of the missing. My thoughts are with them. I assure you that the DFAT is providing assistance to the Australian families and will continue to do so.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
China: Human Rights
Dear Chair
Thank you for your letter regarding petition EN1914, presented to the House of Representatives, which expressed concerns about the treatment of Uyghur Muslims in Xinjiang, China.

The Australian Government holds grave concerns about credible reports of severe human rights violations against Uyghurs and other Muslim ethnic minorities in Xinjiang. These include reports of restrictions on freedom of religion, pervasive mass surveillance, large-scale extra-judicial detentions, forced labour and forced birth control, including sterilisation.

The Government consistently raises concerns both directly with China and in international forums, including by joining statements in the UN Human Rights Council (UNHCR) and UN General Assembly (UNGA). Australia was one of 43 countries to support a joint statement on Xinjiang at UNGA on 21 October 2021.

As I told the UNHRC on 2 March 2022, Australia welcomed the High Commissioner's undertaking in the Council's 48th Session to publicly release her Office's assessment on the allegations of egregious human rights violations in the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region. Publication of this material as soon as possible is vital, given the lack of transparency from China surrounding these extremely serious abuses. We continue to call for China to allow urgent and meaningful access to Xinjiang for independent observers, including the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights.

Australia's Special Envoy to the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation (OIC), Ridwaan Jadwat, has also discussed our concerns with OIC members. Australia will continue to raise the treatment of Uighur and other Muslim ethnic minorities in Xinjiang in a principled and consistent manner.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Donations To Political Parties
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence dated 18 January 2022 referring petition EN1919 on political donations. I apologise for my delay in responding to you.

Australia has a longstanding history of conducting free and fair elections which ensures Australians enjoy the freedom to engage in democratic discourse that is consistent with the implied freedom of political communication under the Australian Constitution.

Participation in this process includes Australians financially supporting candidates and political parties of their choice through political donations. The Government supports the right of all Australian individuals and organisations to freely participate in Australian elections.

The Government is committed to maintaining a robust electoral system and does this through legislative reform to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918. The reforms contained in the Electoral Legislation Amendment (Electoral Funding and Disclosure Reform) Act 2018 introduced a Transparency Register to Australia's electoral framework. The register contains information about political parties, candidates and other participants in the electoral process who are registered with, or recognised by, the Australian Electoral Commission. The register is publically available at https://transparency.aec.gov.au. This transparency register is a key part in assuring that political parties and candidates who receive donations are subject to, and accountable to, public scrutiny.

More recently, the Government has passed a number of legislative reforms to enhance transparency and access to information regarding political finance. The Electoral Legislation Amendment (Political Campaigners) Act 2021 ensures consistency in funding disclosure requirements for entities that are seeking to influence an election, bringing them into line with the same strong disclosure standards that apply political parties. The Electoral Legislation Amendment (Annual Disclosure Equality) Act 2021 also increases transparency by tightening the loopholes that allow candidates, particularly independents, to avoid electoral donation disclosure, and ensures all parliamentarians, submit annual returns when they receive electoral donations personally. I trust that this information is helpful. Australians can be assured that there are robust safeguards in place to require greater transparency from political actors seeking to influence voters.

I note that following each federal election, it is customary for the Parliament to establish a Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. The Committee is appointed to inquire into and report on such matters relating to electoral laws and practices and their administration. I invite the signatories to this petition to observe the conduct of the upcoming federal election and the operation of the new legislation and provide suggestions for improvement and further reform to the Committee for consideration and recommendation to the 47th Parliament.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Special Minister of State, Mr Morton

subdebateinfo.title: Aged Care, National Disability Insurance Scheme

p.span: Aged Care
National Disability Insurance Scheme
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your correspondence of 30 November 2020, regarding petition EN1976—funding of the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS). I apologise for the delay in responding.

As the Minister for the NDIS, I am proud of the many achievements of the NDIS in improving the lives of Australians living with permanent disabilities. The NDIS is a world-first social insurance scheme that delivers funding for disability supports to eligible persons, known as participants, with permanent disabilities. The NDIS heralded a significant change to the way people with disability are supported in Australia as it takes, at its core, an individualised and rights-based approach to disability support, empowering participants with true choice and control in accessing support.

Since commencing in 2013, the NDIS has grown rapidly and now supports over 500,000 participants, of which about 50 per cent of participants are receiving disability supports for the first time. Prior to the NDIS, combined Commonwealth and state and territory funding for services to support people with disability was around $7.9 billion. The 2021-22 Commonwealth Budget estimates provide $26.5 billion for the NDIS in this financial year.

In regards to how the NDIS is funded, the NDIS was designed to provide access to nationally consistent funding to help participants realise their aspirations, and to participate in the social and economic life of the community. As an insurance scheme, the NDIS takes a lifetime approach, investing in people with disability early to improve their outcomes later in life. The NDIS provides people with a permanent and significant disability with the reasonable and necessary supports they need to live an ordinary life. It is not means tested and provides its participants with funding for supports to help them live an ordinary life.

Importantly, the level of funding attributed to participants for their supports is individualised according to each person's reasonable and necessary needs. There is no minimum or maximum 'cap' on the level of funding a participant can receive. Rather, a participant will receive an NDIS plan developed upon assessment of what supports are considered reasonable and necessary given a person's level of functional capacity and their current access to formal and informal supports. This individualised approach is crucial to the scheme, as the NDIS does not provide income support, which is the responsibility of the separate social security system.
I appreciate you bringing this matter to my attention and I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme, Senator Reynolds
Child Support Scheme
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for referring petition EN2402 to me on 17 January 2022.

The Australian Government acknowledges that family breakdowns are incredibly difficult. The Child Support Scheme is in place to ensure that, as far as possible, children affected by a family breakdown remain financially secure until they reach 18 years of age, regardless of the custody arrangements in place. The Child Support Scheme facilitates the assessment and collection of child support between parents.
The petitioner may be interested in the following information.

The Australian Government has zero tolerance for domestic, family and sexual violence. All forms of violence in our community is unacceptable, and everyone, regardless of gender, has the right to live free from harm and without fear of violence or abuse.

The National Plan to Reduce Violence against Women and their Children 2010-2022 (National Plan) is Australia's overarching strategy to address domestic, family and sexual violence. The Australian Government, in conjunction with state and territory governments, is leading the development of the next National Plan, which will take effect from mid-2022 when the current plan ends. The next National Plan will be the national blueprint for change and will set out our collective ambitions for ending all forms of ending gender-based violence in Australia over the next 10 years.

The Australian Government has committed over $2 billion dollars to contribute 'towards a zero target' to end family and domestic violence. The focus is on prevention, financial support, creating a safe on line space, working with perpetrators, support for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and other diverse groups, children experiencing violence and building a strong evidence base.

Under this investment are a range of activities that support any person needing assistance either as they experience family, domestic or sexual violence, or they are seeking support to address family or relationship issues.

In the 2021-22 Budget, the Australian Government announced $144.8 million in funding for a 2-year trial of the Escaping Violence Payment. The Escaping Violence Payment will assist eligible individuals to access financial assistance to establish a home free from violence.

The financial assistance provided through the Escaping Violence Payment includes up to $5,000, with up to $1,500 in financial support and the remaining funds provided in goods, services and supports. The assistance may be used to pay bills, cover relocation expenses, furnishings, legal services and counselling.

To be eligible for the Escaping Violence Payment, individuals must be an Australian Citizen or permanent resident, aged 18 years or older, experiencing financial stress and be the victim of family and domestic violence that has resulted in a changed living arrangement.

The Escaping Violence Payment is delivered Australia-wide by UnitingCare Network. Individuals seeking further information or to apply for the Escaping Violence Payment, can contact UnitingCare Network in person or through
www.unitingvictas.org.au/escaping-violence-payment.

Also, through the Keeping Women Safe in their Homes (KWSITH) initiative, the Australian Government funds state and territory governments and select non-government providers to deliver services to improve the safety of women and their children who have experienced family and domestic violence. Since 2015, the Australian Government has committed $34.6 million for KWSITH.

The KWSITH initiative supports women and their children to stay in their own home, or a home of their choice, where it is safe and appropriate to do so through a range of safety responses such as risk assessments, safety planning, home security audits and upgrades, and case management.

Where a parent has concerns around family violence, Services Australia will take particular care to manage the case in a sensitive and appropriate manner. This can include allocating a Personalised Services Service Officer to support the parent, and adopting strategies in consultation with the parent to reduce the likelihood of family violence and provide safety for them and their children.

Once Services Australia registers a registrable maintenance liability (child support case) for collection, the amounts payable are debts due to the Commonwealth by the payer and the debt is enforceable by Services Australia.

Services Australia actively engages with all paying parents to ensure on time and in full payments. Employer withholding is the default method of collection and is set up when child support payments become collectable by the agency, unless the paying parent requests an exemption. Parents can make manual payments, however, if payments are not received in full and on time, employer withholding or garnishee notices may be used to enforce payment of child support and arrears. Services Australia takes action when a first child support payment is missed. A Child Support Service Officer will attempt to contact the parent, undertake searches to identify enforcement avenues, and send collection notices to third parties.

Child support arrears are legally recoverable and are collected by administrative and court enforcement (which is always given careful consideration prior to action being undertaken). Services Australia's compliance approach balances education, support, advice and enforcement activities. Services Australia takes all necessary action at the first opportunity to recover child support arrears, regardless of the size or age of the parent's arrears balance.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Minister for Women's Safety, Senator Ruston
Pensions and Benefits
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for referring petition EN2464 to me on 17 January 2022.

Australia's social security system is a non-contributory system designed to support the basic living standards of all Australians and increase their social and economic participation. Pensions are funded by taxpayers and targeted through the means test to those who need them most. They are designed to provide income support to people who, for reasons such as age, unemployment or ill health, are unable to support themselves.

Pensions are designed to acknowledge that some people face additional barriers such as age, disability or caring responsibilities that make it difficult for them to support themselves or supplement their income through paid employment. Pensions are paid at the highest legislated rate of income support in the social security system because recipients are not expected to work to support themselves.

On 20 September 2021, the maximum total pension rate for single pensioners increased by $14.80 to $967.50 a fortnight or $25,155 a year. The maximum rate for pensioner couples combined increased by $22.40 to $1,458.60 a fortnight or $37,923.60 a year. Under social security law, base pension rates are indexed twice a year to ensure they keep up with increases in the cost of living. Pension rates will continue to be reviewed twice a year, as set out in legislation. They will next be indexed on 20 March 2022.

In addition to their main payment, pensioners can receive a range of benefits and concessions that increase their economic security, including Commonwealth Rent Assistance, subsidised prescription medicines under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, subsidised health care and related products, and subsidised aged care.
As part of the Government's economic response to the COVID-19 pandemic, each eligible pensioner also received a total of $2,000 through four Economic Support Payments.
Thank you again for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Senator Ruston
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence concerning petition number EN2901 calling for the House of Representatives to remove the mandatory COVID-19 vaccination requirements for aged care workers. I apologise for the delay in responding.

Senior Australians are among the most vulnerable to severe outcomes ofCOVID-19. COVID-19 vaccines protect aged care workers, and older Australians in their care, from severe disease, hospitalisation and death from COVID-19.

Following the recommendations of the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee endorsed by National Cabinet, jurisdictions have implemented public health orders setting mandatory COVID-19 vaccine requirements for residential, in-home and community aged care workers, with limited exemptions.

State and territory public health orders or directions have been used throughout the pandemic as they can be implemented quickly, have a high degree of flexibility to deal with differences in the overall legal frameworks within jurisdictions and also come with a wide range of powers for use by local authorities.

Each jurisdiction has human rights, equal opportunity or anti-discrimination commissions. Complaints about acts done by state or territory governments or under state or territory legislation may be considered by those state and territory commissions. Generally, it is the remit of state and territory human rights, equal opportunity or anti-discrimination commissions to scrutinise measures enacted by state and territory governments.

The Australian Human Rights Commission has information about COVID-19 and human rights, accessible by contacting 1300 369 711 from 9:00am to 5:00pm AEST, via email at: infoservice@humanrights.gov.au or webform at:
humanrights.gov.au/about/contact.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Commonwealth Electoral Act
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email dated 18 October 2021 referring Petition EN3038 on preferential voting. I apologise for my delay in responding to you.
Australia has a longstanding history of conducting safe and fair elections, and the Government is committed to the integrity of our electoral process.

The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 has provided for full preferential voting in the Australian House of Representatives since 1918. Full preferential voting, as applied in Australian federal elections, requires a candidate to build an absolute majority of support in an electorate, rather than the simple majority required in jurisdictions using a first-past-the-post method.

In 2016, Australia's federal voting system was reformed to address flaws in the Senate voting system, with the passage of the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill 2016. This reform placed the control of preference allocation back into the hands of the voter, by allowing the voter to select and preference the parties and candidates that best represent the voter's interests. The voting system thus no longer facilitates the exchange of preferences between parties or candidates, but rather leaves the voter in full control of determining which party or candidate will get their vote.
Looking towards the upcoming 2022 federal election, the Government has no plans to remove preferential voting from Australia's electoral legislation.

Historically, changes to Australia's electoral system have occurred based on inquiries by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. Citizens are encouraged to engage with the Committee regarding electoral matters. Further information on the Committee is available at:
www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Joint/Electoral_Matters.
Thank you for bringing the matters referred to in this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Special Minister of State, Mr Morton
Commonwealth Electoral Act
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email of 18 October 2021 referring petition number EN3126 on preferential voting. I apologise for my delay in responding to you.
Australia has a longstanding history of conducting safe and fair elections, and the Government is committed to the integrity of our electoral process.

The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 has provided for full preferential voting in the Australian House of Representatives since 1918. Full preferential voting, as applied in Australian federal elections, requires a candidate to build an absolute majority of support in an electorate, rather than the simple majority required in jurisdictions using a first-past-the-post method.

In 2016, Australia's federal voting system was reformed to address flaws in the Senate voting system, with the passage of the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill 2016. This reform placed the control of preference allocation back into the hands of the voter, by allowing the voter to select and preference the parties and candidates that best represent the voter's interests. The voting system thus no longer facilitates the exchange of preferences between parties or candidates, but rather leaves the voter in full control of determining which party or candidate will get their vote.
Looking towards the upcoming 2022 federal election, the Government has no plans to remove preferential voting from Australia's electoral legislation.

Historically, changes to Australia's electoral system have occurred based on inquiries by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. Citizens are encouraged to engage with the Committee regarding electoral matters. Further information on the Committee is available at:
www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Joint/Electoral_Matters.
Thank you for bringing the matters referred to in this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Special Minister of State, Mr Morton
National Disability Insurance Scheme
Dear Mr O'Dowd

I refer to your email of 18 October 2021 concerning petition EN3215 to the House of Representatives to allow attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), anxiety and oppositional defiant disorder (ODD) to be included in the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS).

I would like to assure you that all people with disability are able to access the NDIS if they meet the requirements set out in the National Disability Insurance Scheme Act 2013 (NDIS Act), including age, residency and disability or early intervention requirements. Generally, a person will be eligible for the NDIS if their disability is, or is likely to be, permanent and significantly affects their communication, social interaction, learning, mobility, self-care or self-management.

Access to supports under the NDIS is not based on types of disability or on the presence of an underlying condition, illness or injury. People with ADHD, anxiety and ODD can become NDIS participants if they meet requirements set out in the NDIS Act, including providing evidence of the functional impact of their disability on activities of daily living. However, not all people with ADHD, anxiety or ODD will meet the requirements in the NDIS Act to be a participant.

While not all children with these conditions may be eligible participants of the NDIS, they may access general supports through the NDIS early childhood approach. This approach connects children and their families and carers with initial supports and short-term early intervention programs. This approach is open to all children under the age of 7 with developmental delay (including developmental concerns) or disability, their families and carers. Through Early Childhood Partners around Australia, the approach assists families to navigate available local community supports and develop the skills they need to support their child.
In addition, the Australian Government provides a range of services and supports, outside the NDIS. These include:
playgroups to provide play opportunities to suit the interests, strengths and needs of the child, while supporting parents and carers;
workshops to provide free, flexible and tailored support for parents and carers to better support their children and learn new coping skills; and
networks to provide free, evidence-based, online information, resources and advice for parents and carers in a variety of formats, including the web-based Carer and Disability Gateways.

Local Area Coordination services funded through the National Disability Insurance Agency are available to children who are over the age of 5 and live with disability or developmental delays to connect them to community and local services.

I note the petitioners' concerns about the supports provided to children living with ADHD, anxiety and ODD in schools and other settings. By law, schools are required to ensure equal access for students with disability as specified under the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 and the Disability Standards for Education 2005 (the Standards). This requirement exists regardless of whether the child with disability is a participant of the NDIS.

The Standards give students with disability rights in relation to specialised services needed for them to participate in the educational activities for which they are enrolled. These services include specialist expertise, personal educational support or support for personal and medical care. State and territory education systems are responsible for making the reasonable educational adjustments required in schools as a result of a child's disability. Schools receive funding to support the needs of students with disability from the Commonwealth, state and territory governments and parental contributions (where the child is enrolled in a non-government school).
I appreciate you bringing this matter to my attention and trust this information clarifies the matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme, Senator Reynolds
Media
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN3485, originally directed to the Treasurer. The Petition seeks the designation of Facebook under the News Media and Digital Platforms Mandatory Bargaining Code. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Code came into force on 3 March 2021. It is intended to ensure that digital platforms fairly compensate news businesses for the content they use, thereby assisting the sustainability of the Australian news sector.

The Code does this primarily by creating incentives for commercial deals to be reached between the digital platforms -particularly Google and Facebook- and news businesses outside of the Code. To facilitate this, it provides a framework for good faith negotiations and mediation between the parties, backed by a fair and balanced arbitration process, to resolve outstanding disputes.
The Australian Government welcomes the deals that have been struck to date between digital platforms and a wide range of large, small and regional news businesses.
To ensure the Code is meeting its objectives, a review of the Code commenced on 28 February 2022. It will report to the Government in September 2022.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Climate Change
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 8 February 2022 to the Minister for Industry, Energy and Emissions Reduction, the Hon Angus Taylor MP, concerning petition number EN3499 on the Duty of Care to Australian Children and Extraction and Burning of Coal. Your correspondence has been referred to me as it falls under my responsibilities as the Minister for the Environment.

My approval of any coal mine follows a rigorous assessment of the potential impacts on matters of national environmental significance and all other relevant considerations under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to the Australian Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment, Ms Ley
Broadband
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your letter of 29 November 2021, concerning House of Representatives Petition EN3518. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government has rolled out the National Broadband Network (NBN) to deliver affordable high-speed broadband to all Australian homes and businesses. The NBN is now complete apart from connections to a small number of complex premises. NBN Co Limited (NBN Co) is completing the build for these complex connections as quickly as possible. Build activities for new developments will be an ongoing activity for the company.

NBN Co completed the initial network build within the funding envelope of $51 billion, made up of $29.5 billion Commonwealth equity contribution, $19.5 billion Commonwealth loan (totalling $49 billion of funding from the Commonwealth), and $2 billion of private debt.

The network is designed to provide access to peak wholesale download speeds of at least 25 megabits per second (Mbps) to all premises and at least 50 Mbps to 90 per cent of fixed-line premises. NBN Co is implementing plans so the majority of premises will be able to access wholesale speeds of up to 1 Gigabit per second (Gbps) by 2023.

NBN Co, has rolled out the network using the technology best suited to each area of Australia. The multi-technology mix approach to the rollout allowed NBN Co to deploy the network in a technology-agnostic fashion, with decisions about the rollout based on the most cost-effective and time-efficient approach. This meant that when the COVID pandemic hit, the network was effectively complete and able to support households.

Regional and remote communities across Australia are benefiting from access to affordable high-speed broadband. Outside of major urban areas, NBN Co has deployed fixed-line broadband to around 73 per cent of premises, with the remainder served by fixed wireless or satellite technology.
In its 2022 Corporate Plan, NBN Co reported that the network is supporting 50 Mbps download speeds to 90.45 per cent of the fixed-line footprint and 25 Mbps to 98.55 per cent of all premises.

In some areas, the NBN can only operate at full power once legacy services are migrated off the Telstra copper network. During the first eighteen month migration period, other telcos can still operate legacy broadband services (such as ADSL services) over NBN infrastructure. To minimise interference, NBN operates with reduced power and speed. NBN Co services can be configured for optimal speeds once these legacy services have migrated and this will result in increased speeds for impacted premises.

It will be part of NBN Co's ongoing operations that the company will continue to invest in network capacity, extend the network to new developments and remediate technical issues as they arise. NBN Co has committed to a range of investments totalling $4.5 billion which include a $3.5 billion upgrade of the network so that 75% of premises will be able to access services of up to 1 Gigabit per second on demand; $700 million to extend ultra-fast connectivity to 90 per cent of all Australian business locations at no upfront cost, including through establishing 297 Business Fibre Zones nationwide; and a $300 million fund to co-invest with state, territory and local governments in projects to improve broadband services in rural and regional communities.

As part of this investment, NBN Co is extending fibre deeper into some Fibre to the Node (FTTN) areas to provide the option of higher speeds as customer demand emerges over the next few years. Premises connected to the NBN via FTTN technology that require higher speeds will be able to access higher wholesale speed tiers via Fibre to the Premises (FTTP) technology. This will be done by using existing fibre infrastructure already built to nodes and investing in the continued rollout of fibre deeper into neighbourhoods. Customers living or working in these areas will be able to place an order with any participating internet provider for a higher speed NBN Home Fast, Home Superfast or Home Ultrafast broadband plan. At that point, NBN Co will complete the fibre lead-in to the premises. More information about NBN Co's Corporate Plan is available on NBN Co's website at
www.nbnco.com.au/blog/the-nbn-project/evolving-the-nbn-network-to-meet-future-demand.

NBN Co is focussed on completing network construction to premises that are not yet 'ready to connect', and provide progress updates in its publicly available quarterly reporting. NBN Co's website provides information on expected build completion dates for remaining premises and the company is carefully managing and tracking completion for these areas and individual premises.
NBN Co is accountable to the Government and to the Australian community for managing the network on a commercial basis in line with the Government's Statement of Expectations, available at
www.nbnco.com.au/content/dam/nbn/documents/about-nbn/policies/soe-shareholder-minister-letter-2021.pdf.
The company is expected to maximise the economic and social benefits of the network and make appropriate investments to meet the current and future needs of Australians, wherever they live.
Thank you for bringing these concerns to my attention. I hope the information in this letter is of some help.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Urban Infrastructure, Cities and the Arts, Mr Fletcher
Media
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN3530, originally directed to the Treasurer. The Petition seeks the designation of digital platforms under the News Media and Digital Platforms Mandatory Bargaining Code. Your correspondence has been referred to me for response.

The Code came into force on 3 March 2021. It is intended to ensure that digital platforms fairly compensate news businesses for the content they use, thereby assisting the sustainability of the Australian news sector.

The Code does this primarily by creating incentives for commercial deals to be reached between the digital platforms- particularly Google and Facebook- and news businesses outside of the Code. To facilitate this, it provides a framework for good faith negotiations and mediation between the parties, backed by a fair and balanced arbitration process, to resolve outstanding disputes.
The Australian Government welcomes the deals that have been struck to date between digital platforms and a wide range of large, small and regional news businesses.
To ensure the Code is meeting its objectives, a review of the Code commenced on 28 February 2022. It will report to the Government in September 2022.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, Mr Sukkar
Australian Defence Force
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 14 February 2022 concerning Petition EN3556 which requests 2 Squadron, Special Air Service Regiment (SASR) be restored to the Australian Army's Order of Battle.
I would like to acknowledge the individuals who have signed this petition and their support of the Australian Defence Force and SASR.

The Inspector-General of the Australian Defence Force Afghanistan Inquiry report, released November 2020, made 191 findings and 143 recommendations. Defence accepted the Inspector-General's findings and is addressing the recommendations.

In November 2020, the Chief of Army directed that 2 Squadron SASR was to be removed from the Army Order of Battle. In September 2021, it was announced the command and control arrangements for the SASR were being strengthened. The command of SASR has been elevated to a Colonel (06) position from a Lieutenant Colonel (05) position to ensure sufficient capacity and appropriate oversight for the complex missions SASR is expected to perform in the future.

Members of SASR continue to work incredibly hard to prepare for the demanding, sensitive and important role they are employed to undertake, and they have my full support as Minister. The focus now is on the strategic challenges facing our country into the future.
I trust this information is of assistance to the petitioners of EN3556.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Defence, Mr Dutton
Health Care
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 14 February 2022 concerning Petition EN3575 seeking 'that the House repeal the Health Legislation Amendment (Information Sharing) Bill 2021 or allow alternative protection of personal data'.
I note that this petition refers to a Victorian State Government Bill, and I therefore cannot respond to the petition's concerns.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Elections
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your letter dated 14 February 2022 regarding petition EN3592 which concerns the implement or method for voters to mark their ballot papers at federal electoral events. I am responding as the Special Minister of State with responsibility for electoral matters.

The petition proposes that the House of Representatives ban all carbon/graphite pencils from voting booths in favour of indelible or ink-based pens; and that if a vote is received that has been marked by a carbon/graphite pencil that vote be judged as invalid and not be included in the count.
Section 206 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 (Electoral Act) requires that each polling booth voting compartment must have an implement or method for voters to mark their ballot papers.

The Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) provides pencils for federal elections for a number of reasons. Pencils are the most reliable implements for marking ballot papers. Pencils are practical because they do not run out and the polling staff check and sharpen pencils as necessary throughout election day. Pencils can be stored between elections, and they work better in tropical areas. Sharp pencils deliver clear, consistent numbers free of smudging, which is a requirement when scanning Senate ballot papers.
There is, however, nothing to prevent an elector from marking their ballot paper with a pen if they so wish.
There is no evidence that any votes marked in pencil compromise the integrity of an election. All electoral processes are transparent and open to scrutineers appointed by candidates.

The AEC is an independent and politically neutral statutory authority, with all employees required to declare that they will act in an impartial manner. The Government, and the Australian people, can have confidence in the AEC's continued ability to delivery free, fair and efficient electoral events.
Thank you for bringing the petitioners' concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Special Minister of State, Mr Morton
COVID-19: International Travel
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your representation of 14 February 2022 enclosing Petition EN3612 with 16 signatures, concerning international travel for all visa holders.

As of 21 February 2022, all fully vaccinated visa holders, including those with a visitor visa, will be able to enter Australia without a travel exemption. This further re-opening of our international border will ensure we protect the health of Australians, while we continue to secure our economic recovery.

The Australian Border Force Commissioner's travel exemption system will remain in place for unvaccinated travellers. Visa holders who are not fully vaccinated will still require a valid travel exemption to enter Australia, and will be subject to state and territory quarantine requirements.
The most up-to-date announcements and information on who can travel to Australia, and the requirements that apply can be found at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3612 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
COVID-19: Migration
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 14 February 2022 to the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon Alex Hawke MP, enclosing Petition EN3633 with 1203 signatures, seeking inclusion of adult children of Australian citizens and permanent residents as immediate family for the purpose of an automatic exemption from Australia's travel restrictions. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for Home Affairs as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

As of 21 February 2022, all fully vaccinated visa holders, including those with a visitor visa, will be able to enter Australia without a travel exemption. This further re-opening of our international border will ensure we protect the health of Australians, while we continue to secure our economic recovery.

The Australian Border Force Commissioner's travel exemption system will remain in place for unvaccinated travellers. Visa holders who are not fully vaccinated will still require a valid travel exemption to enter Australia, and will be subject to state and territory quarantine requirements.
The most up-to-date announcements and information on who can travel to Australia, and the requirements that apply can be found at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3633 to the Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
Education
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 14 February 2022 to the Minister for Education and Youth, regarding Petition number EN3639. As the Acting Minister for Education and Youth, your correspondence has been provided to me for reply. In response to the issues raised in the Petition, I can provide the following advice.

span.span: The Australian Curriculum's requirements for students to develop 21st century skills

p.span: The Australian Curriculum (the curriculum) sets out requirements to ensure Australian students have a skill set that prepares them for the future, beyond traditional discipline knowledge. The curriculum prepares students to have personal and social skills as well as skills in critical and creative thinking, effective communication, information and communication technology and working collaboratively and in teams.

The curriculum includes eight learning areas, seven general capabilities and three cross-curriculum priorities. The general capability of Critical and Creative Thinking plays a significant role in the curriculum in equipping young Australians to live and work successfully in the 21st century. Through this capability, which is embedded in all learning areas, students learn to generate and evaluate knowledge, clarify concepts and ideas, seek possibilities, consider alternatives and solve problems. Students are asked to develop 21st century skills as they think broadly and deeply, and make use of logic, resourcefulness, imagination and innovation in all learning areas at school.

In 2015, Education Ministers agreed regular reviews of the curriculum would occur every six years. The last review was in 2014. In June 2020, the Education Council agreed to the terms of reference for the current review to refine, realign and declutter the content of the curriculum and to ensure the curriculum remains current and continues to meet the needs of students.

In undertaking the review, the Australian Curriculum, Assessment and Reporting Authority (ACARA), the organisation responsible for the administration of the curriculum, ran a public consultation between April and July 2021 on a new draft of the curriculum. It was the first time the curriculum had been made available for public consultation and the public interest demonstrated the importance of what our students learn.

Education Ministers met on 4 February 2022 to consider the revised curriculum. At that meeting, while acknowledging the significant improvements made to the curriculum, the Australian Government and the Western Australian Government requested ACARA undertake further work on the Mathematics and Humanities and Social Sciences curricula. All Education Ministers requested further work on the mental health aspects of Health and Physical Education curriculum.
The revised version of the curriculum will be presented to Education Ministers in April 2022 and, if endorsed, it will be ready for implementation from 2023.

span.span: and Territories and the Australian Government

p.span: While the Australian Government plays a national leadership role in school education, State and Territory Governments and non-government education authorities and individual schools are responsible for the day-to-day delivery of education programs and the curriculum, taking into account their context and community needs.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Acting Minister for Education and Youth, Mr Robert
Ethiopia
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email regarding Petition Number EN3650 on the conflict in Ethiopia.

Australia is gravely concerned by the conflict in Ethiopia, and the dire humanitarian situation this has created for many Ethiopians. I have made my concerns known on numerous occasions and called on the Tigray People's Liberation Front and the Ethiopian Government to immediately end hostilities and reach a negotiated solution.

Australia has repeatedly raised concerns about human rights abuses and violations in Ethiopia, in a range of international fora. The findings of the Office of the United Nations (UN) High Commissioner for Human Rights—Ethiopian Human Rights Commission joint investigation into alleged human rights abuses in Tigray were deeply troubling. All parties to the conflict were implicated. It is essential that those responsible are held to account for their actions and justice is restored to those who have lost access to it.

To this end, Australia co-sponsored a resolution at the 17 December 2021Special Session of the UN Human Rights Council on Ethiopia, establishing an International Commission of Experts to investigate and report on human rights abuses during the conflict. This includes human rights abuses in Afar and Amhara regions. Australia has called on all parties to the conflict to work with the Commission of Experts to ensure all human rights violations and abuses are documented and perpertrators are held to account.

Australia is also responding to the humanitarian situation in northern Ethiopia. In the past 12 months we have provided $3 million to the World Food Programme to respond to food insecurity and $3 million to the International Committee of the Red Cross to help address the needs of the most vulnerable, including supporting survivors of sexual violence. We also provided $118,000 to the International Planned Parenthood Federation to deliver sexual and reproductive health services to Ethiopian refugees in Sudan. Australia has also deployed humanitarian specialists to key UN agencies in Ethiopia to assist with the humanitarian response. We has joined with others in the international community in calling for rapid, unimpeded and sustained humanitarian access to those in need.

Australia will continue to raise concerns regarding the conflict in Ethiopia, and also closely monitor the work of the Commission of Experts, including their oral update and written report due later this year.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Agriculture
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 14 February 2022 concerning petition EN3657 requesting the Australian Government cease all support of animal production industries, and that taxpayers should be offered the choice of 'opting-out' of taxes that support animal industries.
I recognise that the topic of animal production can be highly emotive for some people. The government takes the welfare of all animals seriously and is committed to strong animal welfare outcomes.

Agriculture is doing the heavy lifting in Australia's economic recovery and the Australian Government is standing shoulder to shoulder with our farmers so they can boost production to $100 billion by 2030. The industry provides significant employment opportunities across regional and rural Australia both directly and indirectly. Over 313,000 people are employed in Australian agriculture and a further 247,000 employed in the food and beverage manufacturing sector.

The government is committed to providing the foundations for industry to not only achieve its goal, but to help farmers build resilience and access new markets across the world. Both industry and the government recognise that creating and meeting demand for Australian produce is essential to the competitiveness and profitability of our primary industries and provides benefits for the whole Australian community.

More broadly, the Parliament—and not individual citizens—exercises control over government expenditure and taxation arrangements through the passage of appropriation, taxation and other legislation. Consistent with Australia's constitutional requirements, taxation cannot be arbitrary; a mechanism to allow some taxpayers to 'opt out' on various grounds would negatively affect horizontal equity in the tax system, as taxpayers in otherwise similar circumstances would pay a different amount of tax.

Instead, in Australia's system of representative democracy, it is the proper role of elected representatives to decide appropriate taxation and spending arrangements. As such, it is right and proper for citizens to raise their concerns directly with us through such mechanisms as this petition, and I thank you for bringing it to my attention.
I have sent a copy of this letter to the Treasurer, the Hon Josh Frydenberg MP.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Agriculture and Northern Australia, Mr Littleproud
cc. The Hon Josh Frydenberg MP, Treasurer
Migration
Dear Mr O'Dowd

Thank you for your correspondence of 14 February 2022 to the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon Alex Hawke MP, enclosing Petition EN3658 with 448 signatures, seeking inclusion of siblings of Australian citizens and permanent residents as immediate family for the purpose of an automatic exemption from Australia's travel restrictions. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Minister for Home Affairs as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

As of 21 February 2022, all fully vaccinated visa holders, including those with a visitor visa, will be able to enter Australia without a travel exemption. This further re-opening of our international border will ensure we protect the health of Australians, while we continue to secure our economic recovery.

The Australian Border Force Commissioner's travel exemption system will remain in place for unvaccinated travellers. Visa holders who are not fully vaccinated will still require a valid travel exemption to enter Australia, and will be subject to state and territory quarantine requirements.
The most up-to-date announcements and information on who can travel to Australia, and the requirements that apply can be found at: https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3658 to the Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Mrs Andrews
Private Health Insurance
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 14 February 2022 concerning flexible waiting times for pregnancy related policies (petition number EN3691).

The private health insurance reforms that introduced the Gold, Silver, Bronze and Basic product tiers in 2019 have made private health insurance simpler and helped people choose the cover that best suits their needs. What is, and what is not covered in these tiers, is based on minimum standard clinical categories.

The pregnancy and birth clinical category must be covered in products in the Gold product tier however, insurers have flexibility to provide coverage for pregnancy and birth in the Basic, Bronze, or Silver tiers. This is a commercial decision for insurers.

Coverage requirements for product tiers were developed in close consultation with healthcare providers and were formulated to provide products that balance service coverage with premium affordability.

Generally, benefits paid for pregnancy and birth are significant, and warrant a higher level of product and premiums. The level of benefits paid is reflective of the fees charged by medical practitioners and hospitals, that operate as private businesses, and are free to place their own value on services provided. The Australian Government has no authority to determine the fees charged by medical practitioners.

While health insurers cannot apply waiting periods in excess of the maximum levels set out in the Private Health Insurance Act 2007 (12 months for obstetric treatment), they may choose to apply reduced waiting periods on a case-by-case basis. This is a commercial decision for insurers. Signatories to the petition may wish to engage individual private health insurers on whether a reduction in waiting periods may be applied or other assistance offered.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Health Care
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 14 February 2022 concerning petition EN3770, a request to establish a National Centre for Disease Control (CDC).

A National CDC would not add to Australia's proven expertise and capacity to effectively respond to national communicable disease outbreaks. Additional structures could risk overlap and duplication with existing communicable disease control functions.

My Department, through the Office of Health Protection and Response (Office), is leading the COVID-19 response. The Office is staffed by a range of expert medical advisers, epidemiologists, pandemic policy and logistics specialists, and utilises its networks to collaborate with internal and external experts and stakeholders, including state and territory governments, through established mechanisms, such as National Cabinet.

National Cabinet is advised by the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC). The AHPPC is supported by a number of expert advisory committees including the jurisdictionally based Public Health Laboratory Network (PHLN) and the Communicable Diseases Network Australia (CDNA).

PHLN and CDNA are comprised of directors and managers from Australian public health pathology laboratories and public health units. These networks, among several others, are providing technical advice on the evolution of the COVID-19 pandemic in the Australian context, to inform response activities.

In 2017 Australia voluntarily requested the World Health Organization undertake a Joint External Evaluation (JEE) as part of our ongoing commitment to the monitoring and evaluation of our core capacities under the International Health Regulations (IHR) (2005).

The JEE review reported that Australia has a comprehensive system of capabilities and functions to prepare, detect and respond to health security threats and has fully implemented the necessary legislation to implement the IHR (2005). The JEE team commended Australia on our proactive support to other Member States in the region to achieve their core capacities under IHR (2005). The full JEE review, including results and priority actions, is available at:
www.who.int/ihr/publications/WHO-WHE-CPI-REP-2018.8/en.

The health and safety of all Australians is of paramount importance to the Australian Government. The Government continues to take a strong and decisive approach in responding to COVID-19, based on the latest medical advice from the AHPPC and is committed to keeping all Australians as safe and well as possible.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Alcohol
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 14 February 2022 concerning Petition EN3782—The display of alcohol content on bar taps.

I would like to assure the signatories of this Petition that the Australian Government remains committed to improving the health, safety and social wellbeing of the community and preventing and minimising alcohol related harms for all Australians.

This commitment is outlined in the National Alcohol Strategy 2019-2028 (Strategy) and the National Preventive Health Strategy 2021-2030. The Strategy aims to prevent and minimise alcohol-related harms among individuals, families and communities by identifying agreed national priority areas of focus and policy options. Implementation of the Strategy is a shared responsibility of the Government, state and territory governments and non-government sectors.

One of the priorities in the Strategy is 'Improving community safety and amenity' and includes requiring licensees to ensure staff are trained in Responsible Service of Alcohol requirements. These requirements, and other matters associated with retail sales and point of sale materials, are largely the responsibility of state and territory governments.
The signatories of this Petition may wish to raise this issue with their state or territory authority which regulates alcohol sales.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
Somalia
Dear Mr O'Dowd
Thank you for your email regarding Petition Number EN3798 on Somaliland.

Australia, in line with the broader international community, does not recognise Somaliland as an independent state, but considers it as part of Somalia. Australia respects the territorial integrity and unity of Somalia and considers it for the Somali people to determine their future constitutional status, including the status of semi-autonomous regions.

Australia seeks to make a constructive contribution to international efforts to achieve stability and security in Somalia. Australia provided over $15 million in funding for humanitarian support to Somalia between 2018-21.

We are closely monitoring the elections in Somalia and note the completion of House of the People elections in Somaliland as part of this process. Australia continues to call for inclusive, free and fair elections to be completed across the country.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Payne
Koalas
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 14 February 2022 concerning a petition from the Standing Committee on Petitions (EN3804) for funds to oversee research to establish accurate data on koala population, health and habitat in Victoria and establish a National Koala Protection Act across Australia.

Recently, I made the decision to up-list the koala (combined populations of Queensland, New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory) (the listed koala) from Vulnerable to Endangered under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999. This was based on an assessment undertaken by the independent Threatened Species Scientific Committee. The assessment found the listed koala populations have suffered declines from prolonged drought and the impact of the 2019-2020 black summer bushfires, disease and habitat loss. The up-listing will strengthen the level of protections under the established rigorous and transparent regulatory framework for its protection as a matter of national environmental significance.

While the Victorian and South Australian populations are subject to similar threats, these populations are considered overall stable. As Victorian koalas are not part of the nationally listed population, koala welfare and management issues within Victoria are principally matters for the Victorian Government.

Since 2016, the Australian Government has invested more than $74 million in recovering the listed Koala. This includes investment in the next four years of $10 million for community-led initiatives, $20 million for large-scale koala habitat and health projects, $2 million to improve koala health outcomes and $1 million for koala care, treatment and tirage. Although not directly for Victorian and South Australian populations, the knowledge outcomes from this investment will benefit all koala populations.

The recovery plan for the listed koala acknowledges the need to manage the listed koala populations in context of its relationship with the Victorian and South Australian populations. In recognising this, I announced $IO million to continue the National Koala Monitoring Program, which includes monitoring populations of Victoria and South Australia.

Currently the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) are managing this program and have identified the surrounding Ballarat region (Moorabol area) as a potential area for establishing a monitoring site. Other sites across Victoria are being established. Interested groups are strongly encouraged to contact CSIRO at koalamonitoring@csiro.au if they wish to get involved.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment, Ms Ley
Fertility Treatment
Dear Chair
I refer to your correspondence of 14 February 2021 concerning petition EN3808 which requests discounting the cost of egg-freezing treatments for women aged between 28 and 37 years.

The Australian Government is committed to ensuring that all Australians are able to access timely and affordable, high quality health care by providing medical benefits (rebates) for services listed on the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS), subsidised medicines via the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS), and free hospital services for public patients in public hospitals.

The Government is investing record funding in Medicare, $125.7 billion over the next four years, to provide more support to Australians as we face some of the greatest health challenges in a generation. This includes significant funding to support access to assisted reproductive technology (ART) services. In 2020-21, total expenditure on ART services through the MBS and the PBS was around $500 million.

Medicare rebates are available for professional medical services associated with egg-retrieval and freezing. However, under the Medicare legislation, for a service to attract a Medicare rebate, it must be clinically relevant. For ART services, this means a patient must be experiencing medical infertility. It is up to each clinician to apply their professional judgement to determine if a service is clinically relevant for each patient.
Thank you for bringing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair

I refer to your correspondence of 14 February 2022 concerning a petition requesting that the House of Representatives ensure the Omicron variant, and any future variants which are infectious despite previous vaccination, are treated as separate pandemics.

It is important to note that treating new variants of SARS-CoV-2 (the virus that causes COVID-19) as separate pandemics would not alter the public health response. Variants are different versions of the same virus and a number of variants of SARS-CoV-2 have been identified globally. A variant becomes a variant of concern when there is evidence that it may have increased transmissibility or immune escape, or has the potential to cause more severe disease.

The Omicron variant was designated a variant of concern by the World Health Organization on 26 November 2021. It was first detected in Australia on 28 November 2021 and has since become the dominant variant of SARS-CoV-2 circulating in Australia.

While the Omicron variant does differ from other variants seen in Australia, it is not a new disease. Preliminary data suggests that infection with Omicron protects against infection from other SARS-CoV-2 variants and the current vaccines that have been rolled out across Australia remain effective.

There is evidence that suggests vaccination is not as effective in preventing a person from contracting Omicron when compared to the Delta variant. However, vaccination continues to be effective in preventing serious disease and death in those who do contract the disease. A third dose of vaccine has been shown to further reduce the likelihood of severe disease and death from Omicron.

The Australian Government's COVID-19 response continues to be informed by the best possible medical and scientific advice. We continue to monitor the situation closely and are ready to respond quickly to changing information and circumstances, including the possibility of new variants of SARS-CoV-2 emerging in Australia.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Hunt (Petition No. EN3814)
Euthanasia
Dear Chair

Thank you for your letter of 14 February 2022 regarding the petition to repeal section 50A of the Northern Territory (Self Government) Act 1978 (the Northern Territory Self Government Act) to allow the Northern Territory to enact laws dealing with voluntary assisted dying (PN0527).

The Australian Government recognises members of the community have strong views about dying with dignity, compassion and with minimal pain. The Australian Government believes people should have access to quality palliative care and relief from pain and suffering and, where possible, people should be able to choose the extent of active medical treatment they receive. The underlying principle of our investment in health services is quality of life, and this includes during end of life care.

The Australian Government does not intend to introduce legislation to repeal the Euthanasia Laws Act 1997(Cth) that inserted provisions preventing the Northern Territory from legislating to permit euthanasia. I note on 4 August 2021, Senator Sam McMahon introduced the Ensuring Northern Territory Rights Bill 2021 into Parliament. This private members' bill seeks to amend the Northern Territory Self Government Act to remove limits on the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly's powers to make laws in relation to a range of matters, including voluntary assisted dying. The Bill is currently before the Senate.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Regional Development and Territories, Mrs Marino
COMMITTEES
Treaties Joint Committee
Report

Mr SHARMA (Wentworth) (11:07): On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, I present the committee's report entitled Report 200: International Labour Organization protocol of 2014 to the Forced Labour Convention, 1930.

span.span: Report made a parliamentary paper in accordance with standing order 39(e).

subdebateinfo.title: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Joint Committee

p.span: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Joint Committee
Report
Mr SHARMA (Wentworth) (11:08): On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the report entitled Strengthening Australia's Relationships in the Pacific.
Report made a parliamentary paper in accordance with standing order 39(e).

Mr SHARMA: by leave—As recent news events have illustrated to us, the Pacific is a region of incredible strategic defence, military and development importance to Australia and it is important that we maintain our position as the primary partner of choice for these countries, the security guarantor for these countries, the preferred development partner for these countries and the leading exemplar of soft power in the region. I believe that we have made a number of important steps in recent years in both recognising the importance of this region to our own strategic interests, recognising our humanitarian obligations to this region and increasing the level of Australian engagement accordingly through programs like the Pacific Step-Up, through expanded labour mobility programs, through expanding and enhancing our diplomatic presence in the region, through enhancing our defence engagement and defence partnership with the region, and through programs like the scholarships, educational exchanges and even, indeed, sports diplomacy.

The report that the committee is tabling today, Strengthening Australia's relationships with countries in the Pacific, seeks to build upon what has been achieved already in the Pacific Step-Up. I must also at this juncture commend some of the measures announced in the budget on Tuesday evening which increase our level of development assistance to the Pacific and also provide a number of new initiatives to enhance our relationship.

Australia can no longer assume that our interests in the Pacific will look after themselves. We've had to contend with outside powers seeking to exert influence before, but those sorts of developments have generally been of a more manageable variety: rivalry between Taiwan and the mainland of China for diplomatic recognition in the late 1990s and 2000s; some occasional forays from nations like Russia, Iran, even Libya for a period, but nothing like what we're seeing in terms of the level of interest from Beijing and China's government in the Pacific. Of course, something that has been in the news much this week is the potential partnership agreement between the Solomon Islands and China, which, if it were to allow the establishment of a military presence, permanent or nonpermanent, in the Solomon Islands, would pose a grave risk to Australia's strategic and defence interests.

What that means, though, in short is we need to work harder in the Pacific. We need to invest more time and resources and people and diplomacy and development and defence assets in the Pacific, and we should no longer assume that these nations will take us for granted. We need to both address their priorities and listen to their concerns. With this in mind, the committee heard evidence from a number of Pacific island countries, think tanks, academics and others about some of the initiatives they would like to see, and this report seeks to elaborate on those. Firstly, the report recommends that we lead a large-scale, multiyear post-COVID aid and recovery package for the Pacific. I note that the government has announced such a package. They're building on it in the budget, but it's incredibly important, given the dependence of some of those countries in particular on tourism receipts, that we help their economies rebuild after a period when they've had almost no tourist dollars come in. We also recommend that Australia seeks to build upon existing and expanding labour mobility schemes with the Pacific to make sure that such schemes provide career development options so people can move up the skills ladder and take better skills back. Also, Australia seeks to build limited permanent residency pathways so that people who are making an enduring commitment to this nation also have options to reside here longer term.

As a committee we heard a lot of evidence about the exceptional importance of climate change as an issue facing the Pacific, and the report emphasises and recommends that climate change mitigation and climate change adaptation efforts be a high priority in Australia's assistance to the region but also our diplomatic engagement with the region. For most of these countries, they see this as an existential challenge, and they look to Australia to take the lead on this issue both domestically and internationally.

We also make recommendations that the federal court's judiciary program in the Pacific continue to be supported; that we look at the creation of a dedicated Pacific component to Australia's permanent migration intake, similar to what New Zealand offers to these countries, as a way of strengthening our people-to-people and cultural ties; and that we look at expanding Australia's media and broadcasting footprint in the Pacific, recognising that this is a key element of Australia's soft power. The information domain is increasingly contested in these countries, and we need to make sure that we, Australia, remain a trusted source of unbiased and fact based news for these countries, given that there are alternatives available.

Finally, while the committee take no particular view on the outcome of these explorations, we do recommend that we explore ambitious proposals for deeper integration with the Pacific, such as a long-term compact of free association. I commend this report to the House.

Mr GORMAN (Perth) (11:14): by leave—I too rise to speak on this report of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I'll start by commending the work of the chair, who's done an excellent job in chairing the committee, and acknowledging the deputy chair, the member for Bruce—who would be speaking on this report if it weren't for the fact that, unfortunately, he currently has COVID. I'll thank the committee members for their work and also the secretariat. We saw in the submissions that were put to this inquiry the great enthusiasm from the foreign policy community in Australia and indeed business, trade unions and academia about the opportunities for Australia that lie in the Pacific.

One recommendation that I think does need to be picked up is to acknowledge that while there was a Pacific Step-up there is so much more to be done. Recommendation 1 notes that Australia should lead a 'large-scale, multi-year post-COVID-19 aid and recovery package within the Pacific islands region', looking for not just a step-up but 'transformative public investment'. And I think it is that transformative public investment that we need in order to fully realise the potential of the Pacific as well as to realise our ambitions in helping our Pacific neighbours to achieve their goals.

I note that this is one of four inquiries that the broader Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee has completed that focus on the Pacific, and I commend the chair of the joint standing committee for their leadership in getting us to that point of having a multi-report response to some of the opportunities that lie in the Pacific. Australia's relationship with the Pacific is—and must be—a forever partnership. A region as diverse as the Pacific will of course have diverse views and diverse opportunities. But what we did see was a universally positive association with Australia's engagement and that we are seen as a first responder when our friends in the Pacific face a crisis. But of course that is not enough. We should also be the partner of choice for our Pacific partners to address shared challenges in our region. Unfortunately we have seen some signs that this may no longer be happening, and the impact of COVID in the Pacific highlights more than ever the importance of Australia working with Pacific neighbours to deliver a region is both secure and sovereign.

Beyond those challenges that the chair outlined, we also have the challenge of climate change. While the report rightly identifies climate change as an issue facing the Pacific region, I believe it fails to fully capture the significance of the challenge. I fear that the government has always dealt with climate change as an issue for domestic politics rather than something where Australia needs to be seen on the world stage as a good, honest long-term actor. We can no longer let down our Pacific neighbours by failing to take climate change seriously both at home and in our work abroad.

I'd also like to highlight John Blaxland's 'grand compact' proposal—that is, that Australia offer a compact of association with South Pacific countries for shared governance, somewhat similar to what New Zealand has done. The committee has recommended that the Australian government consider this proposal, with, as the chair mentioned, a permanent migration intake similar to that in the New Zealand model.

Finally, I want to talk about Radio Australia. It was 25 years ago that the Howard government made significant cuts to Radio Australia. This report says that we have to change direction. We need to reinvigorate Radio Australia, which is well regarded in the region, and to boost its digital appeal. We know that soft diplomacy, using our media assets and using things like Radio Australia, is a huge opportunity to share stories of the Pacific and stories of Australia with our neighbours. Continuing to invest in things such as Radio Australia is just one simple way that we can reverse some of the damage that's been done over many years in our relationship with the Pacific.
Mr SHARMA (Wentworth) (11:19): I move:
That the House take note of the report.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Mr Rick Wilson ): In accordance with standing order 39, the debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for a later hour this day.
Reference to Federation Chamber
Mr SHARMA (Wentworth) (11:19): I move:
That the order of the day be referred to the Federation Chamber for debate.
Question agreed to.
Report

Ms SWANSON (Paterson) (11:19): On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs Defence and Trade, I present the committee's report, incorporating a dissenting report, entitled Inquiry into PFAS remediation in and around Defence bases: Final report.
Report made a parliamentary paper in accordance with standing order 39(e).

Ms SWANSON: by leave—This is the third and final report of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the national PFAS Investigation and Management Program. The committee has consistently heard about the stress and uncertainty that PFAS remediation places on residents in affected communities. The committee heard about the lack of government information, about a lack of trust in government information, which has developed in and around the communities impacted by PFAS. It is essential that the Australian government ensure that this is open, direct and timely when information and updates are provided to the community. This should hold whether there is good news, bad news or even no progress to communicate. Those communities have demonstrated that they need to be kept in the information loop where this contaminant is concerned.

The committee has made eight recommendations to the Australian government, which provide some practical suggestions that may assist the government in ensuring that the PFAS response meets the needs of these communities. The committee heard pfas.gov.au, the website, is intended to be the central information starting point for people. It's where they are directed to go for information. However, during the course of this inquiry, the committee noted that this website went over 500 days without any news or new updates, especially at a time when people were relying, because of COVID, on virtual information. It just seemed outstanding to the community members—shocking, in fact—that the website that is supposed to be the key portal for them to receive information had been left untouched for almost two years. Surely there'd been work done in that time.

The committee has recommended that the Australian government ensure that each federal government department publish quarterly updates on work to date on pfas.gov.au. This will provide more assurance for communities that work is not stalling or, in fact, anything is being done at all. One community witness recognised that the Department of Defence is having, 'A red-hot crack at cleaning up this mess.' Indeed, Mr Lindsay Clout from my electorate spoke of that. I know that he has been heavily involved. I want to thank him and all the community members who took the time to come before our committee and contribute to this report. They have done a really great job in communicating what has been going on in their lives over the past six years. It's been a travesty for many of them.

The evidence received by the committee from government agencies revealed the range of work being undertaken, from the establishment of national standards for chemical regulation to the testing of remediation technologies.
